b. If the element involves a result of his/her conduct, he/she is aware that it is practically certain that his/her conduct will cause such a result.

(3) Recklessly: a person acts recklessly with respect to an element of an offense when he/she consciously disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the element exists or will result from his/her conduct. The risk must be of such a nature and degree that, considering the nature and purpose of the person's conduct and the circumstances known to him/her, its disregard involves a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a law-abiding person would observe in the actor's situation.

(4) Negligently: a person acts negligently with respect to an element of an offense when he/she should be aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the element exists or will result from his/her conduct. The risk must be of such a nature and degree that the actor's failure to perceive it, considering the nature and purpose of their conduct and the circumstances known to them, involves a gross deviation from the standard of care that a reasonable person would observe in the actor's situation.

(5) Strict Liability: an element of an offense shall involve strict liability only when the definition of the offense or element clearly indicates a legislative purpose to impose strict liability for an element of the offense by use of the phrase "strict liability" or other terms of similar import, and when so used no proof of a culpable mental state is required to establish the commission of the element or offense.

C. When the culpability sufficient to establish an element of an offense is not specifically prescribed, such element is established if a person acts purposely, knowingly, or recklessly with respect thereto.

D. When the law defining an offense prescribes the kind of culpability that is sufficient for the commission of an offense, without distinguishing among the elements thereof, such provision shall apply to all the material elements of the offense, unless a contrary purpose plainly appears.

E. When the law provides that negligence suffices to establish an element of an offense, such element also is established if a person acts purposely, knowingly or recklessly. When recklessness suffices to establish an element, such element is also established if a person acts purposely or knowingly. When acting knowingly suffices to establish an element, such element is also established if a person acts purposely.

F. When a particular purpose is an element of an offense, the element is established although such purpose is conditional, unless the condition negates the harm or evil sought to be prevented by the offense.

G. When knowledge of the existence of a particular fact is an element of an offense, such knowledge is established if a person is, or should be, aware of a high probability of its existence, unless he/she actually believes that it does not exist.

H. A requirement that an offense be committed willfully is satisfied if a person acts knowingly with respect to the material elements of the offense, unless a purpose to impose further requirements appears.

I. Neither the knowledge nor recklessness nor negligence as to whether conduct constitutes an offense or as to the existence, meaning or application of the law determining the elements of an offense is an element of such offense, unless the definition of the offense so provides.

J. When the grade or degree of an offense depends on whether the offense is committed purposely, knowingly, recklessly, or criminally negligently, its grade or degree shall be the lowest for which the determinative kind of culpability is established with respect to any material element of the offense.

Section 4-2-3. Causal Relationships Between Conduct and Result.

A. Conduct is the cause of a result when:

(1) It is an antecedent but for which the result in question would not have occurred; and

(2) The relationship between the conduct and result satisfies any additional causal requirements imposed by this Code or the definition of the offense.

(3) When a particular mental state is specified in conjunction with an element of an offense, proof of that element is not avoided because the actual result differed from that intended or that which was probable or likely under the circumstances, either in kind or degree or because a different person or property was injured or affected than that intended or than that which was probable or likely under the circumstances. Unless such differences are sufficient without consideration of the mental state involved to constitute a defense or avoidance or unless such differences are of such a magnitude that it would be unjust to find the element involved in light of such differences.

Section 4-2-4. Ignorance or Mistake.

A. Ignorance or mistake as to a matter of fact or law is a defense only if:

(1) The ignorance or mistake negates a specific mental state required to establish an element of the offense; or

(2) The law provided that the actual state of mind, which existed itself, constitutes a defense.

B. Although ignorance or mistake would otherwise afford a defense to the offense charged, the defense is not available if the defendant would be guilty of another offense if the situation had been as he/she supposed in which case the punishment available upon conviction shall not exceed that prescribed for the other offense.

C. A belief that conduct does not legally constitute an offense is a defense for the prosecution of an offense based on that conduct only when:

(1) The enactment defining the offense is not known to the person and has not been published or reasonably made available prior to the conduct alleged; or

(2) The person acted in reasonable reliance upon an official statement of law contained in a subsequent enactment or an interpretation rendered by a Judge in a written opinion. In either case the defendant shall have the burden of proving, by a preponderance of the evidence, his/her defense under this subsection.

Section 4-2-5. Liability for Conduct of Another.

A. A person is guilty of an offense if it is committed by his/her own conduct or by the conduct of another person for whom he/she is legally responsible, or both.

B. A person is legally responsible for the conduct of another person when:

(1) Acting with the kind of culpability that is sufficient for the commission of the offense, he/she causes an innocent or irresponsible person to engage in such conduct; or

(2) He/she is made responsible for the conduct of such other person by this Code or the definition of the offense; or

(3) He/she is an accomplice of such other person in the commission of the offense.

C. A person is an accomplice of another person in the commission of an offense if:

(1) With the purpose promoting or facilitating the commission of an offense, he/she;

a. Solicits such other person to commit it; or

b. Aids, agrees or attempts to aid such person in planning or committing it; or

c. Having legal duty to prevent the commission of the offense, fails to make proper effort to do so; or

d. His/her conduct is expressly declared by law to establish his/her complicity.

D. When causing a particular result is an element of an offense, an accomplice in the conduct causing such result, is an accomplice in the commission of that offense if he/she acts with the kind of culpability, if any, with respect to that result that is sufficient for the commission of the offense.

E. A person is legally incapable of committing a particular offense him/herself may be guilty thereof if it is committed by the conduct of another person for whom he/she is legally responsible, unless such liability is inconsistent with the purpose of his/her incapacity.

F. Unless otherwise provided by this Code or by the law defining the offense, a person is not an accomplice in an offense committed by another person, if:

(1) He/she is a victim of that offense; or

(2) The offense is so defined that his/her conduct is inevitably incident to its commission; or

(3) He/she terminates his/her complicity prior to the commission of the offense and

a. wholly deprives it of effectiveness in the offense, or

b. gives timely warning to law enforcement authorities or otherwise makes proper effort to prevent the commission of the offense.

G. An accomplice may be convicted on proof of the commission of the offense and of his/her complicity therein, though the person claimed to have committed the offense has not been prosecuted or convicted or has been convicted of a different offense or degree of offense or has immunity from prosecution or has been acquitted.

Section 4-2-6. Corporations and Unincorporated Associations.

A. A person is legally responsible for any conduct he/she performs or causes to be performed in the name of a corporation or unincorporated association or in its behalf to the same extent as if it were performed in his/her own name or behalf.

B. Whenever a duty to act is imposed by law upon a corporation or unincorporated association, any agent of the corporation or association having primary responsibility for the discharge of the duty is legally responsible for a reckless omission to perform the required act to the same extent as if the duty were imposed by law directly upon them.

C. When a person is convicted of an offense by reason of his/her legal responsibility for the conduct of a corporation or an unincorporated association, he/she is subject to the sentence authorized by law when a natural person is convicted of an offense of the class involved.

Section 4-2-7. Intoxication.

A. Except as provided in Subsection D of this Section, intoxication of a person is not a defense unless it negates an element of the offense.

B. When recklessness establishes an element of the offense, if a person, due to self-induced intoxication, is unaware of a risk of which he/she would have been aware had he/she been sober, such unawareness is immaterial.

C. Intoxication does not, in itself, constitute a mental disease as that term is used in this Code.

D. Intoxication which (a) is not self-induced, or (b) is the result of intoxication excessive in degree given the amount of the intoxicant, to which result the actor does not know he/she is susceptible, is an affirmative defense, if by reason of such intoxication, the person at the time of his/her conduct lacks substantial capacity either to appreciate its wrongfulness or to conform his/her conduct to the requirements of the law.

E. "Intoxication" means a disturbance of mental or physical capabilities and/or capacities resulting from the introduction of substances into the body. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, intoxication can be proven by its external indications and no proof of specific consumption or blood alcohol content is necessary, though such evidence is permissible to prove intoxication.

Section 4-2-8. Duress.

A. Except as herein otherwise provided, it is an affirmative defense that a person engaged in conduct charged to constitute an offense because he/she was coerced to do so by the use of, or threat to use, unlawful force against his/her person or the person of another, which a law abiding person of reasonable firmness in his/her situation would have been unable to resist.

B. The defense provided in this Section is unavailable to a person who intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly places him/herself in a situation in which it is probable that he/she will be subjected to duress.

C. It is not a defense that a woman acted on the command of her husband, unless she acted under such coercion as would establish a defense under Subsection A of this Section. No presumption of duress arises from the mere presence of the husband at the time a woman acted.

D. The defense provided in this Section is unavailable in any situation where the coerced conduct threatens to cause death or serious bodily harm to some person, other than the actor, or does in fact cause such harm.

Section 4-2-9. Consent.

A. The consent of the victim to conduct charged to constitute an offense or to the result thereof is a defense if such consent negates an element of the offense or precluded the infliction of the harm or evil sought to be prevented by the law defining the offense.

B. When conduct is charged to constitute an offense because it threatens to cause or causes bodily harm, consent to such conduct or to the infliction of such harm is a defense only if:

(1) The bodily harm consented to or threatened by the conduct consented to is not serious; or

(2) The conduct and the harm are reasonably foreseeable hazards of joint participation in a lawful athletic contest, competitive sport or other lawful activity; or

(3) The consent establishes a justification for the conduct under this Code.

C. Unless otherwise provided by this Code or the law defining the offense, assent does not constitute consent if:

(1) It is given by a person who is legally incompetent to authorize the conduct charged to constitute an offense; or

(2) It is given by a person who by reason of youth, mental disease or defect, or intoxication is manifestly unable or known to the actor to be unable to make a reasonable judgment as to the nature or the harmfulness of the conduct charged to constitute the offense; or

(3) It is given by a person whose improvident consent is sought to be prevented by the law defining the offense; or

(4) It is induced by force, duress, or deception.

Section 4-2-10. Entrapment.

A. A public law enforcement officer or official or a person acting in cooperation with such an official perpetrates an entrapment if for the purpose of obtaining evidence of the commission of an offense, he/she induces or encourages another person to engage in conduct constituting an offense by either:

(1) Making knowingly false representations designed to induce the belief that such conduct is not prohibited; or

(2) Employing methods of persuasion or inducement, which create a substantial risk that such an offense will be committed by persons other than those who are ready to commit it.

B. The defense afforded by this Section shall be unavailable when causing or threatening bodily injury is an element of the offense charged and the prosecution is based on conduct causing or threatening such injury to a person other than the person perpetrating the entrapment.

C. Except as provided in Subsection B of this Section, a person prosecuted for an offense shall be acquitted if he/she proves by a preponderance of evidence that his/her conduct occurred in response to an entrapment. The issue of entrapment shall be tried to and decided by the Court and not by the jury. Evidence of past offenses shall be admissible only if the defendant takes the stand in his/her own defense.

Section 4-2-11. Mental Disease or Defect

A. In any prosecution for an offense, it shall be a defense that the defendant, at the time of the conduct upon which the prosecution is based, as a result of mental disease or defect, lacked substantial capacity either to appreciate the wrongfulness of his/her conduct or to conform his/her conduct to the requirements of the law.

B. As used in this Section, the terms "mental disease" or "defect" do not include an abnormality manifested only by repeated criminal or otherwise antisocial conduct.

C. The defense afforded by this Section shall not be available unless notice of intent to rely on such defense is given at least two weeks before trial. By giving such notice, the defendant will be deemed to have consented to be examined for the prosecution by not more than two professional medical or other experts for the purpose of ascertaining the state of the defendant's mental health.

D. No person who, as a result of mental disease or defect, lacks capacity to understand the proceedings against him/her or to assist in their own defense shall be tried, convicted, or sentenced for the commission of an offense so long as such incapacity endures.

Section 4-2-12. Justification.

Conduct, which is justified, is a defense to prosecution for any offense based on the conduct. The defense of justification may be claimed:

A. When a person's conduct is in defense of persons or property or as otherwise described in the next succeeding five sections (Â§4-2-13 through Â§4-2-17); or

B. When a person's conduct is reasonable and in fulfillment of his/her duties as a Tribal or governmental officer or employee; or

C. When a person's conduct is reasonable discipline of minors by parents, guardians, teachers or other persons in loco parentis (in place of parent); or

D. When a person's conduct is reasonable discipline of persons in custody under this Code.

Section 4-2-13. Force in Defense of Persons.

A. A person is justified in threatening or using force against another when, and to the extent that he/she reasonably believes, that such force is necessary to defend him/herself or a third person against such other's imminent use of unlawful force; however, a person is justified in using force which is intended or likely to cause death or serious bodily injury only if he/she reasonably believes that such force is necessary to prevent death or serious bodily injury to him/herself or a third person.

B. A person is not justified in using force under the circumstances specified in Subsection A of this Section if he/she:

(1) Initially provokes the use of force against him/herself with the intent to use force against as an excuse to inflict bodily harm upon the assailant; or

(2) Is, attempting to commit, committing, or fleeing after the commission of an offense; or

(3) Was the aggressor or was engaged in a combat by agreement, unless he/she withdraws from the encounter and effectively communicates to such other person his/her intent to do so and the other, notwithstanding, continues or threatens to continue the use of unlawful force,

Section 4-2-14. Force in Arrest.

Any person is justified in using any force, except deadly force, which he/she reasonably believes to be necessary to affect an arrest or to defend him/herself or another from bodily harm while making an arrest.

Section 4-2-15. Deadly Force by Law Enforcement Officer.

A law enforcement officer or any person acting by his/her command in his/her aid and assistance is justified in using deadly force when:

A. In effecting the arrest or preventing an escape from custody following an arrest and the officer reasonably believes that both:

(1) Such force is necessary to prevent the arrest from being defeated by resistance or escape; and;

(2) The person to be arrested is attempting to escape by use of a deadly weapon.

B. The officer is in the performance of his/her legal duty or the execution of legal process and reasonably believes the use of force is necessary to protect themselves or others from imminent danger to life.

Section 4-2-16. Force in Defense of Habitation.

A person is justified in using force against another when, and to the extent, that he/she reasonably believes that the force is necessary to prevent or terminate the other's unlawful entry into or attack upon their place of habitation; however, he/she is justified in the use of force which is intended or likely to cause death or serious bodily injury only if:

A. The entry is made or attempted in a violent and tumultuous manner and he/she reasonably believes that the entry is attempted or made for the purpose of assaulting or offering personal violence to any dwelling or person therein, and that the force is necessary to prevent the assault or offering of personal violence; or

B. He/she reasonably believes that the entry is made or attempted for the purpose of committing a Class A offense or other offense involving threat of bodily injury therein, and that such force is necessary to prevent the commission of such offense.

Section 4-2-17. Force in Defense of Property.

A person is justified in using or threatening to use force, other than deadly force, against another when and to the extent that he/she reasonably believes that force is necessary to prevent or terminate criminal interference with real or personal property, when that property is:

A. Lawfully in his/her possession; or

B. Lawfully in the possession of his/her immediate family; or

C. Belonging to a person whose property he/she has a legal duty to protect.

Section 4-2-18. Justification of a Defense; Civil Remedies.

A. In any prosecution based on conduct, which is justified as specified in this Code, such justification is an affirmative defense.

B. The fact that conduct is justifiable as specified in this Code does not abolish or impair any civil right or remedy, which might arise from such conduct.

CHAPTER 3 SENTENCES AND PUNISHMENT

Section 4-3-1. Sentencing in General.

A. A person adjudged guilty of an offense under this Code shall be sentenced in accordance in accordance with this chapter.

B. Penal laws enacted or adopted after the effective date of this Code shall be classified for sentencing purposes in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter.

Section 4-3-2. Designation of Offenses.

Offenses are designated as Class A offenses, Class B offenses, and Class C offenses.

Section 4-3-3. Class of Offense Not Specified.

Any offense for which no penalty or sentence is specified, or which is not specifically designated as a certain class of offense, shall be treated for purposes of sentencing and punishment as a Class C offense.

Section 4-3-4. General Principles.

The sentence imposed in each case should call for the minimum amount of custody or confinement, which is consistent with the protection of the public, the severity of the offense, and the rehabilitative needs of the defendant.

Section 4-3-5. Sentences and Combinations of Sentences; Civil, Penalties.

A. A Court may, as provided in this chapter, sentence a person adjudged guilty of an offense to any one of the following sentences or a combination of such sentences:

(1) To pay a fine; or

(2) Removal from and/or disqualification of public or private office, but only if such is specifically provided for as a punishment for conviction of a specific offense; or

(3) Probation and/or suspension of sentence on such terms and conditions as the Court may direct; or

(4) Imprisonment or confinement, either full or part time.

B. A Court shall also have the authority to order a person found guilty of an offense to pay any or all of the following amounts or to do the following acts:

(1) Pay court costs not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00); or

(2) Pay any civil penalty provided by law; or

(3) Pay money damages, surrender property, or perform any other act for the benefit of any person or party injured personally, or in his/her property, by the person found guilty, provided such injuries are fairly attributable to the act or failure to act constituting the offense for which guilty was adjudged.

C. This part shall not deprive a Court of authority to cite for contempt, cancel or suspend a license, forfeit property, or do any other act or make any other order authorized by law.

Section 4-3-6. Maximum Fines and Sentences of Imprisonment.

A. A person convicted of an offense may be sentences as follows:

(1) Class A offense â to a term of imprisonment not to exceed twelve (12) months and to a fine not to exceed five-thousand dollars ($5,000.00);

(2) Class B offense â to a term of imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months and to a fine not to exceed one-thousand dollars ($1,000.00);

(3) Class C offense â to a term of imprisonment not to exceed forty-five (45) days and to a fine not to exceed five-hundred dollars ($500.00).

B. The terms of imprisonment listed above apply only to full-time incarceration in a BIA contracted or managed facility and do not apply to full-time or part-time residence or confinement in a medical or rehabilitative facility as a condition of probation or parole or as otherwise ordered by the Court.

C. The fines listed above may be imposed in addition to any assessment of costs or other civil penalties and in addition to any amounts ordered by the Court to be paid as restitution.

Section 4-3-7. Payment of Fines and Other Monies.

A. Fines shall be paid by money order or certified check only, or with the consent of the Court, may be worked off by performing approved labor for the Pueblo of Picuris, at a rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per hour, or as otherwise established by the Tribal Council.

B. The Court may, upon request of a defendant or upon its own motion, allow that any fine or other required payments be paid in installments and on conditions tailored to the means of the defendant.

C. The imposition of incarceration should not be imposed as an automatic alternative to payment of a fine or other money, but rather the Court should, upon default to pay a fine or other money as required, examine the reason for the default and may, if justice requires, impose an additional sentence of incarceration of no more than one day of incarceration for each one- hundred dollars ($100.00) of the required money left unpaid.

D. The methods available for collecting a civil judgment shall be available to collect any unpaid money upon order of the Court following a failure to make any required payment and ascertainment of a reason thereof.

E. When justice requires, the Court may revoke or remit a fine or any unpaid portion thereof or any other monies required to be paid, or may modify the terms and conditions of payment.

Section 4-3-8. Decision to Impose a Fine.

In determining whether to impose a fine and its amount, the Court should consider:

(1) The financial resources of the defendant and the burden that payment of a fine will impose with due regard to his/her other obligations;

(2) The ability of the defendant to pay a fine on an installment basis or on other conditions to be fixed by the Court;

(3) The extent to which payment of a fine will interfere with the ability of the defendant to make any ordered restitution or reparation to the victim of the crime; and

(4) Whether there are particular reasons which make a fine appropriate as a deterrent to the offense involved or appropriate as a corrective measure for the defendant.

Section 4-3-9. Concurrent and Consecutive Sentences.

A. Unless the Court shall direct otherwise in its pronouncement of sentence, all sentences shall run concurrently and not consecutively.

B. The Court shall consider the gravity and circumstances of the offenses and the history, character, and rehabilitative needs of the defendant as well the need to protect the public in determining whether to impose consecutive sentences.

C. The Court shall not impose consecutive sentences for offenses arising out of a single course of criminal conduct, including solicitation and criminal conspiracy, unless the criminal conduct involved the death or serious bodily injury of any victim of the crime or a serious threat of such, unless the offense was committed in a willful, malicious or aggravated manner and involved an offense against the person of the victim or victims.

D. In no event shall the maximum term of imprisonment imposed exceed three (3) years from the date of sentencing.

E. Whenever a sentence is imposed or sentences are imposed to run concurrently with the other or with sentences presently being served, the greater sentence shall be the term to be served with all lesser sentences merging therein, or, if equal sentences are imposed, they shall merge into one sentence, but in no event shall the imposition of one sentence cut short the time to be served on another sentence unless the Court specifically directs that such be the result.

Section 4-3-10. Credit.

A. Credit against a term of imprisonment imposed following an adjudication of guilty shall be given to a defendant for all time spent in custody as a result of the criminal charge for which the sentence is imposed or as a result of the conduct on which such charge is based. Such credit shall apply to time spent in custody prior to trial, during trial, pending sentencing, and pending resolution of an appeal.

B. In case of re-prosecution for any reason of the same offense or an offense based on the same conduct for which a defendant has been imprisoned, credit shall be given for all time spent in custody under the prior prosecution as provided in Subsection A. above.

C. Credit as provided in this Section should be considered and computed by the Court at the time of sentencing.

Section 4-3-11. Reduction of Sentences.

A. The Court may, upon motion of any party or on its own motion, reduce or modify a sentence within a reasonable time after its imposition as provided on the Rules of Criminal Procedure if new factors bearing on the sentence become known. Such reduction or modification shall be done in open Court.

B. In the event that commitment to a special type of facility, other than a detention facility, is imposed or accepted as a condition of probation or parole, the Court may for good cause shown, terminate or reduce such commitment.

C. The Court shall have authority to terminate, at any time, continued supervision or the power to revoke either a sentence not involving confinement or a sentence involving less than total confinement in a detention facility. The Court shall also have the power to lessen the conditions on which such sentences were imposed or lessen the time in which the power to revoke will exist.

D. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Chapter, the Court shall not increase a term of imprisonment once it has been imposed.

Section 4-3-12. Sentencing Proceeding.

As soon as practicable after the determination of guilt and the examination of any presentence reports or recommendations, a proceeding should be held at which the Court shall:

(1) Hear submission by the parties on the facts relevant to the sentence;

(2) Hear argument by the defendant or his/her counsel on the applicability of various sentencing alternatives to the facts of the case;

(3) Afford the defendant the opportunity to make a statement to the Court;

(4) In cases where guilt was determined by plea, be informed of the existence of plea discussions or agreements and the extent to which they involve recommendations as to the appropriate sentence;

(5) Make specific findings on all refuted issues of fact which are deemed relevant to the sentencing decision;

(6) Ascertain and consider all credits due the defendant as a result of prior periods of incarceration;

(7) Carefully state and assure that a record is made of the precise terms of the sentence imposed and assure that those responsible for the executing the sentence be informed of such terms;

(8) State for the record the reasons for selecting the particular sentence imposed, unless the Court deems it to be in the best interests of the defendant not to do so.

Section 4-3-13. Suspension of Sentence and Probation.

A. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, the Court shall have the authority to suspend the imposition of sentence on a person who has been convicted of an offense and place him/her on probation as provided herein.

B. When the Court suspends the imposition of sentence on a person who has been convicted of a crime or sentences him/her to be placed on probation, it shall attach such reasonable conditions as authorized herein, as it deems necessary to insure that he/she will lead a law abiding life or likely to assist him/her to do so.

C. The Court, as a condition of its order of probation, may require the defendant to:

(1) Meet his/her family responsibilities;

(2) Devote him/herself to a specific employment or occupation;

(3) Undergo available medical, psychiatric or other rehabilitative treatment and to enter and remain in a specified institution and/or center, when required for that purpose;

(4) Pursue a prescribed secular course of study or vocational training;

(5) Attend or reside in a facility established for the instruction, recreation or residence of persons on probation;

(6) Refrain from frequenting unlawful or disreputable places, or consorting with disreputable persons;

(7) Refrain from all use of intoxicants, narcotics or drugs, unless taken or used under a doctor's orders and obtained by a doctor's prescription;

(8) Have in his/her possession no firearms or other dangerous weapons unless written permission is granted by the Court;

(9) Make restitution for the fruits of his/her crime or to make reparation, in an amount he/she can afford to pay, for the loss of damage caused thereby;

(10) Remain within the jurisdiction of the Court and to notify the Court or the probation officer of any change of address or employment;

(11) Report as directed to the Court or the probation officer and to permit the officer to visit his/her home;

(12) Satisfy any other conditions reasonably related to the rehabilitation of the defendant and not incompatible with his/her freedom of conscience or unduly restrictive of his/her liberty given his/her status as a probationer.

D. When the Court sentences a person who has been convicted of a Class A offense or a Class B offense to be placed on probation, it may require him/her to serve a term of imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days in the case of a Class A offense and fifteen (15) days in the case of a Class B offense, as an additional condition of its order. Such term of imprisonment shall be counted as part of the period of the probation, but shall not count as part of any sentenced pronounced as a result of a revocation of probation.

E. The defendant shall be given a copy of the requirements of his/her probation stated with sufficient specificity to enable him/her to guide him/herself accordingly.

Section 4-3-14. Period of Suspension or Probation; Modification.

A. When the Court has suspended a sentence and/or has sentenced a defendant to be placed on probation, the maximum period of the suspension or probation shall be two (2) years, provided, however, that the maximum period will be imposed for Class B and Class C offenses only when such appears to be consistent with the rehabilitative needs of the defendant. Shorter periods may be imposed at the Court's discretion.

B. During the period of suspension or probation, the Court, on application of the probation officer or of the defendant, or on its own motion, may modify the requirements imposed on the defendant or add further requirements consistent with the rehabilitative needs of the defendant or may discharge the defendant.

C. Upon termination of the period of suspension or probation, or other earlier discharge of the defendant, the defendant shall be relieved of any obligations imposed by Order of the Court and shall have satisfied his/her sentence for the offense.

Section 4-3-15. Violation of Terms of Suspension or Probation.

A. At any time before the discharge of the defendant or the termination of the period of suspension or probation:

(1) The Court may summon the defendant to appear before it or it may issue a warrant for his/her arrest;

(2) A probation or law enforcement officer, having probable cause to believe the defendant has failed to comply with a requirement imposed as a condition of the probation order or that he/she has committed another crime may arrest him/her without a warrant;

(3) The Court, if there is probable cause to believe the defendant has committed another crime or if he/she has been held to answer therefore, may commit him/her without bail, pending a determination of the charge by the Court;

(4) The Court, if satisfied that the defendant has inexcusably failed to comply with a substantial requirement imposed as a condition of the probation order, or if he/she has been convicted of another crime, may revoke the suspension or probation and sentence or resentence the defendant as provided in this Code.

B. When the Court revokes a suspension or probation, it may impose on the defendant any sentence that might have been imposed originally for the crime for which he/she was convicted, except that the defendant shall not be sentenced to imprisonment unless:

(1) He/she was convicted of another crime; or

(2) His/her conduct indicates that his/her continued liberty involves undue risk that he/she will commit another crime; or

(3) Such disposition is essential to vindicate the authority of the Court.

C. The Court shall not revoke suspension or probation or increase the requirements imposed thereby except after a hearing upon written notice to the defendant on the grounds at which such action is proposed. The defendant shall have the right to hear and controvert the evidence against him/her, to offer evidence in his/her defense and to be represented by counsel of his/her choice at his/her own expense.

D. Whenever a defendant is taken into and held in custody as provided in this Section for violation of probation conditions other than the alleged commission of an offense, he/she shall be entitled to have his/her sentence considered by the Court within 48 hours of his/her confinement, unless he/she requests further time to prepare his/her defense.

Section 4-3-16. Order Removing Disqualification or Disability Based on Conviction.

A. When the Court has suspended a sentence or has sentenced the defendant to be placed on probation and the defendant has fully complied with the requirements imposed as a condition of such order and has satisfied the sentence, the Court may order that so long as the defendant is not convicted on another offense, the judgment shall not constitute a conviction for the purpose of any disqualification or disability imposed by law upon conviction of a crime or offense.

B. Proof of a conviction as relevant evidence upon the trial or determination of any issue or for the purpose of impeaching the defendant as a witness is not a disqualification or disability within the meaning of this Section.

Section 4-3-17. Final Judgment.

A judgment suspending sentence or sentencing a defendant to be placed on probation shall be deemed tentative to the extent such is modifiable as provided herein, but for all other purposes shall constitute a final judgment.

Section 4-3-18. Eligibility for Parole.

A. Except as otherwise provided herein, a defendant sentenced to and serving a term of imprisonment for more than sixty (60) days shall be eligible to petition the Court for a grant of release on parole.

B. Parole may be granted as provided herein to a defendant who has demonstrated good behavior and faithful performance of duties while incarcerated.

C. Parole shall not be considered or granted to a defendant who has been convicted of an offense involving the death or serious bodily injury of a victim of the offense unless the defendant has been sentenced to consecutive sentences totaling in excess of one (1) year and such consideration may be given only after the defendant has served one (1) year under such sentences.

D. The provisions on parole contained herein shall apply only to confinement in a jail or penitentiary and shall not apply to confinement ordered in a medical or rehabilitative facility.

Section 4-3-19. Petition for Parole.

A. Parole may be granted by the Court on its own motion or on the petition of an incarcerated defendant.

B. Any defendant eligible for parole as set forth above may petition the Court for consideration of parole. Such petition may be made on a form to be provided for such purposes by the Court, at a time no earlier than the expiration of half the period of imprisonment ordered by the Court. If a defendant desires, he/she will be allowed opportunity to contact and meet with counsel on the detention facility premises to aid him/her in the preparation of his/her petition for parole. The completed petition shall be forwarded without unnecessary delay to the Court by the defendant's counsel or by the detention facility.

Section 4-3-20. Consideration for Parole.

A. The Court, upon receipt of a petition for parole, shall cause the Clerk of the Court to prepare a report stating the term for which the defendant was sentenced, the offense(s) charged, the time served and may include a sworn statement from a detention facility caseworker regarding the conduct of the defendant while incarcerated and any other information deemed relevant by the Court.

B. Unless it appears that the defendant is not eligible for parole as a result of some reason other than his/her behavior while incarcerated, the Judge shall schedule a parole hearing within fourteen (14) days and may request a report from a probation officer on the background and rehabilitative needs of the defendant.

C. A hearing shall be held at which time the defendant shall have the right to be represented by counsel, at their own expense, and present evidence. The Court may, upon consideration of all relevant factors, grant parole to a defendant upon any or all of the conditions set forth in this Code for granting of probation and for like periods as if probation were then imposed.

D. The Court's decision to grant or refuse parole shall be reviewable only for abuse of discretion.

Section 4-3-21. Powers over Parolee.

Once parole is granted, the defendant shall be subject to the same procedures and conditions as if he/she were originally placed on probation and the Court shall have the power to modify or revoke the probation under like rules and circumstances as provided in this Code for defendants on probation.

CHAPTER 4 OFFENSES AND PENALTIES.

Section 4-4-1. Mayhem.

A. A person is guilty of mayhem if he/she unlawfully and purposely or knowingly;

(1) Deprives a human being of a bodily member or disables or renders it useless; or

(2) Cuts out or disables the tongue, puts out an eye, or slits the nose, ear or lip of another.

B. Mayhem is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-2. Terroristic Threats.

A. A person is guilty of terroristic threats if he/she threatens verbally or in writing to commit any offense involving violence with intent to terrorize another or place such other in fear of imminent serious bodily injury or to cause evacuation of a building, place of assembly, or place of public transportation, or otherwise to cause serious public inconvenience, or in reckless disregard of the risk of causing such terror or inconvenience.

B. Terroristic Threats is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-3. Criminal Homicide.

A. A person is guilty of criminal homicide if he/she purposely, knowingly, recklessly or negligently causes the death of another human being.

B. Criminal homicide is a Class A offense, and if the offense is found to have been committed purposely or knowingly, no suspension of sentence, probation or parole shall be granted, and the maximum fine and incarceration shall be imposed.

Section 4-4-4. Vehicular Homicide.

A. A person is guilty of vehicular homicide if, while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage, intoxicating liquor, a controlled substance, or any drug, to a degree which renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle, he/she causes the death of another by operating a motor vehicle in a reckless, negligent, or careless manner.

B. Any chemical test administered on a defendant with his/her consent or after his/her arrest, whether with or against his/her consent, to determine blood alcohol content, shall be admissible in accordance with the rules of evidence.

C. Any presumptions established to determine intoxication based on blood alcohol content shall apply to the proof of intoxication under this Section.

D. For purpose of this Section, a motor vehicle is any self-propelled vehicle and includes, but is not limited to any automobile, truck, van, motorcycle, all-terrain vehicle, tractor or snowmobile.

E. Vehicular homicide is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-5. Causing a Suicide.

A. A person is guilty of causing a suicide if he/she purposely causes a suicide by force, duress, or deception.

B. Causing a suicide is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-6. Aiding or Soliciting a Suicide.

A. A person is guilty of aiding or soliciting a suicide if he/she purposely aids or solicits another to commit suicide.

B. Aiding or soliciting a suicide is a Class A offense, if the defendant's conduct has actually caused or contributed substantially to a suicide or an attempted suicide; otherwise it is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-7. Assault.

A. A person shall be guilty of assault if that person:

(1) Attempts to commit a battery upon the person of another;

(2) Acts unlawfully in a threatening or menacing manner which causes another person to reasonably believe that he/she is in danger of receiving an immediate battery; or

(3) Uses insulting language toward another person attacking his/her honor or reputation.

B. Assault is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-8. Aggravated Assault.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated assault if that person:

(1) Unlawfully assaults or strikes at another person with a deadly weapon;

(2) Commits assault by threatening or menacing another person while wearing a mask, hood, robe, or other covering upon the face, head, or body, or while disguised in any manner, so as to conceal identity; or

(3) Willfully and intentionally assault another with the intent to commit another crime.

B. Aggravated Assault is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-9. Assault Against a Household Member.

A. Assault against a household member consists of:

(1) An attempt to commit a battery against a household member; or

(2) Any unlawful act, threat, or menacing conduct that causes a household member to reasonably believe that they are in danger of receiving an immediate battery.

B. Assault against a household member is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-10. Aggravated Assault Against a Household Member.

A. Aggravated assault against a household member consists of:

(1) Unlawfully assaulting or striking a household member with a deadly weapon; or

(2) Willfully and intentionally assaulting a household member with intent to commit any Class A offense.

B. Aggravated assault against a household member is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-11. Assault Upon a Law Enforcement Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of assault upon a law enforcement officer if that person:

(1) Attempts to commit upon the person of a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties; or

(2) Acts unlawfully in a threatening or menacing manner which causes a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties to reasonably believe that he/she is in danger of receiving an immediate battery.

B. Assault upon a law enforcement officer is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-12. Aggravated Assault On a Law Enforcement Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated assault upon a law enforcement officer if that person:

(1) Unlawfully assaults or strikes at a law enforcement officer with a deadly weapon while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties; or

(2) Commits assault by threatening or menacing a law enforcement officer who is engaged in the lawful discharge of his/her duties by a person wearing a mask, hood, robe, or other covering upon the face, head, or body, or while disguised in an manner, so as to conceal identity; or

(3) Willfully and intentionally assaults a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties with the intent to commit a crime.

B. Aggravated assault upon a law enforcement officer is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-13. Battery.

A. A person shall be guilty of battery if that person:

(1) Willfully strikes another person or otherwise intentionally inflicts bodily injury on another; or

(2) Who shall cause another person to harm themself.

B. Battery is a Class B offense. Upon conviction, at the discretion of the Court, such offender may be required to pay any hospital and/or doctor bills for treatment of injuries; and/or to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-14. Battery Against a Household Member.

A. Battery against a household member consists of the unlawful, intentional touching or application of force to the person of a household member, when done in a rude, insolent, or angry manner.

B. Battery against a household member is a Class B offense. Upon conviction, pursuant to this Section, an offender shall be required to participate in and complete a domestic violence offender treatment program.

Section 4-4-15. Battery On a Law Enforcement Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of battery upon a law enforcement officer if that person:

(1) Willfully strikes the person of a law enforcement officer or otherwise intentionally inflict bodily injury on a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties.

B. Battery upon a law enforcement officer is a Class B offense. Upon conviction thereof, at the discretion of the Court, such offender may be required to pay any hospital and/or doctor bills for treatment of injuries; and/or to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-16. Aggravated Battery.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated battery if that person:

(1) Unlawfully touches or applies force to the person of another with the intent to injure that person causing painful temporary disfigurement or temporary loss or impairment of the functions of any member or organ of the body;

(2) Inflicts great bodily harm on another and does so with a deadly weapon or does so in any manner whereby great bodily harm or death can be inflicted.

B. Aggravated battery is a Class A offense. Upon conviction hereof, at the discretion of the Court, such offender may be required to pay any hospital and/or doctor bills for treatment of injuries; and/or to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-17. Aggravated Battery Against a Household Member.

A. Aggravated battery against a household member consists of the unlawful touching or application of force to the person of a household member with the intent to injure that person or another.

B. Whoever commits aggravated battery against a household member by inflicting an injury to that person that is not likely to cause death or great bodily harm, but causes painful temporary disfigurement or temporary loss or impairment of the functions of any member or organ of the body, is guilty of a Class B offense.

C. Whoever commits aggravated battery against a household member by inflicting great bodily harm or doing so with a deadly weapon or doing so in any manner whereby great bodily harm or death can be inflicted is guilty of a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-18. Aggravated Battery On a Law Enforcement Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated battery upon a law enforcement officer if that person:

(1) Unlawfully touches or applies force to the person of a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties, with the intent to injure that officer causing painful temporary disfigurement or temporary loss or impairment of the functions of any member or organ of the body;

(2) Inflicts great bodily harm upon a law enforcement officer while that officer is in the lawful discharge of his/her duties and does so with a deadly weapon or does so in any many whereby great bodily harm or death can be inflicted.

B. Aggravated battery upon a law enforcement officer is a Class A offense. Upon conviction thereof, at the discretion of the Court, such offender may be required to pay any hospital and/or doctor bills for treatment of injuries; and/or to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-19. Shooting at a Dwelling or Occupied Building: At or From a Motor Vehicle.

A. A person shall be guilty of shooting at a dwelling or occupied building if that person:

(1) Willfully discharges a firearm at a dwelling or occupied building; or

(2) Is shooting at or from a motor vehicle; or

(3) Willfully discharges a firearm at or from a motor vehicle with reckless disregard for the person of another.

B. Shooting at a dwelling or occupied building, at or from a motor vehicle is a Class A offense. This Section shall not apply to a law enforcement officer discharging a firearm in the lawful performance of his/her duties.

Section 4-4-20. Abduction.

A. A person shall be guilty of abduction if that person:

(1) Takes, detains, or entices a child under eighteen (18) years of age, away from the custody of his/her parents or other lawful custodian;

(2) Takes away or detains another person against his/her will.

B. Abduction is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-21. Kidnapping.

A. A person shall be guilty of kidnapping if that person unlawfully takes, restrains, or confines a person, by force or deception, with the intent that the victim:

(1) Be held for ransom;

(2) As a hostage or shield and confined against his/her will; or

(3) Be held to service against the victim's will.

B. Kidnapping is a Class A offense. Upon conviction thereof, at the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution to the victim and/or the victim's family.

Section 4-4-22. False Imprisonment.

A. A person shall be guilty of false imprisonment if that person intentionally confines or restrains another person without his/her consent and with the knowledge that he/she has no lawful authority to do so.

B. False imprisonment is a Class A offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution to the victim and/or the victim's family.

Section 4-4-23. Custodial Interference.

A. A person shall be guilty of custodial interference if such person takes from the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris or causes to be enticed to leave the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, his/her child who is less than eighteen (18) years of age with the intention of holding the child permanently or for a protracted period, knowing that he/she has no legal right to do so.

B. Custodial interference is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-24. Harassment.

A. Harassment consists of knowingly pursuing a pattern of conduct that is intended to annoy, seriously alarm or terrorize another person that serves no lawful purpose. The conduct must be such that it would cause a reasonable person to suffer substantial emotional distress.

B. Harassment is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-25. Stalking.

A. Stalking consists of:

(1) A person knowingly pursuing a pattern of conduct that would cause a reasonable person to feel frightened, intimidated, or threatened; or

(2) The alleged stalker must intend to place another person in reasonable apprehension of death, bodily harm, sexual assault, confinement or restraint; or

(3) The alleged stalker must intend to cause a reasonable person to fear for his/her safety or the safety of a household member;

(4) In furtherance of the stalking, the alleged stalker must commit one or more of the following acts on more than one occasion;

a. Following a person, in a place other than the residence of the alleged stalker;

b. Placing a person under surveillance by remaining present outside that person's school, residence, workplace, or vehicle or any other place frequented by the person, other than the residence of the alleged stalker; or

c. Harassing a person.

B. Stalking is a Class B offense.

C. As used in this Section, "household member" means a spouse, former spouse, family member, including a relative, parent, present or former step-parent, present or former in-law, child or co-parent of a child, or a person with whom the victim has had a continuing personal relationship.

D. In addition to any punishment provided pursuant to the provisions of this Section, the Court shall order a person convicted of stalking to participate in and complete a program of professional counseling at his/her own expense.

Section 4-4-26. Aggravated Stalking.

A. Aggravated stalking consists of stalking perpetrated by a person:

(1) Who knowingly violates a permanent or temporary order of protection issued by a Court, except that mutual violations of such orders may constitute a defense to a charge of aggravated stalking;

(2) In violation of a Court Order setting conditions of release on bond;

(3) When the person is in possession of a deadly weapon; or

(4) When the victim is less than sixteen (16) years of age.

B. Aggravated stalking is a Class A offense. In addition to any punishment provided pursuant to the provisions of this Section, the Court shall order a person convicted of aggravated stalking to participate in and complete a program of professional counseling at his/her own expense.

Section 4-4-27. Disorderly Conduct.

A. A person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct if such person:

(1) Engages in violent, abusive, indecent, profane, boisterous, unreasonably loud or otherwise disorderly conduct which tends to disturb the peace;

(2) Maliciously disturbing, threatening, or in an abrasive rude manner, intentionally touching any dwelling or vehicle occupied by any person;

(3) Appears in public places in an intoxicated condition and does any of the following:

a. Passes out, falls, or is found asleep in a public place or on the property of another without permission; or

b. Bothers, disrupts or otherwise intrudes upon another person or group of persons; or

c. Wanders about without being able to give a reasonable account of his/her destination to a law enforcement officer; or

d. Appears or is found in an area (i.e. Kivas, Plaza, etc. set aside for religious or ceremonial activities which have been traditionally or by Order of the Tribal Council or conducting authorities set aside for use free from alcoholic beverage consumption or the presence of intoxicated persons during the period of such a religious or ceremonial activity.

B. Disorderly conduct is a Class C offense, unless committed under Subsection A (3) d above, then it is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-28. Public Affray.

A. A person shall be guilty of public affray if such person voluntarily or by agreement engages in any fight with another or uses any blows or violence toward another in an angry or quarrelsome manner in any public place, to the disturbance of others.

B. Public affray is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-29. Curfew Violation.

A. A minor under the age of eighteen (18) is guilty of a curfew violation if, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, or unless in attendance at or returning directly home from an organized school, church or tribal function, he/she is away from his/her place of residence in a public place or a private place other than the place where he/she intends to spend the night with the permission of the owner of such place, or is in a vehicle driving about except as allowed above, after the hour of 11:00 p.m. local time.

B. Curfew violation is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-30. Unlawful Assembly.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawful assembly if such person assembles with two (2) or more person and disturbs the peace by using force or violence; or threatens to cause such disturbance using force or violence against the person or property of another and who shall make any overt act to carry out such unlawful purpose

B. Unlawful assembly is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-31. Unlawful Use of a Telephone.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawful use of a telephone if such person with the intent to terrify, intimidate, threaten, harass, annoy, or offend, to telephone another person and:

(1) Uses obscene, lewd, or profane language;

(2) Suggests any lewd, criminal, or sexual overtures;

(3) Threatens to inflict injury or physical harm to the person or property of another;

(4) Attempts to extort money or any other thing of value from such person;

(5) Disturbs by repeated anonymous telephone calls the peace, quiet, or right of privacy of any other person at the place where the telephone call or calls were received;

(6) Maliciously makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with the intent to annoy or disturb another; or

(7) Disrupts the telecommunications of another.

B. Unlawful use of a telephone is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-32. Interference with Members of Staff, Public Officials or the General Public; Trespass; or Damage to Property.

A. A person shall be guilty of interference with members of staff, public official or the general public; trespass; or damage to property if such person shall be in any building or facility or property owned, operated or controlled by the Pueblo, state or federal government, willfully deny to staff, public officials or the general public:

(1) Lawful freedom of movement within the building or facility or the land on which it is situated;

(2) Lawful use of the building or facility or the land on which it is situated;

(3) The right of lawful entry and exit to the building or facility or the land on which it is situated; or

(4) Willfully refuses or fails to leave the said property when requested to do so by a lawful custodian of the building, facility or property if the person is committing, threatens to commit or incites others to commit any act which would disrupt, impair, interfere with or obstruct the lawful mission, processes, procedures, and/or functions of the property, building or facility.

B. Interference with members of staff, public officials, or the general public; trespass; or damage to property is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-33. Unlawful Bomb Scare.

A. A person shall be guilty of an unlawful bomb scare if such person knowingly makes a bomb scare consisting of falsely and maliciously stating to another that a bomb or other explosive has been placed in such a position that property or persons are likely to be injured or destroyed.

B. Unlawful bomb scare is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-34. Public Intoxication.

A. A person shall be guilty of public intoxication if that person is found in any public place while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotics, or any other drug to the degree that he/she may endanger him/herself or other persons or property; or annoy persons in his/her vicinity.

B. Public intoxication is a Class B offense. The Court, in its discretion, shall order habitual offenders to be committed for in-patient treatment for alcohol and/or substance abuse with any available alcoholic or drug abuse treatment program.

Section 4-4-35. Possession of Alcoholic Beverages by a Person Under 21 Years of Age.

A. A person shall be guilty of possession of alcoholic beverages by a person under 21 years of age if that person being under 21 years of age shall:

(1) Possess or consume any beer, wine, ale, whiskey or any alcoholic beverage;

(2) Misrepresents his/her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic beverage; or

(3) Appear in any public or private place while under the influence of an intoxicating beverage to any degree.

B. Possession of alcoholic beverage by a person under 21 years of age is a Class B offense. The Court, may order habitual offenders to be committed for in-patient treatment for alcohol abuse.

Section 4-4-36. Possession of Marijuana.

A. A person shall be guilty of possession of marijuana if that person possesses, plants, cultivates, manufactures, distributes, sells, trades, or gives away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products in an amount exceeding 23 total units, where a unit is equivalent to one gram of dried usable cannabis plant material or 200 milligrams of THC for cannabis-derived products.

B. A person shall be guilty of possession of marijuana if that person distributes, sells, trades, or gives away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products in any amount to a person under eighteen (18) years of age.

C. A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.

D. Possession of Marijuana is a Class B offense. The Court may order habitual offenders to be committed for inpatient treatment for substance abuse with any available substance abuse treatment program.

Section 4-4-37. Possession of a Controlled Substance.

A. A person shall be guilty of possession of a controlled substance if that person intentionally possesses a controlled substance as defined under the Federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 Â§ U.S.C. 801, et seq., unless the substance was obtained pursuant to a valid prescription of a medical practitioner while acting in the course of his or her professional practice.

B. Possession of marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products is governed by Â§4-4-36 of this Criminal Code. A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.

C. Possession of a controlled substance is a Class A offense. The Court may order habitual offenders to be committed for inpatient treatment for substance abuse with any available substance abuse treatment program. Nothing in this section shall be construed as including or applying to peyote or other natural occurring herbs used or possessed for religious purposes by a member of a Native American Church or by any Native American in the practice of his or her religion.

Section 4-4-38. Trafficking a Controlled Substance.

A. A person shall be guilty of trafficking in a controlled substance if that person manufactures, distributes, sells, trades, gives away, or possesses with intent to distribute intent to distribute any controlled substance as defined under the Federal Controlled Substances Act, 21 Â§ U.S.C. 801, et seq., without a valid license.

B. Planting, cultivating, manufacturing, distributing, selling, trading, or giving away marijuana, cannabis concentrates, cannabis extracts, or cannabis-derived products is governed by Â§4-4-36 of this Criminal Code. A person shall not be guilty of possession of marijuana for engaging in activities authorized and in conformity with a medical cannabis program duly enacted by the Pueblo of Picuris.

C. Trafficking in a controlled substance is a Class A offense. Nothing in this section shall be construed as including or applying to peyote or other natural occurring herbs manufactured, distributed, sold, traded, given away, or possessed with intent to distribute for religious purposes by a member of a Native American Church or by any Native American in the practice of his or her religion.

Section 4-4-39. Glue, Aerosol Spray; Abuse or Possession for Abuse.

A. A person shall be guilty of abuse or possession with intent to abuse glue and/or aerosol spray if:

(1) That person intentionally smells, sniffs or inhales the fumes or vapors from a glue, aerosol spray product or other chemical substance for purpose of causing a condition of, or inducing, symptoms of intoxication, elation, dizziness, excitement, irrational behavior, exhilaration, or dulling of the senses, or for the purpose of in any manner changing, distorting, or disturbing the audio, visual or mental process.

B. No person shall intentionally possess glue, aerosol spray product(s), and/or any other chemical substance for the illegal purpose set forth on this Section.

C. Glue, aerosol spray; abuse or possession for abuse is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-40. Damaging Public Property.

A. A person shall be guilty of damaging public property if that person willfully disturbs, defaces, injures, and/or destroys any public real or personal property of the Pueblo, state or federal government.

B. Damaging public property is a Class A offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages.

Section 4-4-41. ; Cruelty to Animals.

A. A person is guilty of cruelty to animals if he/she purposely or knowingly:

(1) Tortures or seriously overworks an animal; or

(2) Fails to provide necessary food, care, or shelter for an animal in his/her custody; or

(3) Abandons an animal in his/her custody; or

(4) Transports or confines an animal in a cruel manner; or

(5) Kills, injures, or administers poison to an animal without legal right to do so; or

(6) Causes one animal to fight with another.

B. It is a defense to prosecution under this Section that the conduct of the actor toward the animal was:

(1) By an accepted veterinary practice; or

(2) Directly related to a bona fide experimentation for scientific research provided that if the animal is to be destroyed, the manner employed will not be unnecessarily cruel unless directly necessary to the veterinary purpose or scientific research involved.

C. Cruelty to animals is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-42. False Alarms.

A. A person is guilty of false alarms if he/she knowingly:

(1) Cause a false fire alarm or alarm of other emergency to be transmitted to or within any organization, official or volunteer, for dealing with emergencies involving danger to life or property; or

(2) Gives false information to any law enforcement officer with purpose to implicate another in an offense; or

(3) Reports to law enforcement authorities an offense or other incident within their concern knowing or believing that it did not occur; or

(4) Pretends to furnish law enforcement authorities with information relating to an offense or incident when he/she knows he/she has no information relating to such an offense or incident; or

(5) Gives a false name or address to a law enforcement officer in the lawful discharge of his/her official duties.

B. False alarms are a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-43. Tampering with Witnesses.

A. A person is guilty of tampering with witnesses if:

(1) Believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, he/she attempts to induce or otherwise cause a person to:

a. Testify or inform falsely; or

b. Withhold any testimony, information, document or thing; or

c. Elude legal process summoning him/her to testify or supply evidence; or

d. Absent him/herself from any proceeding or investigation to which he/she has been legally summoned.

(2) He/she harms another by an unlawful act in retaliation for anything done by another in his/her capacity as a witness or informant; or

(3) He/she solicits, accepts or agrees to accept any benefit in consideration of his/her doing any of the things specified in this Section.

B. Tampering with witnesses is a Class A offense if the actor employs force, deception, threat or offer of a valuable benefit; otherwise, tampering with witnesses is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-44. Tampering with Evidence.

A. A person is guilty of tampering with evidence if, believing that an official proceeding or investigation is pending or about to be instituted, he/she:

(1) Alters, destroys conceals or removes any record, document, or thing with purpose to impair its verity or availability in such proceeding or investigation; or

(2) Makes, presents or uses any record, document, or thing knowing it to be false and with a purpose to mislead a public servant who is or may be engaged in such proceeding or investigation.

B. Tampering with evidence is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-45. Tampering with Public Records.

A. A person is guilty of tampering with public records if he/she:

(1) Knowingly makes a false entry in, or false alteration of, any record, document or thing belonging to or received or kept by, the Tribe or government for information or record, or required by law to be kept by others for information of the Tribe or government; or

(2) Makes, presents or uses any record, document, or thing knowing it to be false, and with purpose that it be taken as a genuine part of information of records referred to in Subsection A(1) above; or

(3) Purposely and unlawfully destroys, conceals, removes or otherwise impairs the verity or availability of any such record, document or thing.

B. Tampering with public records is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-46. Malicious Mischief.

A. A person shall be guilty of malicious mischief if that person maliciously disturbs, defaces, injures, or destroys any tangible or personal property, including, but not limited to domestic animals, or vandalizes any property not belonging to that person.

B. Malicious mischief is a Class B offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages to the victim.

Section 4-4-47. Unauthorized Graffiti on Personal or Real Property.

A. A person shall be guilty of unauthorized graffiti on personal or real property if that person intentionally and maliciously defaces any personal or real property of another with graffiti or other inscribed material inscribed with ink, paint, spray paint, crayon, charcoal or the use of any object without the consent of the owner of such property.

B. Unauthorized graffiti on personal or real property is a Class B offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages to the victim and/or restore the property to its original state.

Section 4-4-48. Desecration of Church, Religious, Cultural, Historic or Sacred Site: or Removal and/or Destruction of Historic Artifacts.

A. A person shall be guilty of desecration of church, religious, cultural, historic, or sacred site; or removal and/or destruction of historic artifacts if that person:

(1) Willfully, maliciously and intentionally defaces a church, religious, cultural, historic, or sacred site or any portion thereof:

(2) Without proper authority removes, excavates, injures, or destroys any historic, prehistoric ruin, cave, monument or any artifact and/or antiquity.

B. Desecration of church, religious, cultural, historic, or sacred site; or removal and/or destruction of historic artifacts is a Class A offense. Upon conviction, the offender may be subject to permanent exclusion from the Pueblo of Picuris.

C. This offense is one which subjects the offender to forfeiture of all property, including vehicles at the time of arrest.

Section 4-4-49. Criminal Trespass.

A. A person shall be guilty of criminal trespass if that person:

(1) Unlawfully enters or remains upon posted private property without possessing written permission from the owner or person in control of the land;

(2) Unlawfully enters or remains upon posted lands of another knowing that such consent to enter or remain is denied or withdrawn by the owner or occupant thereof;

(3) Unlawfully enters upon the lands of another without prior permission and injures, damages, or destroys any part of the realty or its improvements, including buildings, structures, trees, shrubs, or other natural features.

B. Criminal trespass is a Class B offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to pay restitution for damages to the owner.

Section 4-4-50. Maintaining a Public Nuisance.

A. A person shall be guilty of maintaining a public nuisance if that person knowingly;

(1) Acts in such a manner to place another person in fear of their health, safety, comfort; or

(2) Interferes with the exercise and enjoyment of public rights, including the right to use public property.

B. Maintaining a public nuisance is a Class C offense. At the discretion of the Court, such offenders may be required to remove or correct any property posing as a danger to public safety.

Section 4-4-51. Polluting Waters.

A. A person shall be guilty of polluting waters if that person knowingly and unlawfully introduces any object or substance into any body of public water causing it to be offensive or dangerous for human or animal consumption or use.

B. Polluting waters is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-52. Littering.

A. A person shall be guilty of littering if that person knowingly discards refuse:

(1) On public property in any manner other than by placing the refuse in a receptacle provided for the purpose by the responsible governmental authorities, or otherwise in accordance with lawful direction; or

(2) On private property not owned or lawfully occupied or controlled by the person, except with the consent of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof.

B. Littering is a Class B offense. The Court may to the extent permitted by law, as a condition to suspension of any other penalty provided by law, require the offender to pick up and remove from any public place or any private property any litter deposited thereon. The Court may also require restitution for any and all damages caused by debris, from vehicles transporting substances not securely and appropriately covered which litter the environment.

Section 4-4-53. Unlawfully Permitting Livestock Upon Public Highways.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawfully permitting livestock upon public highways if that person, as an owner or custodian of livestock, negligently permits his/her livestock to run at large upon any part of a public highway which is fenced on both sides.

B. Unlawfully permitting livestock upon public highways is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-54. Livestock Offense.

A. A person is guilty of livestock offense if he/she:

(1) Knowingly or recklessly refuses or fails to mark or brand his/her livestock when such is required in the interest of livestock identification or directed by Pueblo or government officials; or

(2) Alters, obliterates, or removes a brand or mark, or misbrands or mismarks livestock with a purpose to deceive another for any reason; or

(3) Knowingly permits his/her livestock to graze or trespass on the property of another or of the Pueblo without permission to do so or in excess of permitted time or amount; or

(4) Knowingly refuses to sell, dispose, or otherwise remove sick or otherwise infectious livestock from common grazing areas or areas where there is a substantial danger of infecting other livestock; or

(5) Knowingly fails to treat or dispose of a sick animal where there is a substantial danger of infecting other animals; or

(6) Fails to dip, inoculate or otherwise treat livestock in the manner which the Tribal Council or its designated representative shall direct; or

(7) Makes a false report of livestock owned; or

(8) Purposely obstructs or interferes with a livestock roundup.

B. Except in cases in which the owner or person having custody of livestock is believed to be in violation of this Section cannot be found after reasonable search, no conviction shall be found for Subsections (1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) set forth above, unless the owner or person having custody of the livestock involved is given forty-eight (48) hours written notice of his/her alleged violation and he/she has not, after such period of notice, remedied the alleged violation.

C. Livestock found to be in violation of this Section may be impounded at the time an arrest is made, and may be impounded without prior notice to the owner if a Court so orders upon receipt of evidence that such animals seriously threaten the property of the Tribe or another or the health of other livestock within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, and that immediate action is necessary to protect such interests from serious harm. A reasonable fee for the care of such animals may be collected prior to their release.

D. Livestock offense is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-55. Larceny.

A. A person shall be guilty of larceny if that person takes or exercises unlawful control over movable property not his/her own, without the permission of the owner. Upon conviction thereof, shall be sentenced as follows:

(1) For property valued fifty dollars ($50) or less, shall be a Class C offense.

(2) For property valued over fifty dollars ($50) but not more than five hundred dollars ($500), shall be a Class B offense; or

(3) For property valued over five hundred dollars ($500), shall be a Class A offense.
