B. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the owner of the stolen property.

Section 4-4-56. Robbery.

A. A person shall be guilty of robbery if that person takes anything of value from the person of another or from the immediate control of another, by use or threatened use of force or violence.

B. Robbery is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-57. Burglary.

A. A person shall be guilty of burglary if that person, without authorization, enters any vehicle, dwelling, or other structure with the intent to commit a crime or theft therein.

B. Burglary is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-58. Breaking and Entering.

A. A person shall be guilty of breaking and entering if that person breaks into any vehicle, dwelling, or other structure by breaking or dismantling any device used to secure such property and enters such property without the permission of the owner, for the purpose to commit a crime.

B. Breaking and entering is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-59. Shoplifting.

A. A person shall be guilty of shoplifting if that person willfully:

(1) Takes possession of any merchandise with the intent of converting it without paying for it;

(2) Conceals any merchandise with the intent of converting it without paying for it;

(3) Alters any label, price tag, or marking upon any merchandise with the intent of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it; or

(4) Transfers any merchandise from the container in or on which it is displayed to any other container with the intent of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it.

B. Shoplifting is a Class C offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the merchant.

Section 4-4-60. Embezzlement.

A. A person shall be guilty of embezzlement if that person fraudulently embezzles or converts for his/her own use, anything of value with which he/she has been entrusted with the intent to deprive the owner thereof.

B. Embezzlement is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution.

Section 4-4-61. Extortion.

A. A person shall be guilty of extortion if that person communicates or transmits any threat to another by any means whatsoever with the intent to wrongfully obtain anything of value or to wrongfully compel the person threatened to do or refrain from doing any act against his/her will.

B. Extortion is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-62. Forgery.

A. A person shall be guilty of forgery if that person falsely makes or alters any signature to, or any part of, any writing purporting to have any legal effect with the intent to injure or defraud another.

B. Forgery is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-63. Fraud.

A. A person shall be guilty of fraud if that person willfully misrepresents or by deceit, or by false interpretation, or by the use of false weights or measures, obtains any money or takes anything of value from another.

B. Fraud is a Class B offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-64. Issuing a Worthless Check.

A. A person shall be guilty of issuing a worthless check if that person issues in exchange for anything of value, with the intent to defraud, any check, draft, or order for payment of money upon any bank or other depository, for the payment of such check, draft, or order in full upon its presentation.

B. Issuing a worthless check is a Class B offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim.

Section 4-4-65. Receiving Stolen Property.

A. A person shall be guilty of receiving stolen property if that person intentionally receives, retains, or disposes of stolen property knowing that it has been stolen or believing that it has been stolen, unless the property is received, retained, or disposed of with the intent to restore it to the owner. The requisite knowledge or belief that property has been stolen is presumed in the case of a dealer who:

(1) Is found in possession or control of property stolen from two or more persons on two (2) separate occasions;

(2) Acquires stolen property for a consideration which the dealer knows is far below the property's reasonable value. A dealer shall be presumed to know the fair market value of the property in which he/she deals; or

(3) Is found in possession or control of items or property stolen within one (1) year prior to the time of the incident charged pursuant to this Section.

B. Receiving stolen property is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-66. Weapons Offense.

A. A person shall be guilty of a weapons offense if:

(1) Being addicted to any narcotic drug, or having been declared mentally incompetent, he/she owns or has in his/her possession or under his/her custody or control a dangerous weapon; or

(2) Being intoxicated or otherwise under the influence of alcoholic beverages or other intoxicating substance, drug, or medicine, he/she has a dangerous weapon in his/her possession or under his/her custody or control; or

(3) He/she carries a loaded firearm in a vehicle on a public road without lawful authority to do so; or

(4) He/she has on his/her person a dangerous weapon with the intent to unlawfully assault another; or

(5) He/she discharges any kind of firearm from a motor vehicle or within a village or posted "no shooting" recreation area without lawful authority to do so; or

(6) He/she discharges a firearm from, upon or across any public highway without lawful authority to do so; or

(7) Being under the age of sixteen (16) years old, he/she possesses a firearm without the consent of his/her parent or guardian.

B. Definition:

(1) "Dangerous weapon" means any item that in the manner of its use or intended use is capable of causing death or serious bodily injury. In determining whether an item, object or thing not commonly known as a dangerous weapon is a dangerous weapon, the character of the instrument, object or thing, the character of the wound produced, and the manner in which the instrument, item or thing was used shall be determinative.

(2) "Firearms" means pistols, revolvers, rifles, shotguns, and any device that is capable of being used as a weapon because it expels a projectile by some means of force.

C. A firearm or other weapon shall be deemed loaded when there is an unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile in the firing position, except in the case of pistols and revolvers, in which case they shall be deemed loaded with the unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile is in a position that the manual operation of any mechanism would cause the unexpended cartridge, shell or projectile to be fired.

D. Weapons offense is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-67. Aggravated Weapons Offense.

A. A person is guilty of aggravated weapons offense if:

(1) He/she carries a dangerous weapon concealed on his/her person; or

(2) He/she threatens to use or exhibits a dangerous weapon in a dangerous and threatening manner, or uses a dangerous weapon in a fight or quarrel; or

(3) He/she possesses a shotgun or rifle having a barrel(s) of less than sixteen (16) inches in length or an altered or modified shotgun or rifle less than twenty-six (26) inches overall length.

B. Aggravated weapons offense is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-68. Unlawful Carrying of a Deadly Weapon.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawful carrying of a deadly weapon if that person carries a concealed loaded firearm or any type of deadly weapon on his/her person or in close proximity thereto, so that the weapon is readily accessible for use.

B. Unlawful carrying of a deadly weapon is a Class B offense. Any person authorized by the Pueblo, State, or Federal Governments to carry a firearm shall be exempt from this section.

Section 4-4-69. Unlawful Carrying of a Firearm in Licensed Liquor Establishment.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawful carrying of a firearm in a licensed liquor establishment if that person carries a loaded or unloaded firearm on any premises licensed by the Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control for the dispensing of alcoholic beverages.

B. Unlawful carrying of a firearm in a licensed liquor establishment is a Class B offense. Exempt from this section are law enforcement officers in the lawful discharge of their duties; the owner or operator of the license premises or their agents, including privately employed security personnel during the performance of their duties; or by a person on the area of licensed premises, primarily utilized for vehicular traffic or parking.

Section 4-4-70. Negligent Use of a Deadly Weapon.

A. A person shall be guilty of negligent use of a deadly weapon if that person:

(1) Discharges a firearm into any building or vehicle so as to knowingly endanger a person or his/her property;

(2) Carrying a firearm while under the influence of an intoxicant or narcotic;

(3) Endangering the safety of another by handling or using a firearm or other deadly weapon in a negligent manner; or

(4) Discharging a firearm within one hundred (100) yards of a dwelling, building or residential area.

B. Negligent use of a deadly weapon is a Class B offense. Exempt from this Section are law enforcement officers in the lawful discharge of their duties.

Section 4-4-71. Unlawful Possession of Switchblades.

A. A person shall be guilty of unlawful possession of a switchblade if that person has possession of any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle of the knife, or any knife having a blade which opens or falls or is ejected into position by the force of gravity or by any outward thrust or movement from the center.

B. Unlawful possession of switchblades is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-72. Libel.

A. A person shall be guilty of libel if that person, with the intent to harm the reputation of another, willfully writes, prints, publishes, sells or circulates any falsehood or malicious statement, knowing the same to be untrue, or which exposes another to hatred, contempt, ridicule degradation or disgrace.

B. Libel is a Class C offense. The Court may require such offenders to make a public retraction of the written falsehood.

Section 4-4-73. Resisting, Evading or Obstructing an Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of resisting, evading, or obstructing an officer if that person:

(1) Knowingly obstructs, resists or opposes any law enforcement officer or any other duly authorized person serving or attempting to serve or execute any process, any rule, order of any Court or any other judicial writ or process;

(2) Intentionally flees, attempts to evade or evading a law enforcement officer when the person committing the act of fleeing, attempting to evade or evasion has knowledge that the officer is attempting to apprehend or arrest him/her;

(3) Willfully refuses to bring a vehicle to a stop when given a visual or audible signal to stop, whether by hand, voice, emergency light, flashing light, siren or other signal by a uniformed officer in an appropriately marked police vehicle; or

(4) Resisting or abusing any Judge or law enforcement officer in the lawful discharge of his/her duties.

B. Resisting, evading or obstructing an officer is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-74. Refusing to Aid an Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of refusing to aid an officer if that person refuses, without sufficient cause, to help a law enforcement officer in the preservation of peace when called upon by such an officer.

B. Refusing to aid an officer is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-75. Concealing Identity.

A. A person shall be guilty of concealing identity if that person conceals his/her true name or identity, or disguises him/herself with the intent to obstruct the due execution of the law or with the intent to intimidate, hinder or interrupt any law enforcement officer or any other person in the legal performance of their duties.

B. Concealing identity is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-76. Harboring or Aiding a Criminal Offender.

A. A person shall be guilty of harboring or aiding a criminal offender if any person, knowingly conceals any criminal offender or gives such offender any other aid with knowledge that a criminal offender has committed a crime, with the intent that the criminal offender escape or avoid arrest, trial, conviction, or punishment.

B. Harboring or aiding a criminal offender is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-77. Escape from Custody.

A. A person shall be guilty of escape from custody if that person, having been placed under lawful arrest, and/or taken into legal custody by a law enforcement officer; or lawfully committed to any detention facility, escapes or attempts to escape from or after escape evades the custody and control of a law enforcement officer or detention facility.

B. Escape from custody is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-78. Impersonating a Law Enforcement Officer or Tribal Officer.

A. A person shall be guilty of impersonating a law enforcement officer or tribal officer if that person:

(1) Without due authority exercises or attempts to exercise the functions of any law enforcement officer or tribal officer; or

(2) Falsely assumes or pretends to be a law enforcement officer with intent to deceive another person.

B. Impersonating a law enforcement officer or tribal officer is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-79. Bringing Contraband into a Place of Confinement.

A. A person shall be guilty of bringing contraband into a place of confinement, if that person, by carrying or transporting any contraband into the premises; or deposits any contraband onto the grounds of a place of confinement. Contraband shall be considered as:

(1) Any deadly weapon, including ammunition, explosive devices and explosive materials; this does not include a weapon carried by a law enforcement officer in the lawful discharge of their duties;

(2) Any alcoholic beverage;

(3) Any controlled substance, as defined in the Controlled Substances Act.

B. Bringing contraband into a place of confinement is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-80. Disobedience to a Lawful Order.

A. A person shall be guilty of disobedience to a lawful order if that person willfully disobeys any command, order, subpoena, or warrant duly issued, made or given by the Court, or an officer of the law.

B. Disobedience to a lawful order is a Class B offense. Such offenders shall be required to comply with any lawful order.

Section 4-4-81. Perjury.

A. A person shall be guilty of perjury if that person makes a false statement under oath or affirmation, material to the issue or matter involved in the course of any judicial, administrative, legislative, or other official proceeding, knowing such statement to be untrue.

B. Perjury is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-82. Refusal to Take an Oath or Affirmation.

A. A person shall be guilty of refusal to take an oath or affirmation if that person refuses, when legally called upon, to give testimony before any Court, administrative proceeding, legislative proceeding or other authority in the Pueblo of Picuris, authorized to administer oaths or affirmations.

B. Refusal to take an oath or affirmation is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-83. Malicious Prosecution.

A. A person shall be guilty of malicious prosecution if that person maliciously procures or attempts to cause a criminal charge to be brought and prosecuted against an innocent person, knowing him/her to be innocent.

B. Malicious prosecution is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-84. Bribery.

A. A person shall be guilty of bribery if that person gives or offers to give, directly or indirectly, anything of value to any tribal officer with the intent to induce or influence the tribal officer to:

(1) Give or render any official opinion, judgment, or decree;

(2) Be more favorable to one party than to the other in any cause, action, suit, election, appointment, matter or thing pending or to be brought before such person.

(3) Procure him/her to vote or withhold his/her vote on any question, matter or proceeding which is then or may thereafter be pending, and which may, by law, come or be brought before him/her in his/her public capacity;

(4) Execute any of the powers vested in him/her;

(5) Perform any public duty otherwise than as required by law, or to delay in or omit to perform any public duty required of him/her by law.

B. Bribery is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-85. Demanding or Receiving a Bribe.

A. A person shall be guilty of demanding or receiving a bribe if that person, being a tribal official, solicits or accepts, directly or indirectly, anything of value with the intent to have his/her decision or action on any question, matter, cause, proceeding, or appointment influenced thereby, and which by law is pending or might be brought before him/her in his/her official capacity.

B. Demanding or receiving a bribe is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-86. Bribery of or Tampering with a Witness.

A. A person shall be guilty of bribery or tampering with a witness if that person:

(1) Gives or offers to give anything of value to any witness, or to any person likely to become a witness in any judicial, administrative, legislative, or other official cause or proceeding pending or about to be brought before, to testify falsely or to abstain from testifying to any fact in any cause or proceeding; or

(2) Intimidates or threatens any witness, or person likely to become a witness in any judicial, administrative, legislative, or other official cause or proceeding pending or about to be brought, for the purpose of preventing such individual from testifying to any fact, to abstain from testifying, or to testify falsely.

B. Bribery or tampering with a witness is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-87. Arson.

A. A person shall be guilty of arson if that person:

(1) Maliciously or willfully starts a fire or causes an explosion with the purpose of destroying or damaging any building, occupied structure, bridge, utility line, fence, sign, or other property of another with the purpose of destroying or damaging such property; or

(2) Maliciously or willfully starts a fire or causes an explosion with the purpose of destroying or damaging his/her own property or the property of another, to collect insurance for such loss.

B. Arson is a Class B offense. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution for damages.

Section 4-4-88. Improper Control of a Fire.

A. A person shall be guilty of improper control of a fire if that person:

(1) By setting a fire or causing or procuring a fire to be set to any flammable vegetation or forest material, growing or being on lands of another person and without permission of the owner thereof and without proper permit issued by the Pueblo of Picuris Forest and Wildland Fire Department;

(2) By allowing fire to escape or spread from the control of the person having charge thereof without using reasonable and proper precaution to prevent such fire from escaping or spreading;

(3) By burning any flammable vegetation or forest material, whether upon his/her own land or that of another person, without using proper and reasonable precaution at all times to prevent the escape of such fire;

(4) By leaving any campfire burning and unattended;

(5) By causing a fire to be started in any flammable vegetation or forest material, growing or being upon the lands of another person, by means of any lighted cigar, cigarette, match or other manner and leaving such fire unexhausted;

B. Improper control of a fire is a Class A offense. The Court may order the offender to pay restitution for damages and forfeit those personal items that were used to start the fire and any other possessions that may be sold to recover costs.

Section 4-4-89. Prostitution.

A. A person shall be guilty of prostitution if that person knowingly engages in or offers to engage in a sexual act for hire. The sexual act means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, masturbation of another, and intercourse or the causing of penetration to any extent and with any object of the genital or anal opening of another person, whether or not there is any emission.

B. Prostitution is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-90. Patronizing Prostitution.

A. A person shall be guilty of patronizing a prostitute if that person knowingly hires or offers to hire a prostitute to engage in a sexual act for hire with that person or another.

B. Patronizing prostitution is a Class C offense.

Section 4-4-91. Indecent Exposure.

A. A person shall be guilty of indecent exposure if that person knowingly and intentionally exposes his/her primary genital area to public view.

B. Indecent exposure is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-92. Incest.

A. A person shall be guilty of incest if that person knowingly intermarries or has sexual intercourse with a person within the following degrees of blood relationship:

(1) Parents and children; including grandparents and grandchildren of every degree;

(2) Brothers and sisters of the half, as well as of the whole blood;

(3) Uncles and nieces/nephews; aunts and nephews/nieces.

B. Incest is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-93. Criminal Sexual Contact.

A. A person shall be guilty of criminal sexual contact if that person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force, without consent to the unclothed intimate parts of another who is at least eighteen (18) years of age and is not a spouse to that person; or causes another person other than that person's spouse, who is at least eighteen (18) years of age to touch his/her intimate parts. For the purpose of this Section, "intimate parts" means the primary genital area, groin, buttocks, anus or breast.

B. Criminal sexual contact is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-94. Aggravated Criminal Sexual Contact.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated criminal sexual contact if that person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force, without consent to the unclothed intimate parts of another who is at least eighteen (18) years of age, and is not a spouse to that person; or causes another person other than that person's spouse, who is at least eighteen (18) years of age to touch his/her intimate parts by:

(1) Using force or coercion resulting in personal injury to the victim; or

(2) Armed with a deadly weapon.

B. Aggravated criminal sexual contact is a Class A offense.

Section 4-4-95. Criminal Sexual Contact of a Minor.

A. A person shall be guilty of criminal sexual contact of a minor if that person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force without consent to the intimate parts of a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age; or causes that minor to touch his/her intimate parts.

B. Criminal sexual contact of a minor is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offenders to be mentally evaluated. Upon conviction, the defendant will be required to register as a convicted sex offender with the State of New Mexico, and may be subject to exclusion from the Pueblo of Picuris. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim for all unreimbursed expense relating to medical and psychological treatment without limitations to time. Those expenses covered by insurance may also be ordered under restitution.

Section 4-4-96. Aggravated Criminal Sexual Contact of a Minor.

A. A person shall be guilty of aggravated criminal sexual contact of a minor if that person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force without consent to the intimate parts of a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age; or causes that minor to touch his/her intimate parts, when:

(1) That person is in a position of authority over the minor and uses that authority to coerce the minor to submit;

(2) That person uses force or coercion resulting in personal injury; or

(3) That person is armed with a deadly weapon.

B. Aggravated criminal sexual contact of a minor is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offenders to be mentally evaluated. Upon conviction, the defendant will be required to register as a convicted sex offender with the State of New Mexico and may be subject to exclusion from the Pueblo of Picuris. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim for all unreimbursed expense relating to medical and psychological treatment without limitations to time. Those expenses covered by insurance may also be ordered under restitution.

Section 4-4-97. Criminal Sexual Penetration.

A. A person shall be guilty of criminal sexual penetration if that person unlawfully and intentionally causes another person to engage in sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal intercourse or the causing of penetration, to any extent and with any object, of the genital or anal openings of another, whether or not there is any emission by:

(1) The use of force or coercion that results in personal injury to the victim;

(2) The use of force or coercion when the perpetrator is aided or abetted by one or more persons;

(3) In the commission of any other crime; or

(4) When the perpetrator is armed with a deadly weapon.

B. Criminal sexual penetration is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offenders to be mentally evaluated. Upon conviction, the defendant will be required to register as a convicted sex offender with the State of New Mexico and may be subject to exclusion from the Pueblo of Picuris. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim for all unreimbursed expense relating to medical and psychological treatment without limitations to time. Those expenses covered by insurance may also be ordered under restitution.

Section 4-4-98. Criminal Sexual Penetration of a Minor

A. A person shall be guilty of criminal sexual penetration of a minor if that person unlawfully and intentionally causes a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, to engage in sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal intercourse or the causing of penetration, to any extent and with any object, of the genital or anal openings of another, whether or not there is any emission by:

(1) The use of force or coercion that results in personal injury to the victim;

(2) The use of force or coercion when the perpetrator is aided or abetted by one or more persons;

(3) In the commission of any other crime; or

(4) When that perpetrator is in a position of authority over the minor and uses that authority to coerce the minor to submit; or

(5) When the perpetrator is armed with a deadly weapon.

B. Criminal sexual penetration of a minor is a Class A offense. The Court may order such offenders to be mentally evaluated. Upon conviction, the defendant will be required to register as a convicted sex offender with the State of New Mexico and may be subject to exclusion from the Pueblo of Picuris. The Court may order such offender to pay restitution to the victim for all unreimbursed expense relating to medical and psychological treatment without limitations to time. Those expenses covered by insurance may also be ordered under restitution.

Section 4-4-99. Failure to Submit to Treatment for a Contagious Disease.

A. A person shall be guilty of failure to submit to treatment for a contagious disease if that person, knowing that he/she is infected with a sexually transmitted disease, including HIV/AIDS, active tuberculosis, or any other contagious disease and who willfully exposes another to the disease, in a place other than a medical facility.

B. The Court, upon finding reasonable cause to believe that the person has any of the diseases, may order the person to be examined. If, upon examination, the person is found to be infected with a contagious disease, the Court may order the person to submit to medical treatment as prescribed by a competent medical authority.

C. Failure to submit to treatment for a contagious disease is a Class B offense. The Court, in its discretion, may suspend such sentence if offender agrees to medical treatment.

Section 4-4-100. Abandonment or Abuse of a Child.

A. A person shall be guilty of abandonment or abuse of a child who has not reached eighteen (18) years of age, if that person as a parent, guardian, or custodian of that child:

(1) Willfully leaves or abandons the child under circumstances whereby the child may or does suffer neglect. For purposes of this Section, "neglect" means that a child is without proper parental care and control of subsistence, education, medical or other care or control necessary for his/her well-being because of the faults or habits of his/her parents, guardian or custodian or their neglect or refusal, when able to do so, to provide for them;

(2) Knowingly or negligently and without justifiable cause, permits or places a child in a situation that may endanger the child's life or health;

(3) Torture, cruelly confine or cruelly punish a child; or

(4) Expose the child to the elements of severe weather.

B. Abandonment or abuse of a child is a Class B offense. The parents/guardians may also be ordered to pay child support and/or reimburse the costs related to transport, shelter care and out of home placement.

Section 4-4-101. Abandonment of a Dependent.

A. A person shall be guilty of abandonment of a dependent if that person, having the ability and means to provide for his/her spouse and minor child's support, and abandoning or failing to provide for the support of such dependent and thereby leaving such spouse or minor child dependent upon public support.

B. Abandonment of a Dependent is a Class B offense. The parents/guardians may also be ordered to pay child support and/or reimburse the costs related to transport, shelter care, and out of home placement.

Section 4-4-102. Contributing to the Delinquency of a Minor.

A. A person shall be guilty of contributing to the delinquency of a minor if that person commits any act or omits the performance of any duty, which act or omission causes or tends to cause or encourage the delinquency of any minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, including, but not limited to, offering such underage minor alcoholic beverages.

B. Contributing to the delinquency of a minor is a Class B offense.

Section 4-4-103. Failure to Send Children to School.

A. A person is guilty of failure to send children to school if, being the parent, guardian or custodian, without good cause, neglects or refuses to send such child to school.

B. Failure to send children to school is a Class B offense. Upon the first conviction, a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1000.00) may be imposed, or the parent of the student may be ordered to perform community service.

C. If violations of the Compulsory School Attendance Law continue, upon the second and subsequent convictions, the parent, guardian or custodian of the student who knowingly allows the student to continue to violate the Compulsory School Attendance Law shall be guilty of a Class A offense and shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1000.00) or imprisonment for a definite term not to exceed three hundred sixty-five days (365) or both.

Section 4-4-104. Obstruction of Reporting or Investigation of Child Abuse or Neglect.

A. A person shall be guilty of obstruction of reporting or investigation of child abuse or neglect if that person knowingly obstructs, prevents, delays, interferes, or intimidates another from reporting child abuse or neglect; or denies access to a law enforcement officer or child protective services social worker in the investigation of a report of child or sexual abuse.

B. Obstruction of reporting or investigation of child abuse or neglect is a Class B offense.

TITLE 5 PUEBLO OF PICURIS TRAFFIC SAFETY CODE

CHAPTER 1 PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS

Section 5-1-1. Name of Code.

This title shall be known and may be cited as the "Pueblo of Picuris Traffic Safety Code" and references in this title to "Code" shall refer to this Code unless another is clearly indicated.

Section 5-1-2. Administration and Enforcement.

The Governor and Tribal Council of the Pueblo of Picuris, authorized tribal officials, and staff shall administer and enforce this title and, may call upon any duly authorized officers to assist in its enforcement.

Section 5-1-3. Jurisdiction and Implied Consent.

A. Any person who operates a motor vehicle on tribal highways shall be deemed to have given his/her consent to be subject to the jurisdiction and laws of the Pueblo of Picuris. The owner, operator or lessee of any motor vehicle may be prosecuted jointly or individually for violations of any provision of this Traffic Safety Code. Whenever there occurs a violation of any parking or other non-moving violation of this Code, proof of the registration number of any motor vehicle therein concerned shall be prima facie evidence that the owner was the operator thereof, except in the case of a leased or rented motor vehicle, such proof shall be prima facie evidence in any action that the lessee was the operator thereof.

B. Where a violation by a non-Indian ["non-Indian" as defined under Section 5-1-5.] has occurred, it would be constituted as an administrative violation and would not be deemed a crime. Any such person may be subject to civil penalties in the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

C. Where certain violations have been committed by an Indian ["Indian" as defined under Section 5-1-5.] under Chapter 7 of this Code, it would be constituted as a criminal offense and shall be subjected to Title 4, Pueblo of Picuris Criminal Code.

Section 5-1-4. Adoption of the New Mexico State Statutes 2011, Chapter 66, Motor Vehicles, Traffic Offenses and Penalties.

The Governor and Tribal Council wish to provide standard uniformity with the traffic laws of this state and the Pueblo of Picuris by applying the New Mexico Motor Vehicle offenses and penalties as may be applicable for proper enforcement of this Code.

Section 5-1-5. Definitions.

"Alcoholic Beverages" means any and all distilled or rectified spirits, potable alcohol, brandy, whiskey, rum, gin, aromatic bitters or any similar alcoholic beverage, including all blended or fermented beverages, dilutions or mixtures or one or more of the foregoing containing more than one-half percent alcohol, but excluding medicinal bitters;

"Abandoned Vehicle" means a vehicle or motor vehicle that has been determined by a law enforcement agency: 1) To have been left unattended on either public or private property for at least thirty (30) days; 2) Not to have been reported stolen; 3) Not to have been claimed by any person asserting ownership; and 4) Not to have been shown by normal record-checking procedures to be owned by any person;

"Authorized Emergency Vehicle" means any fire department vehicle, police vehicle, ambulance and such emergency vehicles of municipal or public utilities or governmental department as are designated or authorized by the director of the New Mexico State Police Division of the Department of Public Safety or local authorities;

"Bicycle" means every device propelled by human power upon which a person may ride, having two tandem wheels, except scooters and similar devices;

"Bodily Injury" means an injury to a person that is not likely to cause death or great bodily harm to the person, but does cause painful temporary disfigurement or temporary loss or impairment of the functions of any member or organ of the person's body;

"Bus" means every motor vehicle designed and used for the transportation of people and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of people for compensation;

"Camping Trailer" means a camping body, mounted on a chassis, or frame with wheels, designed to be drawn by another vehicle and designed to provide temporary living quarters during recreation, camping or travel;

"Cancellation" means that a driver's license is annulled and terminated because of some error or defect or because the licensee is no longer entitled to the license, but cancellation of a license is without prejudice, and application for a new license may be made at any time after cancellation;

"Combination" means any connected assemblage of a motor vehicle and one or more semitrailers, trailers or semitrailers converted to trailers by means of a converter gear;

"Combination Gross Vehicle Weight" means the maximum allowable combined mass of a towing road vehicle, passengers and cargo in the tow vehicle, plus the mass of the trailer and cargo in the trailer;

"Commerce" means the transportation of people, property or merchandise for hire, compensation, profit or in the furtherance of a commercial enterprise in this state or between New Mexico and a place outside New Mexico, including a place outside the United States;

"Commercial Motor Vehicle" means a self-propelled or towed vehicle, other than special mobile equipment, used on public highways in commerce to transport passengers or property when the vehicle: 1) Is operated interstate and has a gross vehicle weight rating or gross combination weight rating, or gross vehicle weight or gross combination weight of four thousand five hundred thirty-six (4,536) kilograms, or ten thousand one (10,001) pounds or more; or is operated only in intrastate commerce and has a gross vehicle weight rating or gross combination weight rating, or gross vehicle weight or gross combination weight, of twenty six thousand one (26,001) or more pounds; 2) Is designed or used to transport more than eight (8) passengers, including the driver, and is used to transport passengers for compensation; 3) Is designed or used to transport sixteen (16) or more passengers, including the driver, and is not used to transport passengers for compensation; or 4) Is used to transport hazardous materials of the type or quantity requiring placarding under rules prescribed by applicable federal, state or Pueblo of Picuris Tribal law;

"Crosswalk" means a marked part of a road where pedestrians have right of way to cross;

"Declared Gross Weight" means the maximum gross vehicle weight or gross combination vehicle weight, at which a vehicle or combination, will be operated during the registration period, as declared by the registration and fee purposes; the vehicle or combination shall have only one declared gross weight for all operating considerations;

"Driver" means any person who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle, including a motorcycle, upon a highway, who is exercising control over steering a vehicle being towed by a motor vehicle or who operates or is in actual physical control of an off- highway motor vehicle;

"Chauffer" means any person who drives a school bus transporting school children or any motor vehicle when used for the transportation of persons or property for compensation;

"Crosswalk" means a marked part of a road where pedestrians have the right of way to cross;

"Driver's License" means a license or a class of license issued by a state or other jurisdiction to an individual that authorized the individual to drive a motor vehicle;

"Evidence of Registration" means any documentation issued by the Department of Motor Vehicles identifying a motor carrier vehicle as being registered with the department or documentation issued by another state pursuant to the terms of a multistate agreement on registration of vehicles to which this state is a party identifying a motor carrier vehicle as being registered with that state; provided that evidence of payment of the weight distance tax and permits obtained under either the Special Fuels Supplier Tax Act [Chapter 7, Article 16A NMSA 1978] or Trip Tax Act [Chapter 7, Article 15 NMSA 1978] are not "evidence of registration;"

"Explosives" means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and that contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, friction, concussion, percussion or detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb;

"Farm Tractor" means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement for drawing plows, mowing machines and other implements of farming;

"Financial Responsibility" means the ability to respond in damages for liability resulting from traffic accidents arising out of the ownership, maintenance or use of a motor vehicle of a type subject to registration under the laws of New Mexico, in amounts not less than specified in the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act [Chapter 66, Article 5 NMSA 1978] or having in effect a motor vehicle insurance policy. "Financial responsibility" includes a motor vehicle insurance policy, a surety bond or evidence of a sufficient cash deposit with the state treasurer;

"First Offender" means a person who for the first time under state or federal law or a municipal ordinance or a tribal law has been found guilty of the charge of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or any other drug that renders the person incapable of safely driving a motor vehicle, regardless of whether the person's sentence was suspended or deferred;

"Flammable Liquid" means any liquid that has a flash point of seventy degrees Fahrenheit (70Â°F) or less, as determined by a Tagliabue or equivalent close-cup test device;

"Fleet" means one or more motor carrier vehicles, either commercial or noncommercial but not mixed, that are operated in this and at least one other jurisdiction;

"Freight Trailer" means any trailer, semitrailer or pole trailer drawn by a truck tractor or road tractor, and any trailer, semitrailer or pole trailer drawn by a truck that has a gross vehicle weight of more than twenty six thousand (26,000) pounds, but "freight trailer" does not include manufactured homes, trailers of less than one-ton carrying capacity used to transport animals or fertilizer trailers of less than three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds empty weight;

"Gross Combination Vehicle Weight" means the maximum allowable combined mass of a towing road vehicle, passengers and cargo in the tow vehicle, plus the mass of the trailer and cargo in the trailer;

"Gross Combination Vehicle Rating" means the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a combination; however, in the absence of a value specified by the manufacturer, the gross combination weight rating shall be determined by adding the gross vehicle weight rating of the power unit and the total weight of the towed unit or units and the load on those units;

"Gross Factory Shipping Weight" means the weight indicated on the manufacturer's certificate of origin;

"Gross Vehicle Weight" means the weight of a loaded vehicle;

"Gross Vehicle Weight Rating" means the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle;

"Hazardous Material" means a substance or material in a quantity and form that may pose an unreasonable risk to health, safety or property when transported in commerce;

"Highway" or "Street" means every way or place generally open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular travel, even though it may be temporarily closed or restricted for the purpose of construction, maintenance, repair or reconstruction;

"Historic or Special Interest Vehicle" means a vehicle of any age that, because of its significance, is being collected, preserved, restored or maintained by a collector as a leisure pursuit;

"Horseless Carriage" means a motor vehicle at least thirty-five (35) years old that is owned as a collector's item and used solely for exhibition and educational purposes;

"House Trailer" means a manufactured home;

"Implement of Husbandry" means every vehicle that is designed for agricultural purposes and exclusively used by the owner in the conduct of agricultural operations;

"Indian" or "Indian Person" shall include any person of Indian descent who is a member of any recognized tribe under federal jurisdiction;

"Intersection" means: 1) The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways that join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict; and 2) Where a highway includes two roadways thirty feet or more apart, every crossing of each roadway of that divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection; in the event that the intersecting highway also includes two roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, every crossing of two roadways of those highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection;

"Lined Roadway" means a roadway that is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic;

"Law Enforcement Agency Designated by the Division" means the law enforcement agency indicated on the dismantler's notification form as the appropriate agency for the receipt of the appropriate copy of that form;

"License", without modification, means any license, temporary instruction permit or temporary license issued or recognized under the laws of New Mexico pertaining to the licensing of persons to operate motor vehicles;

"Lien" or "Encumbrance" means every chattel mortgage, conditional sales contract, lease, purchase lease, sales lease, contract, security interest under the Uniform Commercial Code [Chapter 55 NMSA 1978] or other instrument in writing having the effect of a mortgage or lien or encumbrance upon, or intended to hold, the title to any vehicle in the former owner, possessor or grantor;

"Local Authorities" means every county, municipality and any local board or body having authority to enact laws relating to traffic under the constitution and laws of this state;

"Mail" means any item properly addressed with postage prepaid and delivered by the United States postal service or any other public or private enterprise primarily engaged in the transport and delivery of letters, packages and other parcels;

"Manufactured Home" means a movable or portable housing structure that exceeds either a width of eight (8) feet of a length of forty (40) feet, constructed to be towed on its own chassis and designed to be installed with or without a permanent foundation for human occupancy;

"Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin" means a certification, on a form supplied by or approved by the department, signed by the manufacturer that the new vehicle or boat described in the certificate has been transferred to the New Mexico dealer or distributor named in the certificate or to a dealer duly licensed or recognized as such in another state, territory or possession of the United States and that such transfer is the first transfer of the vehicle or boat in ordinary trade and commerce;

"Moped" means a two-wheeled or three-wheeled vehicle with an automatic transmission and a motor having a piston displacement of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, that is capable of propelling the vehicle at a maximum speed of not more than thirty (30) miles an hour on level ground;

"Motor Carrier" means any person or firm that owns, controls, operates or manages any motor vehicle with gross vehicle weight of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds or more that is used to transport persons or property on the public highways of this state;

"Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, excluding a tractor;

"Motor Home" means a camping body built on a self-propelled motor vehicle chassis so designed that seating for drivers and passengers is within the body itself;

"Motor Vehicle" means every vehicle that is self-propelled and every vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from batteries or from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails; but for the purposes of the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act [66-5-201 NMSA 1978], "motor vehicle' does not include "special mobile equipment;"

"Motor Vehicle Insurance Policy" means a policy of vehicle insurance that covers self- propelled vehicles of a kind required to be registered pursuant to New Mexico law for use on the public and highways. A "motor vehicle policy" shall include: 1) Motor vehicle bodily injury and property damage liability coverages in compliance with the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act; and 2) Uninsured motorist coverage, subject to the provisions of Section 66-5-301 NMSA 1978 permitting the insured to reject such coverage; and 3)Physical damage coverage; 4) Other coverage that the insured and the insurer agree to include within the policy; 5) Medical payments coverage;

"Non-Indian" means any person who is not a member of an Indian Tribe recognized by the United States Government or any State Government;

"Odometer" means a device for recording the total mileage traveled by a vehicle from the vehicle's manufacture and for so long as the vehicle is operable on the highways;

"Off-Highway Motor Vehicle" means any motor vehicle operated or used exclusively off the highways of this state and that is not legally equipped for operation on the highways of this state;

"Official Printout" means any record supplied by the division or a similar agency or government entity that indicates the lien holders of record or owners of record of a vehicle or motor vehicle registered within that government's jurisdiction or indicates information about a driver's license or identification card, including traffic violation history or status;

"Official Traffic-Control Devices" means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with the Motor Vehicle Code placed or erected, by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic;

"Owner" means a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle and may include a conservator, guardian, personal representative, executor or similar fiduciary, or, in the event that a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for conditional sale or lease with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or, in the event that a mortgagor of a vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor;

"Park" or "Parking" means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, other than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading;

"Parking Lot" means a parking area provided for the use of patrons of any office of state or local government or of any public accommodation, retail or commercial establishment;

"Parts Car" means a motor vehicle generally in an inoperable condition that is owned by a collector to furnish parts that are usually not obtainable from normal sources, thus enabling a collector to preserve, restore and maintain a motor vehicle of historic or special interest;

"Pedestrian" means any natural person on foot;

"Personal Information" means information that identifies an individual, including an individual's photograph, social security number, driver identification number, name, address other than zip code, telephone number and medical or disability information, but "personal information" does not include information on vehicles, vehicle ownership, vehicular accidents, driving violations or driver status;

"Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands" shall mean all lands within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris and all other lands owned by the Pueblo of Picuris subject to federal law restrictions on alienation or held by the United States for the use and benefit of the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Placard" or "Parking Placard" means a card-like device that identifies the vehicle as being currently in use to transport a person with severe mobility impairment and issued pursuant to Section 66-3-16 NMSA 1978 to be displayed inside a motor vehicle so as to be readily visible to an observer outside the vehicle;

"Pneumatic Tire" means every tire in which compressed air is designed to support the load;

"Pole Trainer" means any vehicle without motive power, designed to be drawn by another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach or pole or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle and ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads such as poles, structures, pipes and structural members capable, generally, of sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections;

"Police or Peace Officer" means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of the Pueblo of Picuris Traffic Safety Code;

"Preceding Year" means a period of twelve (12) consecutive months fixed by the department, which period is within the sixteen (16) months immediately preceding the commencement of the registration or license year for which proportional registration is sought. The department, in fixing that period, shall make it conform to the terms, conditions and requirements of any applicable agreement or arrangement for the proportional registration of vehicles;

"Private Road or Driveway" means every way or place in private ownership used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not other persons;

"Properly Registered" means bearing the lawfully issued and currently valid evidence of registration of this or another jurisdiction, regardless of the owner's residence, except in the cases where the evidence has been procured by misrepresentation or fraud;

"Property Owner" means the owner of a piece of land or the agent of that property owner;

"Public Highway" means every way or place generally open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular travel, even though it may be temporarily closed or restricted for the purpose of construction, maintenance, repair or reconstruction;

"Reconstructed Vehicle" means any vehicle assembled or constructed largely by means of essential parts, new or used, derived from other vehicles or which, if originally otherwise assembled or constructed, has been materially altered by the removal of essential parts, new or used;

"Recreational Travel Trailer" means a camping body designed to be drawn by another vehicle;

"Registration" means registration certificates and registration plates issued under the laws of New Mexico pertaining to the registration of vehicles;

"Registration Number" means the number assigned upon registration by the division to the owner of a vehicle or motor vehicle required to be registered by the Motor Vehicle Code;

"Registration Plate" means the plate, marker, sticker or tag assigned by the division for the identification of the registered vehicle;

"Registration Sticker" means the tab or sticker issued by the division to signify, upon a registration plate, renewed registration;

"Residence District" means a district where people live, occupied primarily by private residences;

"Revocation" means that the driver's license and privilege to drive a motor vehicle on the public highways are terminated and shall not be renewed or restored, except that an application for a new license may be presented to, and acted upon, by the division after the expiration of at least one year after date of revocation;

"Right of Way" means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway;

"Road Tractor" means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and constructed not to carry a significant load on the road tractor, either independently or as any part of the weight of a vehicle or load drawn;

"Roadway" means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder; when a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" refers to each roadway separately but not to all of the roadways collectively;

"Salvage Vehicle" means a vehicle: 1) Other than a non-repairable vehicle, of a type subject to registration that has been wrecked, destroyed or damaged excluding, pursuant to rules issued by the department, hail damage, to the extent that the owner, leasing company, financial institution or the insurance company that insured or is responsible for repair of the vehicle considers it uneconomical to repair the vehicle and that is subsequently not repaired by, or for, the person who owned the vehicle at the time of the event resulting in damage; 2) That was determined to be uneconomical to repair and for which a total loss payment is made by an insurer, whether or not the vehicle is subsequently repaired, if, prior to or upon making payment to the claimant, the insurer obtained the agreement of the claimant to the amount of the total loss settlement and informed the claimant that, pursuant to rules of the department, the title must be branded and submitted to the department for issuance of a salvage certificate of title for the vehicle;

"School Bus" means a commercial motor vehicle used to transport preprimary, primary or secondary school students from home to school, from school to home or to and from school- sponsored events, but not including a vehicle: 1) Operated by a common carrier, subject to and meeting all requirements of the public regulation commission but not used exclusively for the transportation of students; 2) Operated solely by a government-owned transit authority, if the transit authority meets all safety requirements of the public regulation commission but is not used exclusively for the transportation of students; or 3) Operated as a per capita feeder as defined in Section 22-16-6 NMSA 1978;

"Semitrailer" means a vehicle without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some significant part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle;

"Sidewalk" means a portion of street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians;

"Slide-in Camper" means a camping body designed to be loaded onto and unloaded from the bed of a pickup truck;

"Slow-Moving Vehicle" means a vehicle that is ordinarily moved, operated or driven at a speed less than twenty-five (25) miles per hour;

"Solid Tire" means every tire of rubber or other resilient material that does not depend upon compressed air for the support of the load;

"Special Mobile Equipment" means a vehicle not designed or used primarily for the transportation of persons or property and incidentally operated or moved over the highways, including but not limited to farm tractors, road construction or maintenance machinery, ditch- digging apparatus, well-boring apparatus and concrete mixers;

"State" means a state, territory or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia or any state of the Republic of Mexico or the Federal District of Mexico or a province of the Dominion of Canada;

"State Highway" means a public highway that has been designated as a state highway by the legislature, the state transportation commission or the secretary of transportation;

"Stop" when required, means complete cessation from movement;

"Stop, Stopping or Standing" when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal;

"Street" or "Highway" means a way or place generally open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular travel, even though it may be temporarily closed or restricted for the purpose of construction, maintenance, repair or reconstruction;

"Subsequent Offender" means a person who was previously a first offender and who again, under state law, federal law or a municipal ordinance or a tribal law, has been found guilty of the charge of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or any drug that rendered the person incapable of safely driving a motor vehicle, regardless of whether the person's sentence was suspended or deferred;

"Suspension" means that a person's driver's license and privilege to drive a motor vehicle on the public highways are temporarily withdrawn;

"Tank Vehicle" means a motor vehicle that is designed to transport any liquid or gaseous material within a tank that is either permanently or temporarily attached to the vehicle or the chassis and that has either a gross vehicle weight rating of twenty-six thousand and one (26,001) or more pounds or is used in the transportation of hazardous materials requiring placarding of the vehicle under applicable law;

"Taxicab" means a motor vehicle used for hire in the transportation of persons, having a normal seating capacity of not more than seven (7) persons;

"Through Highway" means every highway or portion of a highway at the entrance to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to stop before entering or crossing it when stop signs are erected as provided in the P.P.T.S.C.;

"Traffic" means the passage of people or vehicles along routes of transportation;

"Traffic-Control Sign" means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed;

"Trailer" means any vehicle without motive power, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle, and so constructed that no significant part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle;

"Transaction" means all operations necessary at one time with respect to one (1) identification card, one (1) driver, one (1) vessel or one (1) vehicle;

"Transporter of Manufactured Homes" means a commercial motor vehicle operation engaged in the business of transporting manufactured homes from the manufacturer's location to the first dealer's location. A "transporter of manufactured homes" may or may not be associated with or affiliated with a particular manufacturer or dealer.

"Travel Trailer" means a trailer with a camping body and included recreational travel trailers and camping trailers;

"Tribal Court" means a Court created by a Tribe or a Court of Indian offense created by the United States Secretary of the Interior;

"Tribe" means an Indian nation, Tribe or Pueblo located wholly or partially in New Mexico;

"Truck" means a motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property;

"Truck Camper" means a camping body designed to be loaded onto, or affixed to, the bed or chassis of a truck. A camping body, when combined with a truck or truck cab and chassis, even though not attached permanently, becomes a part of the motor vehicle, and together they are a recreational unit to be known as a "truck camper"; there are three (3) general types of truck campers: 1) "Slide-in Camper" means a camping body designed to be loaded onto and unloaded from the bed of a pickup truck; 2) "Chassis-Mount Camper" means a camping body designed to be affixed to a truck cab and chassis; 3) "Pickup Cover" or "Camper Shell" means a camping body designed to provide an all-weather protective enclosure over the bed of a pickup truck and to be affixed to the pickup truck.

"Truck Tractor" means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and constructed to carry a part of the weight of the vehicle and load drawn;

"Unclaimed Vehicle or Motor Vehicle" means a vehicle or motor vehicle that has been placed in an impound lot by a law enforcement agency or removed to any storage lot by a property owner, and to which no owner or lien holder of record has asserted a valid claim;

"Utility Trailer" means any trailer, semitrailer or pole trailer, but does not include freight trailers, manufactured homes, trailers of less than one-ton carrying capacity used to transport animals or fertilizer trailers of less than three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds empty weight;

"Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is, or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including any frame, chassis, body or unitized frame and body of any vehicle or motor vehicle, except devices moved exclusively by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks;

"Wholesaler" means any person, except a person making a casual sale of the person's own vehicle who sells or offers for sale vehicles of a type subject to registration in this state, to a vehicle dealer who is licensed under the Motor Vehicle Code or who is franchised by a manufacturer, distributor or vehicle dealer; provided, however, that if any person except a person making a casual sale of the person's own vehicle also sells a vehicle at retail, that person shall be deemed to be a dealer and is subject to the dealer-licensing provisions of the Motor Vehicle Code;

"Written Clearance from a Law Enforcement Agency" means any written statement signed by a law enforcement officer stating that a check has been made of the law enforcement agency's records and the computerized records of the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) and that the check of records indicates that the vehicle or motor vehicle in question has not been reported stolen.

CHAPTER 2 VEHICLE REGISTRATION AND OPERATOR'S LICENSING.

Section 5-2-1/66-5-2. Operators and Chauffeurs Must Be Licensed.

A. No person shall drive any motor vehicle upon a highway on the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, unless he/she has a valid license as an operator or chauffeur under the provisions of this State or Nation (including other Indian Tribes) Motor Vehicle Code.

B. No person shall drive a motor vehicle upon a highway on the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, as a chauffeur unless he/she holds a valid chauffeur's license.

C. All licensed drivers who are authorized to drive a motor vehicle shall be permitted to drive within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, unless their license has been suspended by any State of the United States of America or the Tribal Court.

D. All motorcyclists must have in their possession a driver's license clearly marked "Motorcycle License." Dirt bikes must be kept off the main highway and, all cyclists are required to wear safety helmets while cycle is in motion.

Section 5-2-2/66-5-4. Persons Exempt from License.

Any operator of a farm tractor or agricultural implement temporarily drawn, moved or propelled on the highway within the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, is exempt from possessing a driver's license.

Section 5-2-3/66-5-16. License to be Carried and Exhibited on Demand.

Every licensee shall have his/her operator's or chauffeur's license in his/her immediate possession at all times when operating a motor vehicle and shall display the same upon demand of an officer. However, no person charged with violating this Section shall be convicted if he/she produces in Court an operator's or chauffeur's license issued to him/her at the time of his/her being issued a citation.

Section 5-2-4/66-5-5. Persons Not to be Licensed.

A. No person shall be permitted to operate a vehicle on the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, as an operator, who is under the age of sixteen (16) years, except:

(1) A restricted instruction permit or a restricted license to students fourteen (14) years of age or older, enrolled in a high school driver-education program approved by the State Board of Education;

(2) An operator's permit to any person fifteen (15) years of age or older who has satisfactorily completed an accredited driver-education program.

B. Operator or chauffeur, who is a habitual drunkard, a habitual user of narcotic drugs or a habitual user of any other drug to a degree which renders him/her incapable of safely driving a motor vehicle.

C. Operator or chauffeur, who is three (3) times convicted of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs, regardless of whether the convictions are under the laws or ordinances of any state or any municipality, county or Indian Tribe until restoration of the license. Should the person be subsequently once convicted of either of the same offenses, he/she shall thereafter never be permitted to drive any motor vehicle upon the highways and roads within the Pueblo of Picuris and its boundaries.

D. Operator or chauffeur, who has previously been afflicted with, or suffering from, any mental disability or disease which could render him/her unable to operate a motor vehicle safely upon the highways and who has not, at the time of application, been restored to health.

Section 5-2-5/66-5-37. Unlawful Use of License.

A. It is a violation for any person:

(1) To use any canceled, revoked, suspended, false, or fraudulently altered operator's or chauffeur's license;

(2) To lend his/her operator's or chauffeur's license to any other person or knowingly permit the use by another;

(3) To use any license not issued to him/her;

(4) To fail or refuse to surrender to the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court, upon its lawful demand, any driver's license or permit which has been suspended;

(5) To permit any unlawful use of driver's license or chauffeur's license issued to him/her.

Section 5-2-6/66-5-39. Driving While License Suspended or Revoked.

Any person who drives a motor vehicle on any public road of the Pueblo of Picuris, and its boundaries, at a time when his/her privilege to do so is suspended or revoked shall be guilty of a violation and upon conviction shall be subject to a penalty assessment of not more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars or such other orders of the Court which may include a satisfactory completion of a Driver's Training Course.

Section 5-2-7/66-5-40. Permitting an Unauthorized Minor to Drive.

No person shall cause or knowingly permit a child under his/her care, under the age of eighteen (18) years to drive a motor vehicle upon any highway when such minor is not authorized, or in violation of any of the provisions of this Code.

Section 5-2-8/66-5-41. Permitting an Unauthorized Person to Drive.

No person shall authorize or knowingly permit a motor vehicle owned by him/her or under his/her control to be driven upon any highway by any person who is not licensed to drive.

Section 5-2-9. Authority of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court to Suspend or Revoke License.

A. The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court is hereby authorized to suspend the license of an operator or chauffeur after a hearing and notify the New Mexico Motor Vehicle Department upon a showing of its records or other sufficient evidence that the licensee:

(1) Has committed an offense for which mandatory revocation of license is required upon conviction;

(2) Has been involved as a driver in any accident resulting in the death or personal injury of another or serious property damage;

(3) Has been convicted with such frequency of serious offense against the traffic regulations for traffic laws and a disregard for the safety of other persons on the highways;

(4) Is a habitually reckless or negligent driver of a motor vehicle;

(5) Is incompetent to drive a motor vehicle;

(6) Has permitted an unlawful or fraudulent use of such license;

(7) Fails to appear, after being properly summonsed, to a traffic hearing;

(8) Fails to pay traffic fines.

Section 5-2-10/66-4-3. Refusal to Issue License; Cancellation or Suspension of License or Use of Temporary Permits; Hearings.

A. The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court may suspend a license for violation of the provisions of this Code. The Court shall take the action authorized only after a hearing. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the party concerned as provided. Such notice shall state the proposed action of the Court and the reason for such proposed action.

B. The Court shall prepare rules and regulations for the conduct of such a hearing. At such hearing the technical rules of evidence shall not apply, a party shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to call witnesses on his/her own behalf; and to cross-examine the witnesses of other parties.

C. The Judge shall conduct the hearing for the Court and shall cause a record of hearing to be made.

D. Within ten (10) days after the completion of the hearing, the Judge shall cause to be served upon all parties, in the manner provided in this Code, his/her findings and decision. The decision shall be either:

(1) Suspension of a license for a time stated and notice to the New Mexico Motor Vehicle Department;

(2) Continuing use of a permit, cancellation of use of temporary permits or suspension of use of temporary permits for a time stated, and notice to the New Mexico Motor Vehicle Department.

Section 5-2-11/66-3-13. Evidence of Registration to be Signed and on Demand.

Every owner, upon receipt of registration evidence, shall write his/her signature thereon in the space provided. Every such registration evidence or duplicates validated by the division shall be exhibited upon demand of any police officer.

Section 5-2-12/66-3-18. Display of Registration Plates and Temporary Registration Permits; Displays, Prohibited and Allowed.

A. The registration plate shall be attached to the rear of the vehicle for which it is issued; however, the registration plate shall be attached to the front of a road tractor or truck tractor. The plate shall be securely fastened at all times in a fixed horizontal position at a height of not less than twelve (12) inches from the ground, measuring from the bottom of the plate. It shall be in a place and position so as to be clearly visible, and it shall be maintained free from foreign material and in a condition to be clearly legible.

B. A demonstration or temporary registration permit shall be firmly affixed to the inside left rear window of the vehicle to which it is issued, unless such display presents a safety hazard or the demonstration or temporary registration permit is not visible or readable from that position, in which case, the demonstration or temporary registration permit shall be displayed in such a manner that it is clearly visible from the rear or left side of the vehicle.

C. No vehicle while being operated on the highways of the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, or state, shall have displayed either on the front or the rear of the vehicle any registration plate, including registration sticker, other than one issued or validated for the current registration period by the department or any other licensing authority having jurisdiction over the vehicle. No expired registration plate or registration sticker shall be displayed on the vehicle other than an expired special registration plate which may be exhibited on the front of the vehicle.

D. Nothing contained in this Section shall be construed as prohibiting the use of a promotional or advertising plate on the front of the vehicle.

Section 5-2-13. Improper Use of Evidences of Registration.

No person shall lend to another any certificate of title, registration evidence, registration plate, special plate, or permit issued to him/her if the person desiring to borrow the same would not be entitled to the use thereof, nor shall any person knowingly permit the use of any of the same by one not entitled thereto, nor shall any person display upon a vehicle any registration evidence, registration plate, or permit not issued for such vehicle or not otherwise lawfully used thereon under this Code.

Section 5-2-14. Seizure of Documents and Plates.

The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court is hereby authorized to take possession of any certificate of title, evidence of registration, permit, license or registration plate issued by it upon expiration, revocation, cancellation, or suspension, or which is fictitious, or which has been unlawfully or erroneously issued.

Section 5-2-15/66-5-201. Vehicles Must be Insured or Owner Must Have Evidence of Financial Responsibility; Penalties.

A. No owner shall permit the operation of an uninsured motor vehicle, or a motor vehicle for which evidence of financial responsibility as was affirmed to the department is not currently valid, upon the streets of highways of New Mexico unless the vehicles is specifically exempted from the provisions of the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act [66-5-201 NMSA 1978].

B. No person shall drive an uninsured vehicle, or a motor vehicle for which evidence of financial responsibility as was affirmed to the department is not currently valid, upon the highways of New Mexico unless he/she is specifically exempted from the provisions of the Mandatory Financial Act.

C. For the purposes of the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act, "uninsured motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle for which a motor vehicle insurance policy meeting the requirements of the laws of New Mexico and of the secretary is not in effect or a surety bond or evidence of a sufficient cash deposit with the State Treasurer.

D. The provisions of the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act requiring the deposit of evidence of financial responsibility as provided in Section 66-5-218 NMSA 1978, subject to certain exemptions, may apply with respect to persons who have been convicted of or forfeited bail for certain offenses under motor vehicle laws or who have failed to pay judgments or written settlement agreements upon causes of action arising out of ownership, maintenance or use of vehicles of a type subject to registration under the laws of New Mexico.

E. Any person who violates the provisions of this Section is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be sentenced to a fine not to exceed three hundred ($300) dollars.

CHAPTER 3 TRAFFIC ACCIDENTS.

A. The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury or death of any person or in any property damage shall:

(1) Immediately give notice by the quickest means available to the local emergency center by calling 911, for dispatch of first responders and law enforcement. As soon as possible, the Governor's Office should also be notified. When the driver is physically unable to do so, any passenger in the vehicle at the time of the accident shall give or cause to be given the notice required.

(2) Immediately stop his/her vehicle at the accident, or as close as possible without obstructing traffic more than necessary, and shall return and remain at the scene until he/she has given his/her name, address, vehicle registration number, and upon request shall exhibit his/her driver's license to the other person(s) involved in the accident.

(3) Render aid as may be necessary where personal injuries are involved, and make arrangements for securing such aid as may appear to be needed.

(4) In an accident involving damage to an unattended vehicle, fixtures or property on or adjacent to the roadway, the driver shall stop and take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner of such property for the purpose of giving his/her name, address, vehicle registration number, and upon request exhibiting his/her driver's license, and shall also report such accident as required by this Code.
