In addition to any other punishment provided in the Domestic Violence Code, the Court shall order a person to make appropriate restitution to the party injured by the violation of an Order of Protection and order the person convicted to participate in and complete a program of professional counseling, at his or her own expense.

Section 7-3-10. Time for Filing.

In determining whether to grant an Order of Protection, the Court shall consider whether the petitioner's fear is reasonable and imminent regardless of the lapse of time between the act of domestic violence and the filing of the petition.

Section 7-3-11. Mutual Orders of Protection.

If it is clear to the Court that both parties are at risk of physical injury, the Court shall issue mutual protection orders against both parties.

Section 7-3-12. Continuing Duty to Inform Court; Other Proceedings; Omission of Petitioner's Address.

A. At any hearing in a proceeding to obtain or amend an Order of Protection, each party has a continuing duty to inform the Court of any other civil proceedings whether in civil, family, or juvenile court, and of any criminal case involving either of the parties.

B. An Order of Protection is in addition to other civil or criminal proceedings. A petitioner is not barred from applying for an Order of Protection because of other court proceedings.

C. The Court shall not delay granting relief because of a pending action between the parties.

D. The Court shall not refuse to grant or dismiss an Order of Protection because of the possibility, pendency, or existence of other court proceedings.

E. A petitioner may omit their home address from all court papers, but the Court shall maintain the address under sealed record, not to be accessible without the petitioner's consent.

Section 7-3-13. Full Faith and Credit.

A. An Order of Protection issued pursuant to due process of law by a Court of another jurisdiction, State or Tribal, hereinafter "foreign order", shall be given full faith and credit by this Court and enforced as one issued by this Court.

B. A law enforcement officer may rely upon a copy of any foreign Order of Protection that has been provided to the officer by any source and may also rely upon the statement of any person protected by a foreign order that the order remains in effect. A law enforcement officer acting in good faith shall be immune from civil and criminal liability in any action arising in connection with a Court's finding that the foreign order was no enforceable.

CHAPTER 4 VIOLENCE AGAINST DOMESTIC VIOLANCE ADVOCATES AND VOLUNTEERS.

Section 7-4-1. Purpose.

A. The Pueblo of Picuris recognizes that abusers and/or their families may target Tribal and domestic violence advocates, as well as other who assist victims of domestic violence, for retaliatory violence, intimidation, harassment, and other unlawful acts. Such acts often are committed or attempted as a result of advocacy activities and assistance rendered during the course of advocacy duties or efforts.

B. For the purpose of this Chapter:

(1) "Unlawful acts" means any violation of an Order of Protection, issued against an abuser, that enjoins the abuser and his/her family from committing assault, battery, harassment, intimidation, stalking, malicious mischief, destruction of property, terroristic threats, or any other unlawful act of force or violence, as set forth under the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Code, against any domestic violence advocate;

(2) The abuser's "family" includes parents, grandparents, children, siblings, uncles, aunts, cousins of the first degree, current or former spouses and their parents, grandparents, children, siblings, uncles, aunts, or cousins of the first degree;

(3) "Advocate" is construed to include Tribal employees, volunteers, and employees of private, non-profit agencies, employees and volunteers of any domestic violence shelter or program, or any other person who, in the course of their regular duties, provides services or assistance to victims of domestic violence.

C. This Chapter makes any such retaliation or intimidation unlawful as a matter of Civil Contempt and any findings of liability by the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Code will subject the respondent to the sanctions expressed in this Chapter, as well as any other applicable fines, remedies, or restrictions available under Title 1, Chapter 4 (Contempts), and Title 2 (Rules of Civil Procedures) of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Code.

Section 7-4-2. Implied Consent.

A. Any person who is not a member of the Pueblo of Picuris shall be deemed as having consented to the jurisdiction of the Tribe by doing personally, through an employee, through an agent, or through a subsidiary, any of the following acts within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris:

(1) Transacting any business;

(2) Committing or omitting any act which results in a valid tort action;

(3) Owning, using or possessing any property situated within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris;

(4) Engaging in any employer-employee relationship;

(5) Leasing or permitting of any land or property;

(6) Residing within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris;

(7) Committing any act giving rise to claims for spousal support, separate maintenance, child support, child custody, divorce, or modification of any decree of divorce or separate maintenance proceedings;

(8) Entering any contractual agreement within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris.

B. The Pueblo of Picuris has chosen, through this Section, to exercise its civil authority to provide civil sanctions against those persons, whether members, non-members, or non-Indians, who live within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, or who otherwise come under the Tribe's authority through implied consent, and who use unlawful force or violence in violation of this Chapter.

Section 7-4-3. Penalties.

Any person found liable, or against whom a default judgment has been entered, in any cause of action brought as a result of retaliation or intimidation against any person identified in Section 7-4-1, shall be subject to a minimum of one-thousand ($1,000) dollars in punitive charges, plus such costs, medical fees, compensatory damages, and/or any further relief which the Court may deem just and proper.

Section 7-4-4. Special Court Rules.

A. In addition to the rules of court generally applicable to criminal proceedings, the Court is authorized to take the following actions in a proceeding involving alleged domestic violence offenses:

(1) If the alleged perpetrator pleads guilty, a pre-sentence report may be ordered at the discretion of the Court prior to sentencing;

(2) If it appears to the Court that alcohol and/or drugs contributed in the abuse, a chemical dependency evaluation with a treatment plan may be ordered, at the discretion of the Court, prior to sentencing.

B. Upon a guilty plea or conviction, the perpetrator shall be ordered to participate in an appropriate domestic violence program consisting of at least the following:

(1) The perpetrator shall attend and cooperate in an intake session for evaluation;

(2) The evaluation shall be completed by the domestic violence program no later than ten (10) calendar days after entry of the order requiring evaluation, unless the Court extends that time period;

(3) A copy of the evaluation and recommended treatment plan shall be provided to the Court;

(4) In the discretion of the Court, the perpetrator's participation in treatment sessions based on the domestic violence program's treatment plan may be in lieu of confinement and/or, the execution of any such penalty may be suspended pending completion of the treatment ordered by the Court;

(5) The coordinator, or other service provider, shall submit progress reports to the Court at first contact, after six (6) weeks, upon completion of treatment or whenever problems arise.

C. Willful failure or refusal to comply with the Court Order requiring a perpetrator to attend and cooperate in evaluation and/or to undergo treatment as described in the treatment plan, shall constitute contempt of court. If the Court has suspended execution of any penalty imposed under Section 7-2-12 of this Chapter on the condition that the perpetrator under Court ordered evaluation and/or treatment, the Court may also order execution of any such suspended sentence.

Section 7-4-5. Liability.

No law enforcement officer shall be held criminally or civilly liable for making an arrest authorized by this Code, provided he/she acted in good faith and without malice.

Section 7-4-6. Confidentiality.

The Tribal Court Clerk shall keep statistical data concerning incidents of domestic abuse or neglect and present these reports to the Chief Judge on request, but at least annually.

TITLE 8 EXCLUSION AND REMOVAL CODE

CHAPTER 1 GENERAL PROVISIONS

Section 8-1-1. Statement of Intent and Purpose.

The Pueblo of Picuris, by its Tribal Council, hereby finds and determines that pursuant to the power vested in the Pueblo of Picuris as a sovereign Indian Tribe, the authority of the Pueblo of Picuris under the laws of the United States of America and applicable treaties, it is necessary to provide a means whereby the Pueblo can protect itself, its members, and other persons living on the lands of the Pueblo of Picuris, from people whose presence on the Pueblo lands is harmful to, or threatens harm to, the peace, health, safety, morals and general welfare of the Pueblo and its members. Such action is deemed necessary as a result of the Pueblo's interest in maintaining the aforementioned free from harm, to protect the cultural identity of the Pueblo, and to protect those residents of the Pueblo of Picuris and its exterior boundaries who may be imposed upon, harmed or otherwise disadvantaged. The procedures outlined herein are intended to provide procedural fairness to persons affected by these provisions while at the same time recognizing the need, in appropriate situations, to act immediately to remedy actual or threatened harms.

Section 8-1-2. Persons Subject to Exclusion and Removal.

All persons whether or not members of the Pueblo of Picuris or who are not authorized by federal law to be present on the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, may be excluded or removed from all or any portion of the Pueblo of Picuris. These lands include those presently or which may hereafter be added thereto within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, and all lands owned by the Pueblo subject to federal law restrictions on alienation or held, in trust, by the United States for the use and benefit of the Pueblo.

Section 8-1-3. Grounds for Exclusion and Removal.

A person is subject to exclusion and removal as provided herein, may be excluded and/or removed from the boundaries of the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris as defined in this Tribal Code, upon any one or more of the following grounds:

A. Hunting, fishing or trapping on the Pueblo of Picuris, to include the exterior boundaries, without authority from the Pueblo or contrary to the rules and regulations of the Tribe governing such activities;

B. Trading or conducting business within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris in violation of Tribal regulations;

C. Prospecting within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris without authority of the Pueblo;

D. Mining, cutting timber, grazing or other use, abuse or damage to Tribal property without authority from the Pueblo;

E. Exploring for, or excavating items, sites, or locations of historic, religious or scientific significance without authority from the Pueblo, or in violation of federal laws or regulations;

F. Being in or traveling upon the Pueblo of Picuris while afflicted with a communicable or contagious disease;

G. Committing frauds, confidence games, or usury against Indian people residing within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, or inducing them to enter into grossly unfavorable contracts of any kind;

H. Repeated commission of criminal offenses;

I. Interfering with or photographing Pueblo of Picuris ceremonies or religious shrines without permission from the persons involved or the Pueblo;

J. Repeated invasion of the privacy of the residents within the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris;

K. Interfering with the official, political, governmental business or religious affairs of the Pueblo;

L. Doing, or threatening to do, any act upon the Pueblo of Picuris which seriously threatens the peace, health, safety, morals and general welfare of the Pueblo, its members or other persons living within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris;

M. Any other objectionable behavior or condition found by the Tribal Court to be sufficient cause of exclusion; provided, that the person has been first advised of the objection and nevertheless continues the misconduct or condition.

Section 8-1-4. Proceedings for Exclusion and Removal.

Upon complaint of any member of the Pueblo, the Tribal Court may determine whether a person has committed any of the aforementioned acts constituting grounds for exclusion and removal and whether or not the removal and/or exclusion of such person is to be ordered. Such proceedings shall be conducted as provided herein below. An Order of Exclusion and/or Removal may be entered by the Tribal Court.

Section 8-1-5. Emergency Exclusion and Removal Without Prior Hearing.

A. Whenever the Tribal Court finds that there is an immediate need to order the exclusion and/or removal of a person from the Pueblo of Picuris, and its boundaries, and that the granting of notice and opportunity to be heard to such persons prior to making such order would cause a delay seriously detrimental to the interests of the Pueblo or its members, the Tribal Court shall immediately order such exclusion and/or removal and provide the notice and opportunity for review of such decision as outlined below.

B. Whenever the exclusion and/or removal is ordered without a prior hearing as provided herein, the person shall be served with a notice of such action. Such notice shall state the nature and extent of the exclusion and/or removal so ordered, shall state the reasons why no prior hearing was held, shall inform the person that once he/she has complied with the order, he/she may immediately petition the Tribal Court for a hearing to reconsider the order, that he/she may be represented by counsel at such hearing and present evidence in his/her own defense, and shall inform him/her that his/her compliance with such order may be enforced by BIA law enforcement officers. A copy of the order shall be served with the notice and such service may be accomplished by personal service or, if personal service is not reasonably possible, by mailing to the person by United States registered mail, return receipt requested, at his/her last known address.

C. Upon receipt of a petition for a hearing as provided above, the Tribal Court shall schedule a hearing to allow the person to present evidence. Such hearing shall be held within two (2) weeks of the receipt of the petition, provided however, that the Order of Exclusion and/or Removal shall remain in force pending the hearing and a decision thereon, except for the purposes of attending a hearing.

D. The Tribal Court shall, as a result of such hearing, either affirm, modify or rescind its previous order. If a decision is not made during the hearing the Court shall give the person notice of such decision in the same manner as provided for service of the notice above.

Section 8-1-6. Hearing on Exclusion and/or Removal in Non-Emergency Situations.

A. In all other cases of exclusion and/or removal, the Court Clerk shall cause to be served a copy of the petition and a Notice of Hearing upon the person involved either by personal service, or if such service is not reasonably possible, by mailing to the person by United States registered mail, return receipt requested to the last known address of such person. Such notice shall contain the date and time of the hearing, which shall not be less than three (3) days from the date of service, and shall further inform him/her that he/she may appear, with counsel if he/she desires, and present evidence in his/her own defense.

B. The hearing on a proposed exclusion and/or removal may be held at a regular session of the Tribal Court.

C. The Tribal Court shall hear the evidence presented and shall, if appropriate, order the exclusion and/or removal of the person. If the person is not present at such hearing, or if a decision thereon is not rendered until after the hearing, appropriate notice shall be served on the person in the manner provided in Section 8-1-6A, informing him/her of the action of the Tribal Court and such notice shall include a copy of any Order of Exclusion and/or Removal, which affects such person.

Section 8-1-7. Review of Orders of Exclusion and/or Removal.

A. The Southwest Intertribal Court of Appeals (SWITCA) shall have exclusive authority to hear appeals from Orders of Exclusion and/or Removal after a hearing has been held thereon before the Tribal Court.

B. SWITCA shall have authority to stay an Order of Exclusion and/or Removal upon such conditions of security as it deems just only if all prior hearing remedies have been exhausted and only if no substantial interest of the Pueblo, its members, or other residents of the Pueblo of Picuris will be harmed thereby.

C. All Orders of Exclusion and/or Removal shall remain in full force and effect during periods of hearing(s) or review unless stayed as provided herein.

Section 8-1-8. Enforcement of Orders of Exclusion and/or Removal.

All law enforcement officers of the Bureau of Indian Affairs are hereby empowered to carry into effect any exclusion and/or removal order of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court according to the terms of such order.

TITLE 9 PUEBLO OF PICURIS GAME AND FISH CODE

CHAPTER 1 GENERAL PROVISIONS

Section 9-1-1. Statement of Policy.

A. The Tribal Council of the Pueblo of Picuris asserts its civil and political authority as a tribal government to control the resources and property within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris and hereby enacts this Code regulating the fishing, hunting and trapping within the Pueblo of Picuris. The Council further asserts that the power to regulate the harvesting of its natural resources within the boundaries of the Pueblo has never been extinguished by agreements with the United States Government or any other government, and that, as a result, in addition to the aboriginal right to govern itself through its own traditional methods and customs, the Pueblo of Picuris possesses the power to regulate the taking of fish and game animals from within the boundaries of the Pueblo. It is the intent and purpose of this Game and Fish Code to:

(1) Provide an orderly system for the control and regulation of hunting and fishing on the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands;

(2) Provide a means to promote the conservation and management of wildlife resources on the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands;

(3) Provide a means to control and regulate outdoor recreational activities on the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands.

B. All matters relating to the conservation, regulation, control and management of the wildlife resources of the Pueblo of Picuris are subject to the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris.

C. It is recognized that members of the Pueblo of Picuris have a preferred right, interest in and to the wildlife resources of the Pueblo and that the Pueblo has a legitimate right to establish differing rules and standards to govern the actions of members and non-members of the Pueblo on the subject of wildlife regulation.

D. The Tribal Council shall have the authority to adopt annual proclamations or other regulations for the implementation of the policies of this Game and Fish Code and to alter or amend such proclamations and regulations as conditions indicate.

E. All wildlife now or hereafter found within the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands, not held by private ownership lawfully acquired, are hereby declared to be the property of the Pueblo of Picuris, and no right, title, interest or property therein can be acquired or transferred or possession thereof had or maintained except as expressly provided herein.

Section 9-1-2. Definitions.

"All terrain vehicles" means any motorized vehicle designed for, or capable of travel over unimproved terrain;

"Aquatic wildlife" means any species of fish, crustaceans, aquatic insects, or amphibians;

"Bag limit" means the maximum number of game animals which may be lawfully taken by an individual in a given period;

"Big game animals" means all species of deer, elk, bighorn sheep, American pronghorn, bear, and mountain lion;

"Carcass" means the body of, or parts of a dead animal;

"Certificate of registration" means a document granting authority to engage in activities not covered by a license, permit or tag issued under this Code or by proclamation of the Tribal Council;

"Chumming" means the introduction of bait usually consisting of parts of fish into the water to attract fish;

"Closed season" means that period of time during which the taking of wildlife is prohibited; "Code" means the Pueblo of Picuris Game and Fish Code;

"Department" means the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department;

"Director" means the Director of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department;

"Firearm" means pistols, revolvers, rifles, shotguns and any other device from which a projectile is expelled with the use of gunpowder;

"Fishing" means any method of taking fish from the waters. The Pueblo of Picuris may determine the proper method or methods for taking of fish from the waters of the Pueblo, and may regulate the taking of fish from waters within its boundaries no matter what type of method is used;

"Game fish" means all species of trout, perch and pike; "Hunting" means the activity or sport of pursuing game;

"License" means the primary document granting authority to engage in activities covered by this Code;

"Non-Tribal member" means all persons who are not enrolled members of the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Officer" means an officer of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department or BIA law enforcement;

"Open season" means that period of time during which the taking of wildlife by legal means is permitted;

"Permit" means a secondary document, requiring a license as a prerequisite to its issuance, which grants authority to engage in certain specified activities under this Code or by proclamation of the Tribal Council;

"Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands" means any land within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris and any waters within the boundaries shall be considered "Indian Land". The term "Indian Land" includes the Pueblo of Picuris and the exterior boundaries as well as any land purchased by, leased by, or otherwise subject to the control of the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Possession limit" means the maximum number of fish or wildlife which may be possessed by an individual at any one time;

"Proclamation" includes the rules and regulations of the Tribal Council adopted and published under the provisions of this Code;

"Protected species" shall include such species as the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department shall declare and designate, unless altered by regulation or proclamation;

"Pueblo" means the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Ranger" shall mean an officer of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department;

"Recreational Vehicle" means a motor vehicle or trailer equipped with living space and amenities found in a home;

"Sell" means offer or possess for sale, barter, exchange or trade, or the act of selling, bartering, exchanging or trading;

"Small game animals" means all species of rabbits, squirrels, bobcats, coyotes, and foxes;

"Tag" means a card, label or other identification device issued for attachment to the carcass of any wildlife prior to transport;

"Take" means to fish, angle, hunt, pursue, catch, capture, trap, kill or possess any wildlife or fish or any attempt to commit any of these acts;

"Tribal member" or "member of the Tribe" means any enrolled member of the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Tribe" means the Pueblo of Picuris;

"Wildlife" means any form of animal life generally living wild in a state of nature, including all wild mammals, birds, fish, reptiles, and amphibians and their nests, eggs and spawn.

CHAPTER 2 THE PUEBLO OF PICURIS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT.

Section 9-2-1. Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department.

A. The primary responsibility for enforcing the provisions of this Game and Fish Code shall be on the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department.

B. The administrative organization of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department shall be established and approved by the Tribal Council, and the Director of the Department shall report to and be accountable to the Governor and Tribal Council.

Section 9-2-2. Rangers of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department.

A. Rangers of the Department shall meet such requirements as to physical characteristics and training as shall be established by the Tribal Council or the Director.

B. The Director may appoint temporary rangers to aid the Department in times of unusual need.

C. Rangers of the Department shall have the power to issue citations for violations of this Code and to otherwise enforce the provisions of this Code and any proclamations or regulations issued hereunder.

D. Rangers of the Department shall have the authority to confiscate any fishing equipment, rifles, guns or other fishing or hunting equipment or paraphernalia as reasonably appears to have been involved in the commission of the violation for which the citation was made and shall give the person from whom such items are taken an itemized receipt for all such confiscated items.

E. The Tribal Court, when hearing the case concerning the alleged violation, may in addition to any other penalty imposed upon a finding of guilty, order the forfeiture to the Department of all or part of the confiscated items.

CHAPTER 3 PROCLAMATIONS AND REGULATIONS

Section 9-3-1. Proclamations.

A. Annually or at such other specified periods as the Tribal Council shall direct, the Tribal Council shall adopt a Game and Fish Proclamation.

B. The Director of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department shall purpose a proclamation to the Tribal Council which, when adopted by the Tribal Council, either with or without amendments, shall have the force of law on the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands.

C. The Proclamation shall include the following:

(1) Fix seasons, shorten, extend or closed seasons on any species of wildlife in any specific locality or localities, or within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris. When it shall find, after investigation, that such action is necessary either to assure maintenance of an adequate supply thereof, to regulate taking, or to effectuate proper wildlife management and control;

(2) Close or open ponds, rivers, streams, refuges, specified localities or parts thereof, to angling, trapping or hunting and to regulate and prescribe the means by which wildlife may be taken as in its judgment may be best to perpetuate, restore, increase or control any species of wildlife and assure an adequate supply thereof, to regulate the transportation and storage of all wildlife or parts thereof within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris and the shipment or transportation off the Pueblo of Picuris Indian Lands;

(3) Establish or change bag limits and possession limits;

(4) Establish and change territorial limits for the taking of all species of wildlife;

(5) Prescribe the manner and the means of taking or transporting of any species of wildlife to include, but not limited to, the prescribing of type or kinds of bait, lures, tackle, equipment, traps, firearms and weapons, tagging of game or fish or parts thereof, or any other means or device for taking such wildlife;

(6) Designate areas for hunting with bow and arrow or other specified weapons and the season therefore;

(7) Establish refuges or sanctuaries for game, game birds, fish or fur-bearing animals. When private property is to be included within a refuge, written consent of the owner must first be obtained. All boundary lines shall be posted at the usual place of ingress with signs bearing the title of the Department;

(8) Establish methods for checking hunters, fishermen or trappers into and out of designated areas. Prescribe safety and fire control measures and other regulations as may be deemed necessary in the interest of range, game, fish or fur-bearing animal management, and the safety and welfare of hunters, trappers, fishermen, land-owners and the Pueblo of Picuris;

(9) Establish fees for licenses, permits, tags and special hunting seasons;

(10) Establish rules and regulations governing the operation of all-terrain and recreational vehicles within the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-3-2. Publication of Proclamation.

The Proclamation adopted by the Tribal Council shall, before its effective date, be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation on the Pueblo of Picuris and shall be posted in at least three (3) public places within the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-3-3. Additional Regulation.

The Tribal Council may adopt additional regulations of either temporary or permanent application governing the dates, places, means, or manners of taking wildlife or any limitations thereon and such regulations shall, when published in the manner provided for proclamations, have the force of law within the Pueblo of Picuris and its boundaries.

CHAPTER 4 FISHING

Section 9-4-1. Jurisdiction.

All persons, including members of the Pueblo of Picuris, are required to have in their possession a valid Pueblo of Picuris tribal permit or fishing license while fishing the waters of the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-4-2. Manner of Taking Fish.

A. Any person having a license or permit to take fish from the Pueblo of Picuris shall use only one rod or line per license or permit. Any licensee or permittee may have more than one line or rod in possession, but is restricted to the use of two (2) or more hooks or two (2) or more sets of hooks, lures or bait per line or rod.

B. No person fishing on the Pueblo of Picuris may use any type or species of live fish to take fish, or any electric or shocking device to stun or kill fish nor any explosive device or poison in the waters on the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-4-3. Areas Open to Fishing.

A. Persons having a license or permit to fish on the Pueblo of Picuris are permitted to fish at the pond created and maintained for the purpose of fishing. The Pueblo of Picuris also permits fishing, for tribal members only, along designated portions of streams within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris.

B. The Pueblo of Picuris, at any time, may restrict fishing within the Pueblo of Picuris by giving notice of the closing of certain waters.

C. All other lands of the Pueblo of Picuris not designated as open to reasonable travel, whether posted or not, are not available for general use by persons holding licenses or permits.

Section 9-4-4. Limits.

A. Any person having a license or permit shall be permitted to take no more than eight (8) fish per day. No fish may be returned to the water after being brought to land, and all fish brought to land shall be considered as part of the limit.

B. Any person possessing one-day licenses for successive days or a season license may not have more than the daily limit in possession.

Section 9-4-5. Chumming.

No chumming may be allowed in the waters on the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-4-6. Fishing Hours.

Persons holding Pueblo of Picuris licenses or permits may take fish on designated waters by any permissible means from sun-up to sun-down or as posted by the Department.

Section 9-4-7. Access to Fishing Areas.

Persons holding Pueblo of Picuris licenses or permits to take fish must park only in designated areas and no driving off designated roads will be allowed.

Section 9-4-8. Littering.

In order to maintain a pleasant environment in which to fish and to keep foreign substances from polluting the fishing areas, persons holding Pueblo of Picuris licenses or permits, and any persons accompanying or in in the company of a licensee or permittee shall not litter on the Pueblo of Picuris. All material brought on Pueblo of Picuris land must be removed, consumed, or placed in appropriately marked containers.

Section 9-4-9. License Fees.

All persons not specifically exempted from the requirement of holding a Pueblo license or permit shall have in possession a valid license issued by the Pueblo in order to take fish on Indian Land. Schedule of license or permit fees shall be set by the Department and may be subject to change without notice.

Section 9-4-10. Civil Damage.

A. Any person violating the provision of this Code shall be liable for damges in the Tribal Court of the Pueblo of Picuris.

(1) No License.

A person found fishing or taking fish without valid Pueblo of Picuris license in possession shall be determined to have committed trespass against the Pueblo.

(2) Closed Waters.

Any person required to have a valid Pueblo license in possession while fishing shall be determined to have committed trespass against the Pueblo if found fishing in closed waters.

(3) Exceeding the Limit.

Any person found with more fish in possession than this ordinance permits shall be deemed to have destroyed the private property of the Pueblo and shall be liable to the Pueblo in damages at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per fish or as set by the Department.

(4) Littering.

Any person found littering shall be deemed to have destroyed the private property of the Pueblo and shall be liable to the Pueblo in damages.

(5) Cleaning Fish and Waste.

A. Any person cleaning fish in or within thirty (30) feet of any pond or stream, and not within a fish cleaning area, shall be deemed to have destroyed the private property of the Pueblo or alternatively to have cause a nuisance and shall be liable to the Pueblo in damages.

B. No fish may be wasted, discarded, or thrown away.

(6) Bait and Rod Line Limitations.

Any person who shall use bait or hooks which are not allowed by this Code, or who shall use more than one rod or line contrary to the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed to have destroyed the private property of the Pueblo and shall be liable for damages.

CHAPTER 5 HUNTING AND TRAPPING

Section 9-5-1. Enrolled Members.

Enrolled members of the Pueblo of Picuris may hunt within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris provided they are in possession of a valid hunting license issued by the Tribe. Enrolled members of the Pueblo of Picuris may operate trap lines within the boundaries of the Pueblo, provided they are in possession of a valid trapping license issued by the Tribe.

Section 9-5-2. Non-Members of the Pueblo of Picuris.

Non-members of the Pueblo of Picuris may not hunt nor possess firearms within the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris unless licensed to do so by the Governor. Non-members of the Pueblo of Picuris may not operate trap lines on the Pueblo, except by special permission of the Governor.

Section 9-5-3. Seasons, Bag Limits, Etc.

The Governor and Tribal Council shall, from time to time, determine fishing, hunting and trapping seasons, as well as bag limits, areas and species of hunts and any other conditions relating thereto.

Section 9-5-4. Sale of Wild Game Prohibited.

Wild game is not a commercial commodity and the sale of game meat is prohibited. Game meat should not be left to spoil but should be shared with other members of the Pueblo of Picuris by notifying them of the place of its availability.

Section 9-5-5. Trap Lines.

Trap lines must be run or inspected regularly to insure there is no spoilage of game and/or pelts.

Section 9-5-6. Tagged Birds or Animals.

Each hunter shall report all tagged birds and animals to the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department, which will transmit the information to the proper agencies.

Section 9-5-7. Reporting of Birds and Animals Taken.

All wild game birds or animals killed or trapped must be reported to the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department for informational purposes for the protection and conservation of game on the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-5-8. Manner of Hunting Prohibited.

No person shall shoot at, kill or pursue any game animal from an automobile or other self- propelled vehicle, or shoot at, or kill any game animals with the aid of any light or lights attached to such vehicle or by means of any other artificial light.

CHAPTER 6 CAMPING, HIKING AND PICNICKING

Section 9-6-1. Privileges Available Only to Tribal Members.

Camping, hiking, and picnicking privileges are for Pueblo of Picuris tribal members only and only on sites as designated by the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 9-6-2. Disposition of Litter.

No person while camping, hiking or picnicking within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris shall dump trash or leave litter except in proper receptacles.

Section 9-6-3. Control of Fires.

Any person while camping, hiking or picnicking within the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, must ensure that any campfires set are not left unattended and are completely out prior to departure. Fires shall only be set in areas designated by the Pueblo of Picuris.

CHAPTER 7 NOTICE TO PUBLIC

Section 9-7-1. Notice of this Code and Rules and Regulations of the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department.

Every person engaged in hunting, fishing or trapping, or any other activity covered by this Code, shall be deemed to have knowledge of this Code and any implementing rules and regulations adopted by the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department. All rules and regulations adopted by the department shall be printed and posted within the Pueblo of Picuris and copies delivered to State and local officials, local newspapers and to persons who are required to apply for permits from the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department to engage in such pursuits on the Pueblo of Picuris.

CHAPTER 8 VIOLATIONS OF THIS CODE

Section 9-8-1. Violations of this Code or any Rules and Regulations Promulgated by the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department.

The procedures for violations of this Code or any approved Rules and Regulations promulgated by the Pueblo of Picuris Parks and Wildlife Department are set forth in this Code shall be pursued through an administrative hearing. Unless otherwise provided in this Code, violators of the provisions hereof, upon preponderance of evidence, may be subject to a penalty assessment by the Court not to exceed five ($500.00) hundred dollars, and/or forfeiture of fishing, hunting or trapping equipment or such other orders of the Court, with costs, and may be subject to the exclusion and/or removal provisions of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Code.

TITLE 10 PUEBLO OF PICURIS CHILDREN'S CODE

CHAPTER 1 GENERAL PROVISIONS

Section 10-1-1. Title.

This title shall be known and may be cited as the "Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code" and references in this title to "Code" shall refer to this Code unless another is clearly indicated.

Section 10-1-2. Purpose, Meaning and Severability.

A. It is the purpose of this Children's Code to:

(1) Recognize that the children of the Pueblo of Picuris are its most important resource and their welfare is of paramount importance;

(2) Safeguard, protect, and secure for each child coming under the scope of this Code, the care and guidance, preferably in the child's own home or community, as will serve the emotional, mental and physical welfare of the child and the best interest of the Tribe;

(3) Preserve and strengthen family ties whenever possible; to preserve and strengthen the child's cultural and ethnic identity;

(4) Secure for any child(ren) removed from his/her home the care, guidance and control to help him/her develop into responsible, well-adjusted adults; and

(5) Protect the peace and security of the community and its individual residents.

B. The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code shall be liberally interpreted and construed to fulfill the purpose of this Code.

C. If any Section of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code is found to be invalid, the remainder of this Code shall not be affected thereby.

Section 10-1-3. Definitions.

"Abandon" means when a parent or extended family leaves a child without adequate communication or fails to support a child and there is no indication of the parent(s) or extended family's willingness to assume the parental role(s) consistently for a period of no less than six (6) months.

"Abuse" includes physical, emotional, psychological and sexual abuse and are defined as follows.

a. "Physical abuse" includes placing a minor knowingly, intentionally, or negligently in a situation that may endanger his/her life or health; knowingly or intentionally torturing, beating, cruelly confining or punishing a minor;

b. "Emotional abuse" includes systematic patterns of belittling, scapegoating, or other non-physical forms of openly hostile or rejecting actions, as well as excessive non- physical discipline and verbal threats or other forms of maltreatment such as abandonment, beating and sexual assault;

c. "Sexual abuse" means criminal sexual penetration, incest, criminal sexual contact and non-contact sexual exploitation which are defined as follows:

1. "Criminal sexual contact of a minor" is when a person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force to the intimate parts of a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, or causes that minor to touch his/her intimate parts;

2. "Criminal sexual penetration of a minor" is when a person unlawfully and intentionally causes a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, to engage in sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal intercourse or causes penetration, to any extent and with any object, of the genital or anal openings of another whether or not there is any emission, through the use of coercion that results in personal injury to the victim;

3. "Incest" is when a person knowingly marries or has sexual intercourse with a person within the following degrees of blood relationship: parents and children, including grandparents and grandchildren of every degree; brothers and sisters of the half, as well as of the whole blood; uncles and nieces/nephews; aunts and nephews/nieces; first degree cousins;

4. "Non-contact sexual exploitation" is committed when an adult, for their sexual gratification: exposes intimate parts of their body, including the genitals, anus or breasts, to a minor; forces a minor to watch sexual acts or sexual violence; forces the minor to perform sexual acts while being watched by the adult; forces the minor to listen to threats and/or sexual details; or, watches a minor undress.

"Adult" is a person eighteen (18) years of age or older who is subject to the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris.

"Child" is a person under fourteen (14) years of age.

"Custodian" is a person other than a parent or guardian who is providing food, shelter, and supervision to a child.

"Contempt of Court" is the willful disobedience or interference of the Court.

"Delinquent Act" is an act committed by a juvenile which is designated a crime under the Pueblo of Picuris Criminal Code.

"Detention Facility" is a facility in which a minor may be placed for a period of temporary custody prior to disposition by the Pueblo of Picuris Juvenile Court.

"Domicile" means the permanent legal residence of an individual. The domicile of a child is presumed to be that of the child's mother unless proven otherwise.

"Extended Family" is a person (tribal member) who has reached the age of eighteen (18), who is the minor's grandparent, aunt or uncle, brother or sister, brother-in-law or sister-in- law, niece or nephew, first or second cousin, stepparent, godparent or traditionally adopted individual.

"Foster Care" is a child welfare service, which provides substitute family care for a child for a period when his/her own family cannot care for them. The goal of foster care or any placement is a permanent family for the child. It includes all out of home care when it is officially sanctioned by Bureau of Indian Affairs Northern Pueblos Agency social services or human services. Out of home care covers, voluntary and involuntary placements. They may be short or long-term, temporary or emergency placement, with a family, group home, or institution.

"Guardian" is a person other than the minor's parent who is by law responsible for the care and custody of that minor or his/her estate or both.

"Guardian Ad Litem" is an adult appointed by the Court who is to represent a child in any suit to which he/she may be a party for the protection of the child's interest.

"Indian" is any member of a federally recognized tribe or a person eligible for membership in a federally recognized tribe.

"Indian Custodian" is an adult Indian to whom temporary physical care, custody and control has been transferred by the parent of such minor.

"Juvenile Offender" is a person who commits a delinquent act prior to their eighteenth (18th) birthday.

"Legal Custody" is a legal status created by a Court that vests in a person the right and duty to protect the custody of a minor, the right and duty to protect, train and discipline the minor and to provide him/her with food, shelter, education and ordinary medical care, all subject to the powers, rights, duties and responsibilities of the guardian of the minor and subject to any remaining parental rights and duties; an individual granted legal custody of a minor shall exercise his/her rights and responsibilities as custodian personally unless otherwise authorized by the Court entering the order.

"Minor" is a person under eighteen (18) years of age. "Minor-in-Need-of-Care" is a minor who is:

a. Neglected by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s) or other care-provider; or

b. Abused by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s) or other care-provider; or

c. A status offender.

"Neglect" occurs when a minor:

a. Has no parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s), or extended family member available and willing to care for him/her;

b. Has suffered, or is likely to certainly suffer a physical injury, inflicted upon him/her by other than accidental means, which causes or creates a substantial risk of death, disfigurement or impairment of bodily functions; or

c. Has not been provided with food, clothing, shelter, medical care, education or supervision adequate for his/her needs by his/her parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s); or

d. Has committed delinquent acts as a result of parental pressure, guidance, or approval.

"Parent" includes a natural or adoptive parent but does not include persons whose parental rights have been terminated, nor does it include the unwed father whose paternity has not been acknowledged or established.

"Permanency Planning" is the procedure by which a permanent home is to be provided to every child, first, if possible, with the child(ren)'s parent(s) and, if that is not feasible within a reasonable time, with another person or family.

"Probable Cause" is reasonable cause or reasonable grounds to believe a fact, supported by sufficient evidence.

"Probation" is a legal status created by Court Order following an adjudication involving a violation of law by a minor, whereby the minor is permitted to remain in his/her home under prescribed conditions and under supervision of a probation officer, subject to return to the Court for further proceedings if any of the conditions prescribed are violated.

"Protective Supervision" is a legal status created by a Court Order in a proceeding not involving a delinquent act by a minor, whereby the minor is permitted to remain in his/her home under supervision and with assistance to correct the need for supervision or need of care which is provided by a social worker, probation officer or other agency designated by the Court.

"Restitution" is community service or financial reimbursement to the victim by the minor as ordered by the Court. It may include actual repairs done by the minor to the victim's damaged property. Financial reimbursement is limited to: actual damages for injury; loss of property; actual expenses for medical, psychiatric, and psychological treatment for injury to a person; and lost wages from physical injuries which are the direct result of the delinquent act.

"Shelter Care" is a home or living facility used as a temporary living place for a minor pending the return of the minor to his/her family or his/her placement in a residential facility designed for long-term placement.

"Status Offender" is a minor who:

a. Does not comply with the requirements of the compulsory school attendance Chapter of this Code; or

b. Disobeys, continually and habitually, the reasonable and lawful demands of his/her parent, guardian or custodian and is beyond parental control; or

c. Has left the home of his/her parent, guardian, or custodian without consent and has remained away for at least twenty-four (24) hours.

CHAPTER 2 STANDARDS FOR THE PROTECTION AND BENEFIT OF CHILDREN

Section 10-2-1. Best Interests of the Child.

All actions and decisions made under the authority of this Code shall be implemented to serve the best interests of the child. In determining the best interests of the child the following principles govern:

A. A child's need for love, nurturing, protection and stability. A child must have a safe and nurturing home environment offering emotional support and comfort; the basic needs of food, clothing and shelter; reasonable medical care and protection from danger, violence, or exposure to harmful conduct including drug and alcohol abuse.

B. A child's need for family. A child must have connection to loving and caring family members for guidance and nurturing. Although not all children have the benefit of family care, nothing can replace the primary role of loving parents and family in a child's life.

C. A child's need for identity and development. A child must develop self-identity and awareness of his/her unique role within the larger community, including the child's cultural community. This is done by participation in cultural activities, speaking one's native language and having opportunities and encouragement to pursue education and enrichment.

D. A child's need for happiness. A child cannot be happy unless his/her primary needs are met; but a child also needs opportunities for play and recreation, leisure time and other activities that the child enjoys, and possession of toys and other personal items of importance to the child.

Section 10-2-2. Placement Priorities.

A. Any placement under this Code shall be made for the best interests of the child(ren). All placement decisions should support the child(ren)'s affiliation with Pueblo of Picuris or Indian culture and provide the least restrictive environment which meets the child(ren)'s needs, and in the case of detention, assures the safety and protection of the public.

B. With the understanding that the prioritization must be interpreted with flexibility and recognizing that the best interests of the child(ren) are primary, the following order of priority shall guide all placements:

1. The child(ren) remain with the child(ren)'s family in the child(ren)'s home under conditions and restrictions established by the Court;

2. Placement in the home of an extended family member residing on the Pueblo of Picuris;

3. Placement in the home of an extended family member residing off the Pueblo of Picuris;

4. Placement in a facility or home outside the Pueblo of Picuris which is licensed or certified by the Tribe, or licensed or certified for such placement by the State of New Mexico.

C. The child(ren) shall be permitted to have appropriate involvement with family, tribal and cultural activities.

Section 10-2-3. Shelter Standards.

A. The Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department, with the approval of the Tribal Council, shall adopt written regulations for the operation of a shelter care facility, foster care home, or detention facility licensed, certified, or approved by the Department. The regulations shall include standards for cleanliness, sanitation, heat, electricity, personnel, visiting privileges, occupancy limits, provisions for medical, dental and mental health care, and provisions for food, clothing and the possession of personal items.

B. The Department shall enforce the following standards and develop regulations consistent with such standards, for the treatment of minors in a shelter care facility, foster care home, or a detention facility:

(1) A minor shall not be punished, ridiculed or criticized for expressing through speech, custom or dress in the minor's Indian or Tribal heritage;

(2) Subject to legitimate institutional regulations, a minor shall be allowed to wear his/her hair as he/she chooses;

(3) Incoming and outgoing mail may be inspected for contraband, but shall not be read;

(4) Whenever possible, the minor shall be allowed to attend the school in which he/she is enrolled. If the circumstances do not permit the minor to attend his/her regular school, arrangements shall be made to permit the minor to continue his/her education;

(5) A minor shall be allowed to attend family events and traditional ceremonies, provided that he/she is accompanied by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s);

(6) A minor shall be given the opportunity to engage in physical exercise for at least one hour every day;

(7) A minor shall not be punished by physical force, solitary confinement, or deprivation of meals or family visits;

(8) A minor shall perform reasonable work duties such as maintenance of his/her bed and personal property, but shall not be required to perform work duties not commensurate with his/her age, physical, mental, or emotional abilities.

C. In addition to and notwithstanding the provisions of Paragraph B, the following standards shall apply to any placement of a minor in a detention facility:

(1) A minor shall wear only the clothing supplied by the detention facility;

(2) If the minor is unable to attend a local school, schoolwork and education assistance at the minor's level of development shall be provided for the minor;

(3) With prior Court Order, a minor shall be allowed to attend the funeral and related activities of family or extended family members, or to attend traditional ceremonies, provided that he/she is accompanied by the parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s), and returns immediately to the detention facility at the conclusion of the period set by the Court.

(4) If reasonable belief exists that a minor may cause physical injury to him/herself or others, he/she shall be placed in a supervised holding cell and monitored on a prescribed schedule and referred for immediate treatment by medical and/or psychological personnel.

Section 10-2-4. Duty to Report Abuse and Neglect.

A. Persons who have a reasonable cause to suspect a minor has been abused or neglected shall report the abuse or neglect to the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department and to the Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement Office.

B. Those persons who are required to report suspected abuse or neglect are any physician, nurse, other medical, mental health professional, principal, teacher, other school official, social worker, child care worker, other child care staff, including foster parents, residential care or institutional personnel, counselor, peace officer, judge, attorney, other judicial officer and any other person required to report pursuant to Federal or Tribal law. This paragraph shall not be interpreted to override ethical rules defining the attorney-client privilege.

C. Any person may make a report of suspected abuse or neglect.

D. Those persons reporting, except those specified in Paragraph B, may remain anonymous if the Court so determines.

E. All persons or agencies reporting abuse or neglect, in good faith, shall be immune from civil or criminal liability.

Section 10-2-5. Records Maintenance and Protection.

A. A record of all hearings under this Code shall be made and preserved until the jurisdiction of the Court has ended. All Court and law enforcement records concerning a minor shall be kept separate from the records of adults.

B. All records are confidential and shall not be open to inspection other than by Court personnel. The following persons are subject to regulations adopted by the Court:

(1) The minor and his/her attorney;

(2) The minor's parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s);

(3) The Juvenile Probation Officer or child welfare caseworker;

(4) The prosecutor; and

(5) Any other person granted permission by Court Order.

C. Each person who inspects a minor's record shall, in writing agree, to maintain the confidentiality of the record. Failure to abide by the agreement shall constitute Contempt of Court.

D. All records of a minor shall be sealed when the minor is no longer subject to the Court's jurisdiction, and thereafter, released only by Court Order following notice to the parties, and, only if needed, for a Court proceeding concerning a serious criminal charge or similar circumstance of compelling need. This paragraph shall not be construed to permit the release of information for other purposes, such as background checks conducted for employment, licensing, or security clearances. Adoption records shall be released as allowed in Section 10- 13-9.

Section 10-2-6. Confidentiality.

Any record or information obtained as a result of a proceeding covered by this Code and not otherwise covered by Section 10-2-5 are confidential and shall be made available only to his/her representative, the minor's parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s), or to such other person the Court determines has valid reasons to see such records.

Section 10-2-7. Confidentiality of Detention.

The Court may order that the place of detention or shelter care be kept confidential to protect the best interests of the minor.

Section 10-2-8. Fingerprints and Photographs.

A. A minor may be fingerprinted or photographed without Court Order only under the following circumstances:

(1) If necessary for identification;

(2) To compare fingerprints found during an investigation, provided that a law enforcement officer has reasonable cause to believe the fingerprints are those of the minor; or

(3) If there is reasonable cause to believe the minor has been subjected to abuse or neglect.

B. Copies of the fingerprints and photographs shall be immediately destroyed if the minor is not referred to the Court, unless needed for a criminal investigation.

Section 10-2-9. Full Faith and Credit.

The Court shall give full faith and credit to State (and other Tribes') child custody court orders, as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (d).

CHAPTER 3 ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PUEBLO OF PICURIS CHILDREN'S COURT

Section 10-3-1. Establishment.

There is hereby established for the Pueblo of Picuris, a Court to be known as the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court.

Section 10-3-2. Powers and Duties.

A. The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court, when acting as a Children's Court, shall have the same powers and duties as the Tribal Court.

B. The Court is authorized to cooperate fully with federal, state, tribal, public, or private agencies in order to participate in any diversion, rehabilitation, or training programs.

C. The Court shall utilize such social services as may be furnished by any tribe, federal or state agency.

D. The Court shall accept or decline state court or other tribe's transfers of child custody proceedings as set out in the Code.

CHAPTER 4 PERSONNEL

Section 10-4-1. Judges.

A. The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court shall consist of one or more judges appointed by the Tribal Council.

B. In carrying out duties and powers specifically enumerated under the Children's Code, Judges of the Court shall have the same powers and duties as Judges of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

Section 10-4-2. Prosecutor.

A. The Court shall appoint a Children's Court Prosecutor who shall be responsible for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this Code.

B. The duties of the Children's Court Prosecutor are:

(1) File petitions with the Court as provided in this Code;

(2) Represents the interests of the Tribe in all proceedings under this Code; and

(3) Perform such other duties as the Court may order.

Section 10-4-3. Juvenile Probation Officer.

A. The Court shall appoint from among the officers presently employed by the Eight Northern Pueblos Council Peacekeepers Program a Children's Court Juvenile Probation Officer who shall carry out the duties of this office.

B. The Juvenile Probation Officer shall not give any testimony in any court proceeding which may lead to the filing of juvenile offender charges against a minor but may testify for purposes of revoking probation.

C. The duties and powers of the Juvenile Probation Officer shall be to:

(1) Make preliminary inquiries and social studies, and such other investigations as the Judge may direct and to keep written records of such investigations or studies;

(2) Make reports as provided in this Code or as directed by the Judge;

(3) Conduct informal adjustment hearings;

(4) Place a minor in detention or shelter care as provided in this Code;

(5) Identify and develop resources on the Pueblo of Picuris to enhance each minor's potential as a valuable member of the tribal community;

(6) Explain to the minor, if old enough and to the parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s), the meaning and conditions of probation or protective supervision and shall give necessary instructions;

(7) Keep informed concerning the conduct and conditions of each minor on probation or under protective supervision and shall report thereon to the Judge as directed;

(8) Use all suitable methods to aid minors on probation or under protective supervision to bring about improvements in their conduct or condition;

(9) Perform such other duties in connection with the care, custody or transportation of children as the Court may require; and

(10) Have the powers of law enforcement officers for purposes of this Code but shall, whenever possible, refrain from exercising such powers except in urgent situations in which a regular law enforcement officer is not immediately available.

Section 10-4-4. Clerk.

The Clerk of the Tribal Court shall act as Children's Court Clerk and shall keep a record of the court proceedings, issue all processes and notices required herein, and perform such other duties as may be assigned by the Judge.

Section 10-4-5. Guardian Ad Litem.

A. The Court in any proceedings authorized by this Code may appoint, for the purpose of the proceedings, a guardian ad litem for a minor where the Court finds that the minor does not have a parent, guardian or custodian appearing on behalf of the minor or if the interest of the minor conflicts with the interest of the parent, guardian or custodian.

B. The guardian ad litem shall be familiar with the rights of children and the provisions of this Code.

C. Duties of the guardian ad litem are to:

(1) Represent the minor's interest in any proceedings as required by this Court; and

(2) Make recommendations to the Court on disposition.

Section 10-4-6. Court Appointed Special Advocates.

Pursuant to funding and guidelines by the Pueblo of Picuris the Court may utilize a Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) to assist in any Children's Court proceedings.

CHAPTER 5 JURISDICTION

Section 10-5-1. Jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court.

The Children's Court of the Pueblo of Picuris has exclusive original jurisdiction of the following:

A. Juvenile offenders except in those cases transferred to Tribal Court pursuant to this Code;

B. Minors-in-need-of-care;

C. Termination of parental rights;

D. Adoption of minors;

E. Award of custody or appointment of custodian or guardian of minors;

F. Commitment of minors;

G. Emancipation;

H. Minors before a State court who are residents or domiciliary of the Tribe as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (a);

I. Minors before a State court who are not residents or domiciliary of the Tribe and transfer of jurisdiction has been requested and accepted as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (b); or

J. Adults as set out in this Code.

Section 10-5-2. Concurrent Jurisdiction.

The Children's Court of the Pueblo of Picuris has concurrent jurisdiction over any minor who commits an act, which is deemed illegal by federal, state, municipal or other tribe's law, while within any of those jurisdictions when that minor is an enrolled member of the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 10-5-3. Transfer to Tribal Court of Alleged Juvenile Offender.

A. The prosecutor may file a petition requesting the Court to transfer the minor to the jurisdiction of the Tribal Court if the minor is at least sixteen (16) years of age and is alleged to have committed an act that would be considered a crime if committed by an adult.

B. The Court shall conduct a hearing within ten (10) days of filing of the petition to determine whether jurisdiction of the minor should be transferred to Tribal Court.

C. The Juvenile Probation Officer shall prepare and present a written report to the Court at least three (3) days before the transfer hearing. The report shall contain:

(1) Information on the nature and seriousness of the alleged offense(s);

(2) The nature and condition of the minor as evidenced by his/her age as well as mental and physical condition; and

(3) Past record of offenses and Court efforts at rehabilitation

D. The prosecutor and other attorneys representing parties may also file with the Court written recommendations within the same time limit. All reports shall be served on all parties at the same time they are filed.

E. The following factors shall be considered by the Court when determining whether to transfer jurisdiction of the minor to Tribal Court:

(1) The nature and seriousness of the offense(s) with which the minor is charged;

(2) The nature and condition of the minor, as evidences by his/her age as well as mental and physical condition; and

(3) The past record of offenses and Court efforts at rehabilitation.

E. The Court may transfer jurisdiction of the minor to Tribal Court if the Court finds clear and convincing evidence that there are no reasonable prospects for rehabilitating the minor through resources available to the Court and either of the following exist:

(1) The past offenses allegedly committed by the minor indicate a pattern of conduct which constitutes a substantial danger to the public; or

(2) The offense with which the minor is charged as a juvenile offender indicates conduct which constitutes substantial danger to the public.

F. The Court's Order under this Section is a final Order for the purposes of appeal.

Section 10-5-4. Transfer from State Court under the Indian Child Welfare Act (P.L. 95-608).

A. The Tribal agent for service of notice of State Court child custody proceedings, as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), shall be the Pueblo of Picuris ICWA Director.

B. Investigation and pre-transfer report shall be done by the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services. The Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services shall conduct an investigation and file a written report with the Court within three (3) days of receipt of notice from the Tribal agent for service of notice. The report shall include facts which will assist the Court in making its decisions as required by this Section, including but not limited to: parentage, family, existing relatives, reasons for minor being subject to Court jurisdiction, and, if transfer or intervention will be in the minor's best interest.

C. Decision for Transfer or Intervention: The Court shall determine whether the Tribe should petition for transfer from or intervene in State Court and shall file a written order to that effect.

D. Petition for Transfer or Intervention: The Pueblo of Picuris Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall file a petition for transfer or intervention, within three (3) days of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court's Order.

E. The Court will not accept a transfer from State Court unless the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services report recommends acceptance of transfer, and if either of the following exist:

(1) A parent of Indian custodian's petition to State Court for transfer is granted; or

(2) The Tribe's petition to State Court for transfer is granted.

F. Adjudicatory Hearing: Upon receipt of transfer jurisdiction from State Court, the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall file a minor-in-need-of-care petition, and an adjudicatory hearing shall be held in accordance with this Code.

Section 10-5-5. Adults.

A. Parental Responsibility.

(1) Parent as Party: The parent of the child may be made a party to a petition if the child is alleged to be a minor-in-need-of-care or a juvenile offender.

(2) Dispositions: The Court may order the parent to submit to counseling, participate in any probation or other treatment program ordered by the Court and, if the child is committed for institutionalization, to participate in any institutional treatment or counseling program including attendance at the site of the institution.

(3) Fines: The parent is not liable for a fine his/her child may be ordered to pay.

(4) Cost of Support: The Court shall order the parent to pay the reasonable cost or part of the cost of support and treatment of the child if:

a. The child is adjudicated a minor-in-need-of-care, or a juvenile offender; and

b. The Court orders this child placed with an agency, institution or an individual other than the parent.

B. Other Adults: The Court shall join as a party any adult necessary for proper disposition of any case heard pursuant to this Code.

C. Enforcement: The Court may enforce any orders issued under this Section by use of its contempt power.

Section 10-5-6. Continuance of Jurisdiction.

For dispositional purposes, jurisdiction over a child under this Children's Code shall continue until he/she becomes nineteen (19) years of age, unless such jurisdiction is terminated prior thereto.

CHAPTER 6 PROCEDURE.

Section 10-6-1. Rules of Procedure.

The Chief Judge, subject to the approval of the Tribal Council, may adopt rules of procedure and forms for the conduct of the Children's Court.

Section 10-6-2. Commencement of Action.

A. Petition: Except as otherwise provided below, proceedings in children's cases begin by a petition.

B. Exceptions to Petition: A petition shall not be required in the case of violations of motor vehicle laws, ordinances, or fish and game laws and ordinances. The issuance of a traffic or other citation or summons for these violations is sufficient to invoke the jurisdiction of the Children's Court. Unless the Court otherwise orders, a preliminary investigation is not required in such cases.

Section 10-6-3. Petition.

A. A petition shall be entitled, "In the Matter of , A Minor," and shall set forth:

(1) The name, date of birth, and residence of the minor;

(2) The names and residences of the minor's parent(s), guardian(s), or custodian(s);

(3) A citation to the specific section, including number, of this Code, which gives the Court jurisdiction of the proceedings;

(4) Where applicable, a citation to the section of the Criminal Code which the minor is alleged to have violated;

(5) If the minor is in detention or shelter care, the place of detention or shelter care and the date and time he/she was taken into custody; and

(6) A concise statement of facts.

B. Preparation: The statements in the petition may be made upon information and belief and the petition shall be prepared, verified and signed by a Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement Officer.

C. Dismissal: The Court may dismiss a petition at any stage of the proceedings.

Section 10-6-4. Summons.

A. When Required: After a petition is filed and after such further investigation as the Court may direct, the Court shall promptly issue a summons. No summons is required for any person who appears voluntarily or who files a written waiver of service with the Clerk of the Court at or prior to the hearing.

B. Content: The summons shall contain the name of the Court, the title of the proceedings, and (except for a published summons) a brief summary of the allegations in the petition. A published summons shall simply state that a proceeding concerning the child is pending in the Court and that adjudication will be made.

C. Who shall receive: The summons shall be served on all parties and the person or persons who have physical custody of the child requiring them to appear personally and to bring the child before the Court at a time and place stated. If the person or person so summoned are not the parent(s) or guardian of the child, then a summons shall also be served on the parent(s) or guardian(s) as the case may be, notifying them of the pendency of the case and of the time and place set for the hearing. No summons needs to be issued to a parent or parents whose parental rights have been terminated.

Section 10-6-5. Subpoena of Witnesses.

The Court shall issue a subpoena immediately upon a request of any party, but such request shall be made at least forty-eight (48) hours before any hearing for which a subpoena is requested.

Section 10-6-6. Manner of Service of Court Orders.

A. Who Serves Court Orders: Service of summons, subpoena or other Court Order shall be made by an officer of BIA Law Enforcement or the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Sheriff; but upon request of the Court such service may be made by the Tribal Sheriff or by another suitable person selected by the Court.

B. Place of Service: Service of summons, subpoena or other Court Order on the Pueblo of Picuris may be made by delivering a copy thereof to the person summoned, subpoenaed or entitled to a copy of the Order; provided, however, that parents of a child living together in their home may both be served personally by delivering to either parent copies of the summons, one copy for each parent.

C. Service by Mail: If the Court is satisfied that personal service of the summons or order is impractical under the circumstances, the Court may order service by registered mail, with a return receipt requested to be signed by the addressee only, to be addressed at the last known address or the person to be served on the Pueblo of Picuris. Service shall be complete upon return to the Court of the signed receipt.

D. Other Service: If the parent or guardian of any minor required to be summoned by this Code cannot be found within the Pueblo of Picuris, the minor's presence within the Pueblo shall confer jurisdiction on the Court in proceedings in children's cases under this Code as to any absent parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s) provided that due notice has been given in one of the following manners:

(1) If the address of the parent or guardian is unknown, by sending him/her a copy of the summons by registered mail with return receipt requested to be signed by the addressee only, or by personal service outside the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris. Service by registered mail shall be complete upon return to the Court of the signed receipt.

(2) If the address or whereabouts of the guardian outside of the Pueblo, cannot, after diligent inquiry, be ascertained, by publishing a summons in a newspaper having general circulation on the Pueblo. The summons shall be published once a week for four (4) successive weeks. Service shall be complete on the day of the last publication. Proof of such service shall be filed with the Court.

Section 10-6-7. Service: Time Requirement.

A. Summons â In the case of service on the Pueblo of Picuris, service completed not less than five (5) days before the time set in the summons for the appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient to confer jurisdiction. In the case of service outside the Pueblo of Picuris, service completed not less than eight (8) days before the time set in the summons for appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient to confer jurisdiction.

B. Subpoenas and other Court orders shall be served not less than twenty-four (24) hours before the time set for the hearing.

Section 10-6-8. Warrants and Orders for Custody.

A. Custodial Warrant: The Court may issue a warrant directing that a minor be taken into custody upon a sworn written statement of facts showing probable cause to believe the minor is a juvenile offender and is a danger to him/herself or to the community.

B. Emergency Custody Order: The Court may issue an emergency custody order upon a sworn written statement of facts showing probable cause to believe that a minor is a minor-in-need- of-care and is in immediate danger from his/her surroundings.

C. Search Warrants.

(1) The Court may issue a warrant authorizing a law enforcement officer to search for a minor if there is probable cause to believe that the minor is within the Court's jurisdiction and a custodial warrant has been issued for the alleged juvenile offender or an Emergency Custody Order has been issued for a minor alleged to be a minor-in- need-of-care; or

(2) The Court may issue a warrant authorizing a law enforcement officer to search for and seize property when probable cause has been established that the property has been obtained or is possessed in a manner, which constitutes a delinquent act; or is designed or intended for use or which is or has been used as a means of committing a delinquent act; or would be material evidence in a proceeding.

D. Bench Warrant: The Court may issue a warrant for a person's arrest for contempt of court immediately upon the failure to appear in court, either in person or by counsel, as ordered by the Court.

Section 10-6-9. Contempt of Court.

The Court may punish an adult for contempt of court in accordance with the Pueblo of Picuris Law and Order Code, but only after a hearing in which the defendant is accorded the procedures and rights required by this Code.

Section 10-6-10. Separate, Civil Proceedings.

Proceedings in children's cases shall be regarded as civil proceedings, with the Court exercising equitable powers. Children's cases shall be handled separately from adult cases.

Section 10-6-11. Conduct of Hearings.

A. Private and Closed: Hearings shall be separate from other proceedings and shall be private and closed to the public except hearings for traffic, hunting and fishing violations. Only the parties, their attorneys, witnesses and other persons requested by the parties and approved by the Court may be present at the hearing.

B. Denial of Allegations: If the allegations are denied, the Court shall hear the evidence and decide whether or not the allegations are true.

C. Admission of Allegations: The Court must find that an admission is voluntarily and knowingly made.

D. Informal, Non-Jury Hearing: All hearings shall be heard by the Court without a jury and may be conducted in an informal manner so long as the rights of every person appearing before the Court are protected as required by this Code.

E. Dismissal or Disposition.
