(d) A statement which discloses in detail any charge, complaint, fine, order, decree, statement or finding of "no contest" for violation of any Tribal, federal, state, county or municipal environmental or health law, regulation, permit or condition against any officer, director, partner or holder of an interest of 5% or more within the past five (5) years, including the jurisdiction, disposition and name, address and phone number of the person who filed the original charge, or complaint, and the name of the director, board, administrative body, judge, justice of the peace, magistrate or arbitrator who levied or entered any fine, order, penalty, decree, statement or finding.

(10) A current financial statement of the applicant's net worth, including a description of major assets and liabilities, and any other financial information requested by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department.

(11) A description of any judgments rendered against any officer, director, partner or holder of an interest of 5% or more in the applicant for five (5) years preceding the date of the application.

(12) A description of any bankruptcy or insolvency proceedings instituted by any officer, director, partner or holder of an interest of 5% or more in the applicant for five (5) years preceding the date of application.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall not issue a solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit unless the Tribe has issued a land use permit, or lease, authorizing the operation of the MSWLF facility.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may issue a solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit, on if it finds, on the basis of information contained in the application and otherwise available to it, an only after conducting a public hearing as specified herein, that the applicant will comply with the Ordinance: the 40 CFR Part 258 Criteria; and all rules and regulations, technical standards and criteria, guidance documents and permit conditions.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department must also find that the applicant has the financial and technical ability to construct and/or operate, close and post-close the MSWLF as required by the Ordinance.

The burden of proof shall rest on the applicant to demonstrate compliance with all Tribal solid waste criteria and requirement. The issuance or denial of any permit by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department is completely discretionary. In issuing any permit, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may impose permit conditions which are more stringent than provided under the Ordinance, if such are reasonably necessary. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall not issue a solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit, unless it is convinced that the primary consideration of the permittee is to prevent environmental damage and protect the public health. The long-term protection of the Tribe's public health, environment and natural resources shall be a critical consideration for the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department's issuance or denial of a permit.

A solid waste operation facility permit shall be valid for the operation, closures and post- closure period designated and required for such MSWLF, but such permit is subject to revocation, suspension or modification as provided herein. Any condition imposed on any solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit issued by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may only be modified after a public hearing which is duly noticed regarding modification of such permit.

Section 11-1-21. Permits for the Collection and Transportation of Solid Waste

As a condition for the issuance of a solid waste collection and transportation permit, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall require every vehicle operated by the transporter to be conspicuously marked to identify the solid waste transported. Every vehicle shall be marked with the trade name of the transporter, and the number of solid waste transportation permits issued pursuant to this Section. Every vehicle and driver must be licensed by the State of New Mexico and must comply with all safety and insurance requirements of the State of New Mexico and the Department of Transportation.

As a condition for the issuance of a solid waste collection and transportation permit, a transporter agrees to make an annual report by December 1 of each year to the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department indicating the number and type of installations emptied or cleaned, the volume and nature of solid waste disposed of, the place and manner in which such solid waste was finally disposed and such other information as the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may require. A renewal may be denied by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department for failure of the permittee to properly and timely file such annual report.

Solid waste permits for the collection and transportation of solid waste must be renewed annually by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department on a calendar basis. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall adopt rules and regulations for solid waste collection and transportation on the Pueblo of Picuris, including the operation of transfer stations, and may impose whatever condition it deems reasonably necessary to protect the environment, and the health, safety and welfare of the Tribe and its members before issuing any permit under this section.

Section 11-1-22. Public Hearing on MSWLF Permit Applications

No solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit shall be issued unless there has been a public hearing conducted by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department at which the applicant and all interested persons shall have an opportunity to present relevant evidence and be heard on whether or not the permit should be granted, or whether there are any special conditions which should be included in such permit. All applications for a solid waste construction and/or operation facility permit, including all documentation required for such permit, shall be available for public review and inspection at least sixty (60) days in advance of the hearing. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall publish weekly notice of such public hearing on each application beginning at least sixty (60) days in advance of the hearing in the most widely circulated newspaper on the Pueblo of Picuris for three consecutive weeks. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall also post notice, at least sixty (60) days in advance of the hearing. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may designate issues it deems most relevant for the public hearing in the public notice, but the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall consider all issued which are raised at the hearing. The public hearing shall be continued until all persons have had an opportunity to present their views.

Section 11-1-23. Oath and Application Filing Fees

Each report and application filed shall be signed or notarized under oath in a form approved by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department. Each application shall be accompanied by a reasonable filing fee established by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department to reflect the Tribe's cost of processing the application or preparing an environmental assessment, the public notice and hearing and the costs of technical and legal consultants to review the application, prepare the permit, exhibits and guidance documents.

Section 11-1-24. Other Fees and Taxes

In order to recover operating costs, the Tribe may impose reasonable fees on each permittee who constructs or operates an MSWLF, or collects and transports solid waste. Any fees to be imposed by the Tribe shall be specifically referred to in each permit. In addition, the Tribe may impose taxes on each permittee who operates an MSWLF, or collects and transports solid waste. The payment of such fees or taxes shall be a condition of maintaining such permit.

Section 11-1-25. Closure; Post-Closure and Financial Assurances Closure Care Requirements for MSWLFs

The owner or operator of an MSWLF which has received solid waste after October 9, 1991, shall install a final cover system that is designed to minimize infiltration and erosion in compliance with 40 CFR Â§258.60.

The final cover system as set forth in 40 CFR Â§258.60(a) must be comprised of an erosion layer underlain by an infiltration layer as follows:

(1) The infiltration layer must be comprised of a minimum of 18 inches of earthen material that has a permeability of less than or equal to the permeability of any bottom liner system or natural subsoils present, or a permeability no greater than 1 x 10-5 cm/sec, whichever is less; and

(2) The erosion layer must consist of a minimum of 6 inches of earthen material that is capable of sustaining native plant growth.

If EPA approves the Tribe's solid waste program, then the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may approve an alternative final cover design under 40 CFR Â§258.60(b) that includes:

(1) An infiltration layer that achieves an equivalent reduction in infiltration as the infiltration layer specified in Â§258.60(a)(1); and

(2) An erosion layer that provides equivalent protection from wind and water erosion as the erosion layer specified in Â§258.60(a)(2). This alternative final cover design may not be applied to landfills which ceased to receive solid waste on or after October 9, 1993.

The owner or operator must prepare a written closure plan that describes the steps necessary to close an MSWLF unit at any point during its active life in accordance with the cover design requirements. The closure plan, at a minimum, must include the following information:

(1) A description of the final cover and the methods and procedures to be used to install the cover;

(2) An estimate of the largest area of the MSWLF unit ever requiring a final cover at any time during the active life;

(3) An estimate of the maximum inventory of wastes ever on-site over the active life of the landfill facility; and

(4) A schedule for completing all activities necessary to satisfy the closure criteria in Â§258.60.

The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that a closure plan has been prepared and placed in the operating record by the date of the first receipt of solid waste.

Prior to beginning closure of each MSWLF unit, the owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that a notice of intent to close the unit has been placed in the operating record.

The owner or operator must begin closure activities of each MSWLF unit no later than 30 days after the date on which the MSWLF unit receives the known final receipt of wastes or, if the MSWLF unit has remaining capacity and there is a reasonable likelihood that the MSWLF unit will receive additional wastes, no later than one year after the most recent receipt of waste. Extensions beyond the one-year deadline for beginning closure may be granted by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department if the Tribe has an EPA approved solid waste program, and if the owner or operator demonstrates that the MSWLF unit has the capacity to receive additional wastes and the owner or operator has taken and will continue to take all steps necessary to prevent threats to human health and the environment from the unclosed MSWLF unit.

The owner or operator of any MSWLF unit must complete closure activities of each MSWLF unit in accordance with the closure plan within 180 days following the beginning of closure as specified in 40 CFR Â§258.60(f). Extensions of the closure period may be granted by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department, if the Tribe has an EPA approved solid waste program, and if the owner or operator demonstrates that closure will, of necessity, take longer than 180 days and he/she has taken and will continue to take all steps to prevent threats to human health and the environment from the unclosed MSWLF unit.

Following the closure of each MSWLF unit, the owner or operator must supply the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department with a certification signed by an independent registered professional engineer that verifies that closure has been completed in accordance with the closure plan, an shall place such certification in the operating record.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall take whatever action is reasonably necessary in perpetuity to notify any potential users or purchasers of the landfill facility property that the land has been used as a landfill facility and that its use is restricted under 40 CFR Â§258.61(c)(3). Post-closure use of the property shall not disturb the integrity of the site, final cover, liner(s) or monitoring systems, unless necessary to comply with requirements under 40 CFR Part 258.

Post Closure Care Requirement for MSWLFs

(A) Following closure of each MSWLF unit, the owner or operator must conduct post- closure care. Post-closure care must be conducted for thirty (30) years, except as provided under Paragraph B of this section, and must include the following:

(1) Maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of any final cover, including making repairs to the cover as necessary to correct the effects of settlement, subsidence, erosion, or other events, and preventing run-on and run-off from eroding or otherwise damaging the final cover; and

(2) Maintaining and operating the leachate collection system in accordance with the requirements in 40 CFR Â§258.40. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may allow the owner or operator to stop managing leachate if the owner or operator demonstrates that leachate no longer poses a threat to human health and the environment.

(3) Monitoring the ground water in accordance with the requirements of Subpart E of 40 CFR Part 258 and maintaining the groundwater monitoring system; and

(4) Maintaining and operating the gas monitoring system in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Â§258.23.

(B) The length of the post-closure care period may be:

(1) Decreased by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department if the Tribe has an EPA approved solid waste program and if the owner or operator demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the reduced period is sufficient to protect human health and the environment; or

(2) Increased by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department if the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department determines that the lengthened period is necessary to protect human health and the environment.

(C) The owner or operator of an MSWLF unit must prepare a written post-closure plan that includes, at a minimum, the following information:

(1) A description of the monitoring and maintenance activities required in 40 CFR Â§ 258.61(a) for each MSWLF unit, and the frequency at which the activities will be performed; and

(2) The name, address and telephone number of the person or office to contact about the facility during the post-closure period; and

(3) A description of the planned uses of the property during the post-closure period. Post-closure use of the property shall not disturb the integrity of the final cover, liner(s), or any other components of the containment system, or the function of the monitoring systems unless necessary to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 258. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may, if the Tribe has an EPA approved solid waste plan, approve any other disturbance if the owner or operator demonstrates that disturbance of the final cover, liner or other component of the containment system, including any removal of waste, will not increase the potential threat to human health or the environment.

(D) The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that a post-closure plan has been prepared and placed in the operating record prior to the initial receipt of waste by the facility.

(E) Following completion of the post-closure care period for each MSWLF unit, the owner or operator must supply the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department with a certification signed by an independent registered professional engineer which verifies that all post-closure care has been completed in accordance with the post- closure plan, and shall place such certification in the operating record.

Section 11-1-26. Financial Assurance Requirements for Closure, Post-Closure and Corrective Action

Owners or operators of MSWLFs on the Pueblo of Picuris are required to comply with the financial assurance criteria under Subpart G of 40 CFR Part 258, which are incorporated herein and contained at 40 CFR Â§258.71 (Financial Assurance for Closure); 40 CFRÂ§258-72 (Financial Assurance for Post-Closure Care); 40 CFR Â§258.73 (Financial Assurance for Corrective Action); and 40 CFR Â§258.74 (Allowable Mechanisms to Demonstrate Financial Assurance).

(A) Financial Assurance for Closure.

The owner or operator of an MSWLF must have a detailed written estimate, in current dollars, of the cost of hiring a third party to close the largest area of each MSWLF unit ever requiring a final cover as required under 40 CFR Â§258.60 at any time during the active life in accordance with the closure plan. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the estimate has been placed in the operating record.

The cost estimate must equal the cost of closing the largest area of an MSWLF unit ever requiring a final cover at any time during the active life when the extent and manner of its operation would make closure the most expensive, as indicated by its closure plan.

During the active life of the MSWLF unit, the owner or operator must annually adjust the closure estimate for inflation.

The owner or operator must increase the closure cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided, if changes to the closure plan or MSWLF unit conditions increase the maximum cost of closure at any time during the remaining active life. The owner or operator may reduce the closure cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided under Section B herein, if the closure cost estimate exceeds the maximum cost of closure at any time during the remaining life of the MSWLF unit. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the justification for the reduction of the closure cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance has been placed in the operating record.

The owner or operator of each MSWLF unit must establish financial assurance for closure of the MSWLF unit in compliance with 40 CFR Â§258.74. The owner or operator must provide continuous coverage for closure until released from financial assurance requirements by demonstrating compliance with 40 CFR Â§258.60(h) and (i).

(B) Financial Assurance for Post-Closure Care.

The owner or operator must have a detailed estimate, in current dollars, of the cost of hiring a third party to conduct post-closure care for the MSWLF unit in compliance with the post-closure plan developed under 40 CFR Â§258.61. The post-closure cost estimate used to demonstrate financial assurance must account for the total costs of conducting post-

closure care, including annual and periodic costs as described in the post-closure plan over the entire post-closure care period. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the estimate has been placed in the operating record.

The cost estimate for post-closure care must be based on the most expensive cost of post-closure care during the post-closure care period.

During the active live of the MSWLF unit and during the post-closure care period the owner or operator must annually adjust the post-closure cost estimate for inflation.

The owner operator must increase the post-closure care cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided if changes in the post-closure care plan or the MSWLF unit conditions increase the maximum cost of post-closure care. The owner or operator may reduce the post-closure care cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided if the cost estimate exceeds the maximum costs of the post-closure care remaining over the post-closure care period. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the justification for the reduction of the post-closure care cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance has been placed in the operating record.

The owner or operator of each MSWLF unit must establish financial assurance for the costs of post-closure care of the MSWLF unit in compliance with 40 CFRÂ§258.74.

The owner or operator must provide continuous coverage and financial assurance for post- closure care until released from financial assurance requirements for post-closure care by demonstrating compliance with 40 CFR Â§258.61(e).

(C) Financial Assurance for Corrective Action.

An owner or operator of an MSWLF unit required to undertake a corrective action program under 40 CFR Â§258.58 must have a detailed written estimate, in current dollars, of the cost of hiring a third party to perform the corrective action in accordance with the program required under 40 CFR Â§258.58. The corrective action cost estimate must account for the total costs of corrective action activities as described in the corrective action plan for the entire corrective action period. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the estimate has been placed in the operating record.

The owner or operator must annually adjust the estimate for inflation until the corrective action program is completed in accordance with 40 CFR Â§258.58(f).

The owner or operator must increase the corrective action cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided if changes in the corrective action program or MSWLD unit conditions increase the maximum cost of corrective action.

The owner or operator may reduce the amount of the corrective action cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance provided if the cost estimate exceeds the maximum remaining costs of corrective action. The owner or operator must notify the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department that the justification for any reduction of the corrective action cost estimate and the amount of financial assurance has been placed in the operating record.

The owner or operator of each MSWLF unit required to undertake a corrective action program under 40 CFR Â§258.58 must establish, in a manner in accordance with the 40 CFR

Â§258.74, financial assurance for the most recent corrective action program. The owner or operator must provide continuous coverage and financial assurance for corrective action until released from financial assurance requirements for corrective action by demonstrating compliance with the 40 CFR Â§258.58(f) and (g).

(D) Allowable Financial Mechanisms.

40 CFR Â§258.74 required that an owner or operator of an MSWLF unit provide financial assurance to ensure that funds necessary to meet the costs of closure, post-closure care and corrective action for known release will be available in a timely fashion when they are needed. There are four mechanisms available to provide financial assurance, including a trust fund; a surety bond; a letter of cred; an insurance policy; or a combination of all four mechanisms. Any mechanism(s) that is/are used by an owner or operator must comply with all of the criteria in 40 CFR Â§258.74, which is incorporated by reference herein, and must be legally valid, binding and enforceable under state, federal and Tribal law.

The financial assurance mechanism(s) must be obtained by the owner or operator before the initial receipt of waste in the case of closure and post-closure care cost estimates; and no later than one hundred twenty (120) days after the corrective action remedy has been selected in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Â§258.58, and maintained as required by 40 CFR Â§Â§258.71-74.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department must approve the actual financial assurance mechanism(s) and financial assurance agreements that is/are provided by the owner or operator. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may also require in its discretion, in addition to the criteria for financial assurance under 40 CFR Part 258, that an owner or operator provide financial assurance for corrective action for other than known releases as a condition for issuing an MSWLF permit.

The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall also require that liability and property damage insurance coverage be provided by an owner or operator for claims arising from personal injury or property damage, including any claims from releases from an MSWLF unit.

If a trust fund mechanism is used, the trustee must be an entity who has the authority to act as a trustee, and whose trust operations are regulated and examined by a federal agency. Trust fund payments must be made as specified in 40 CFRÂ§258.74 criteria. The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department must approve the terms of any trust agreement which is to be used as a financial assurance mechanism. The trust agreement shall be irrevocable. Trust funds shall only be release to reimburse the owner or operator for closure, post-closure and corrective action costs actually incurred, but only if sufficient funds remain in the trust to cover the remaining costs.

If any surety bond is used, the surety company issuing the bond must, at a minimum, be among those listed as acceptable sureties in federal bonds in Circular 570 of the U.S. Department of the Treasury.

If any letter of credit is used, the issuing institution must be an entity which has the authority to issue letter of credit and whose letter of credit operations are regulated and examined by a federal agency.

Section 11-1-27. Enforcement Program/Administrative Procedures

Enforcement Policy: It is the policy of the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department to encourage informal, practical, result-oriented resolution of alleged violations and actions needed to prevent damage to Pueblo of Picuris resources or harm to the health, safety or welfare of the Pueblo of Picuris population. It is also the policy of the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department, consistent with the principles of due process, to provide effective procedures for enforcement.

Enforcement Agency: The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall be responsible for enforcing the provisions of this Ordinance. Specifically, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall conduct investigations when a complaint is received by the Bureau of Indian Affairs or other tribal agency believes that a violation of this Ordinance has occurred.

Enforcement Activities: Where a written and verified complaint shall be filed with the Bureau of Indian Affairs, New Mexico State Police for Taos County (per Special Law Enforcement Commissions in Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council Resolution 2014-10) and the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department and reviewed by the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department alleging that, or where, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department itself shall have cause to believe that, any person is violating any solid waste regulation or permit condition, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall cause a prompt investigation to be made.

Notice of Violation: Cease and Desist Order: If the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department finds after an investigation pursuant to this Ordinance that a violation of any regulation or permit condition exists, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall promptly notify both the alleged violator and the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council, in writing.

In the case of an apparent violation of this Ordinance, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department is authorized to issue a Notice of Violation to the person(s) apparently responsible for the violation, and, if the apparent violation occurred on property owned by a person other than the alleged violator, a Notice of Violation shall also be issued to the landowner.

In the case of a continuing violation or a threatened violation, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department is authorized to issue a Cease and Desist Order to prevent the violation from continuing or occurring.

Failure to comply with a Cease and Desist Order shall constitute a violation of this Ordinance. Both a Notice of Violation and a Cease and Desist Order may be issued for a single incident. A Notice of Violation will include a Summons to appear before the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court at an enforcement hearing at a specified time and date, and shall advise the alleged violator that failure to appear may result in the imposition of civil penalties.

If a Cease and Desist Order is issued without an accompanying Notice of Violation, the Order will inform the recipient that failure to comply with the Order will constitute a violation of this Ordinance which will result in the issuance of a Notice of Violation and may result in the imposition of civil penalties.

Informal Conferences: The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall afford the landowner or his or her representative reasonable opportunities to discuss proposed enforcement actions at an informal conference prior to taking further enforcement action, unless the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department determines that there may be either imminent environmental damage to a Pueblo of Picuris resource or adverse impact upon the health, safety and welfare of the Pueblo of Picuris population. Informal conferences may be used at any stage in the enforcement proceedings, except that the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department may refuse to conduct informal conferences with respect to any matter pending before the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

Reports Required: The Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall keep written notes of the date and place of the conference, the persons in attendance, the subject matter discussed and any decisions reached with respect to further enforcement action.

Enforcement Hearings: If the landowner and the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department are unable to resolve the matter via an informal conference, the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court is authorized to conduct adjudicatory hearings to determine if a violation of this Ordinance has occurred.

In such a hearing the Pueblo of Picuris Solid Waste Department Manager, in cooperation with the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department Director, in cooperation with the Tribal Sheriff shall present the case to the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court to establish that the person(s) charged has (have) committed a violation of this Ordinance. Any person so charged shall be entitled, at his or her own expense, to be represented by an attorney or other representative.

(A) Burden of Proof. The Director of the Pueblo of Picuris Solid Waste Department Manager shall have the burden of proving that a violation of this Ordinance has occurred and that a person charged was responsible for the violation. The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court shall rule that a violation of this Ordinance has occurred if it finds that the charges are supported by substantial evidence and that a preponderance of the credible evidence supports a finding that a violation has occurred.

(B) Enforcement Orders. Within thirty (30) days after the date of any enforcement hearing, the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court shall issue a written decision. If the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court determines that a violation has occurred and that the person(s) charged was (were) responsible for the violation, the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court shall include an Enforcement Order.

Section 11-1-28. Civil Penalties and Corrective Action:

An Enforcement Order shall direct any person(s) found to have committed a violation of this Ordinance to take whatever corrective action the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court deems appropriate under the circumstances. An Enforcement Order may impose civil penalties in accordance with a schedule of civil penalties prescribed in the Committee's rules. Alternatively, an Enforcement Order may impose civil penalties in the event that a person found to have committed a violation of this Ordinance does not take corrective action in accordance with the Order with a prescribed time frame. If a person who has been found to have committed a violation does not take corrective action within the prescribed timeframe, an appropriate department or agency of the Tribal government may by twice the amount of the cost incurred by the Tribal department or agency taking the corrective action.

(A) Emergency Orders. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Ordinance, if the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court determines that noncompliance with this Ordinance is presenting an imminent and substantial threat to the public health, welfare or environment and determines, in consultation with the Tribe's attorneys, that it is not practicable to assure prompt protection of the public health, welfare or environment of an administrative or judicial action under this Part, the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court may issue such orders as may be necessary to protect the public health, welfare or environment. Any such Order shall be effective immediately upon issuance and shall remain in effect for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days.

(B) Revocation Permit: Failure of any person to comply with any Enforcement Orders will result in an immediate revocation of his or her permit. In order to obtain a reinstatement of such permit, the person(s) against who the Enforcement Order was issued must first demonstrate compliance with the Order and pay all outstanding penalties and then petition the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court, in writing, for reinstatement of the permit with the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department.

Section 11-1-29. Special Provisions for Tribal Departments and Agencies:

In any case in which the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council or any Tribal agency or department is alleged to have violated the terms and conditions of a solid waste permit, or to have conducted activities without a permit, the Pueblo of Picuris Environment Department shall bring the matter to the attention of the Governor of the Pueblo of Picuris who shall consider taking action to ensure compliance with this Ordinance.

Section 11-1-30. Appeals Judicial Review:

Any person who is aggrieved by the issuance or denial of a solid waste permit without respect to whether that person, corporation or other entity is a party to such permit application, or who is the subject of an Enforcement Order, may file an appeal with the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court. The Court is authorized to hear such appeal.

Section 11-1-31. Other Provisions

Severability: If any provision of this Ordinance, or the application thereof, is held invalid, the remainder of this Ordinance, or application of such provisions, shall not be affected.

Section 11-1-32. Amendments

The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council reserves the sole right to amend this Ordinance and to issue rules effecting all aspects of the Ordinance. Provisions in the Ordinance allow the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council full flexibility to enact measures which will benefit the Tribe. The inclusion of these provisions does not necessitate their implementation, but allows the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council flexibility to alter the Ordinance according to the evolving needs of the Pueblo of Picuris.

Section 11-1-33. Modifications and Applicability of Part 258 Criteria

This Ordinance incorporates by reference all of the criteria contained in the 40 CFR Part 258. If any part of 40 CFR Part 258 is modified, any modifications are automatically incorporated by reference and become part of this Ordinance, and supercede any of the provisions that were modified. If any of the part 258 Criteria are not actually restated in this Ordinance, they are nevertheless incorporated by reference and are applicable. If the EPA approves the Tribe's solid waste program, then the Tribe has all of the flexibility granted to it under the Part 258 Criteria, whether or not such flexibility is specifically restated in this Ordinance. Any specific provisions of this Ordinance which are more stringent than Part 258 Criteria are applicable and controlling.

Section 11-1-34. Effective Date

This Ordinance shall become effective on _______________________________, 2015.

Section 11-1-35. Sovereign Immunity Preserved

Nothing in this Ordinance is intended to, nor should be interpreted as a waiver of the Tribe's sovereign immunity from unconsented lawsuit, or as authorization for a claim for monetary damages from the Tribe.

TITLE 12 MEDICAL CANNABIS CODE

CHAPTER 1 â GENERAL PROVISIONS

Section 12-1-1. Short Title.

This Title may be cited as the Medical Cannabis Code.

Section 12-1-2. Findings and Purpose.

The Pueblo of Picuris finds and declares that:

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris is a federally recognized Indian tribe and has sovereign powers of self- government to make and enforce their own laws, rules and regulations for medical cannabis activities within tribal lands.

(b) The Pueblo of Picuris has sovereign immunity from suit.

(c) The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Council has decided to open specific tribal lands within its jurisdiction on to the cultivation, processing, use, possession, distribution and research of medical cannabis by enacting this Title to the Pueblo of Picuris Law and Order Code.

(d) The purpose of this Medical Cannabis Code is to civilly regulate those persons, licensed businesses, and lands within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris with respect to medical cannabis.

(e) The Medical Cannabis Code allows for the beneficial use of medical cannabis, upon written recommendation of a medical provider, in a civilly regulated system for the purpose of alleviating symptoms caused by debilitating medical conditions.

(f) In 1997, New Mexico passed the Lynn and Erin Compassionate Use Act to enable persons residing in New Mexico to obtain and use medical cannabis legally under limited, specified circumstances. The Pueblo of Picuris will cooperate with the State of New Mexico on matters of mutual concern, including law enforcement and public safety.

(g) This Medical Cannabis Code regulates the lawful cultivation, processing, use, possession, distribution and research of medical cannabis in a manner consistent with federal law enforcement guidelines and priorities, and is not preempted by, nor does it violate any federal law.

(h) On October 28, 2014, the U.S. Department of Justice issued it Policy Statement on Cannabis Issues in Indian Country (Wilkinson Memo) which recognized the trend of states toward legalization of medical cannabis, and acknowledged that in exercising its national sovereignty Indian tribes may enact similar laws, consistent with the policy priorities therein. This Title is in compliance with the Wilkinson Memo.

(i) The recorded use of cannabis goes back five thousand years. Modern medical research has confirmed the therapeutic value of cannabis in treating a wide array of debilitating medical conditions. Cannabis has many accepted medical uses in the United States, and around the world, having been recognized by public health organizations, including the Epilepsy Foundation, the American College of Physicians, the American Nurses Association, the National Institute of Health, and the National Institute of Drug Abuse.

(j) The Pueblo of Picuris joins the tribes, states and other jurisdictions in the passage of medical cannabis laws to improve and support health and wellness, ensure a lawful and well-regulated medical cannabis program, and to provide fiscal benefits to the Pueblo of Picuris and its tribal members.

Section 12-1-3. Authority to Establish Medical Cannabis Program.

(a) This Title hereby authorizes the Pueblo of Picuris to establish a Medical Cannabis Program to meet the medical needs of tribal members and qualified patients, and to ensure an adequate supply of medical cannabis for the number of patients in the registry, and to provide the right to use and possess cannabis for medical purposes when recommended by a medical provider who has determined that the person's health would benefit from the use of cannabis in the treatment of a debilitating medical condition.

(b) In order to further the goals and to provide an additional source of governmental revenue, the Tribe has adopted this Title, which shall be liberally construed to fulfill the purposes for which it has been adopted.

(c) The Medical Cannabis Program shall have an Executive Committee for administrative decision-making as specified herein, and to promulgate Program Rules as necessary, for adoption by the Tribal Council.

(d) The Medical Cannabis Program shall hire a Program Manager to fulfill the administrative purposes and achieve program implementation who shall report to the Executive Committee for supervision.

(e) Nothing in this Title shall be deemed to be in conflict with the Controlled Substances Act, 21 U.S.C. section 801 et seq. or to otherwise permit any activity that is lawfully prohibited under that Act.

(f) Nothing in this Title shall be deemed to create a right for individuals to grow and distribute cannabis.

(g) Nothing in this Title shall be construed to (1) allow persons to engage in conduct that endangers others or causes a public nuisance; (2) allow the diversion of medical cannabis to anyone other than the registered cardholder; (3) allow any activity relating to the cultivation, distribution, or consumption of cannabis that is otherwise illegal.

(h) The Medical Cannabis Program shall operate to (1) prevent the distribution of cannabis to persons under 21 years of age; (2) prevent the revenue from the sale of cannabis from going where it is legal to other states; (4) prevent cannabis activity that is legal under this title from being used as a cover or pretext for the trafficking of illegal drugs or other illegal activity; (5) prevent violence and the use of firearms in the cultivation and distribution of cannabis; (6) prevent drugged driving and the exacerabation of other adverse public health consequences associated with the use of cannabis; (7) prevent the growing of cannabis on public lands and the attendant public safety and environmental dangers posed by cannabis production on public lands; and (8) prevent the possession and use of cannabis on federal property.

Section 12-1-4. Sovereign Immunity.

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris hereby declares that it is immune from suit under the doctrine of sovereign immunity. All tribal officials and employees, including members of the Tribal Council, and officers and directors of all federal and tribal corporations, acting within their scope of authority and within their scope of duty, are immune from suit for any acts of omissions, pursuant to this Title.

(b) Nothing in this Title shall be construed to limit or waive the sovereign immunity of the Tribe, Tribal Council, or the Board of Directors of the Three Eagles, Inc. for any purpose, expressly or impliedly.

(c) Tribal Corporations that are federally chartered, or chartered under tribal law, may negotiate limited waivers of sovereign immunity for purposes of doing business on tribal lands, pursuant to this Title.

Section 12-1-5. Jurisdiction.

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court retains general jurisdiction over all matters arising from this Medical Cannabis Code.

(b) People who enter the tribal lands, or property, of the Pueblo of Picuris, shall be deemed to have consented to the civil jurisdiction of the Tribe. In additions, any person who utilizes this Medical Cannabis Code, in any manner, shall have consented to the civil jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court for any cause of action arising under this Title.

Section 12-1-6. Taxation of Medical Cannabis.

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris may impose a sales tax comparable to the State and local sales taxes on the sale of medical cannabis.

(b) The tribe may allow an exemption from tax for sales to the tribe, tribal enterprises, tribal-owned businesses, tribally chartered corporations, or tribal members, on medical cannabis cultivated within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris original land grant.

(c) Medical cannabis used in the course of medical treatments by a clinic, hospital, or similarly situated facility owned and operated by a federally recognized Indian tribe within its exterior boundaries may be exempted from taxation under the terms of this Title and federal Indian law.

Section 12-1-7. Full Faith & Credit; Comity.

(a) The Full Faith and Credit Clause of the United States Title (See 28 U.S.C. 1738) and the New Mexico Foreign Judgments Act (See NMSA 39-4A-3 1978) required the recognition and enforcement of Tribal Court Orders and Administrative Orders when doing so does not offend the public policy of the enforcing State.

(b) The Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Registry Identification Cards are consistent with the laws and public policy of the State of New Mexico, who's Department of Health administers the New Mexico Medical Cannabis Program pursuant to the Lynn and Erin Compassionate Use Act.

(c) Comity provides for a mechanism to be able to move formal orders across boundaries for uniformity and symmetry of policy between foreign nations and recognizes the rights of citizens and other persons under the laws of neighboring jurisdictions.

(d) The Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Program shall coexist with the neighboring State of New Mexico in a stable regulatory framework of policies, guidelines, procedural protections and public health reforms.

(e) Tribes have the right to govern themselves. The Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Registry Identification Cards shall be recognized under principles of Full Faith & Credit and comity throughout the State of New Mexico.

Section 12-1-8. Definitions.

(a) "Administrative Order" means a formal decision of an administrative program of the Pueblo of Picuris, including the issuance of a medical cannabis registry identification card.

(b) "Adult Applicant" means a patient twenty0one years of age or older.

(c) "Allowable Supply of Medical Cannabis" means the amount of cannabis that a qualifying patient may presumptively purchase and possess for the qualifying patient's personal medical use, but at no time shall it be greater than six (6) ounces.

(d) "Cannabis" refers to the plant Cannabis, including constituents of the plant and the preparation of the plant.

(e) "Cannabis Business" means a licensed cultivation facility, processing facility, distribution facility, delivery companies, laboratories or any combination thereof.

(f) "Cannabis Concentrate" means specific subset of cannabis that was produced by extracting cannabinoids from cannabis. Types of cannabis concentrates include water-based cannabis concentrates, solvent-based cannabis concentrates, fat-based cannabis concentrates, and critical fluid cannabis concentrates.

(g) "Cannabis Product" means a product that contains cannabis or an extract thereof and is intended for use or consumption other than by inhalation, including but not limited to foodstuffs, extracts, oils tinctures and other similar products.

(h) "Cannabis Testing" means analyzing the safety and potency of cannabis.

(i) "Cardholder" means a qualifying patient, or nonresident cardholder, who has been issued and possesses a valid Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Patient Registry Identification Card pursuant to this title.

(j) "Critical fluid extraction cannabis concentrate" means a cannabis concentrate that was produced by extracting cannabinoids from cannabis the cannabis plant through the use of a solvent.

(k) "Cultivation" means the preparing and growing of the plant Cannabis.

(l) "Cultivation facility" means an entity licensed pursuant to this Title that acquires, possesses, cultivates, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis and related supplies to qualifying cardholders.

(m) "Debilitating Medical Condition" means any condition for which treatment with medical cannabis would be beneficial, as determined by a patient's medical provider, or any other debilitating medical condition, or its symptoms, provided in this Title.

(n) "Delivery Company" means a licensed cannabis business whose purpose is to deliver medical cannabis to qualified validated cardholders.

(o) "Distribution Facility" means any entity license pursuant to this Title that acquires, possesses, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, sells or dispenses cannabis or related supplies and education materials to qualifying cardholders.

(p) "Edible Cannabis Products" means products that contain or are infused with cannabis or an extract thereof; are intended for consumption by oral ingestion; and are presented in the form of foodstuffs, beverages, extracts, oils, tinctures, and other similar products.

(q) "Executive Committee" means the duly appointed Executive Committee of the Medical Cannabis Program, which is to be comprised of no less than three (3) persons who have knowledge of the regulation, cultivation and distribution of medical cannabis, and of tribal law and tribal economic development, to be chosen by the Three Eagles Board of Directors, to serve the best interest of the tribe and its members.

(r) "Fat-based cannabis concentrate" means a cannabis concentrate that was produced by extracting cannabinoids from cannabis through the use of butter, olive oil or other typical cooking fats as a solvent.

(s) "Foreign cultivation facility" means a licensed cultivation or licensed producer facility that is not under the jurisdiction of the Tribe.

(t) "Inventory control" means a process that may be used to monitor the chain of custody of cannabis from the point of cultivation to the consumer.

(u) "Management employees" means those employees who serve in a supervisor role of some nature.

(v) "Medical Advisory Board" means the board of advisors to the Medical Cannabis Program and to the Executive Committee comprised of three (3) medical providers.

(w) "Medical Cannabis" means useable cannabis, cannabis concentrates, and cannabis infused products used for a qualifying conditions pursuant to this Title.

(x) "Medical Provider" means a person licensed in New Mexico to provide a patient with medical or health services, including professional medical providers such as nurses, nurse practitioners, doctors, psychologists, psychiatrists, and other licensed mental health medical providers, substance abuse counselors, licensed naturopaths, chiropractors, doctors of oriental medicine, and other medical providers approved by the Executive Committee, after consultation with the Medical Advisory Board. In order to recommend medical cannabis to a patient, the medical provider shall evaluate and conduct an assessment of the patient's medical history and medical records, if any and current medical condition, including an appropriate examination; in-person or via tele-medicine, and that the medical provider has consulted with the patient with respect to the patient's debilitating medical condition and the possible risks and benefits associated with medical cannabis.

(y) "Minor Applicant" means a patient less than twenty-one years of age.

(z) "Nonresident Medical Cannabis Card" means a currently valid Medical Cannabis Card, or its equivalent, issued by another tribe, state, district, territory, jurisdiction, or country that allows the person to use cannabis for medical purposes in the jurisdiction of issuance.

(aa) "Patient Registry" means the administrative database for valid medical cannabis patients established by the Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Program.

(bb) "Processing" means the harvesting of the plant Cannabis or the use of any process or equipment, including but not limited to dehydrators or humidifiers that may be necessary to convert raw cannabis plants or plant parts into a consumable product.

(cc) "Processing facility" means any entity licensed pursuant to this Title at which cannabis is processed for distribution.

(dd) "Program Manager" means the person hired by the Executive Committee to manage and direct the Medical Cannabis Patient Registry and tribal administrative program.

(ee) "Pueblo of Picuris" means all lands within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo's original land grant; lands held by the United States of America in trust for the Pueblo of Picuris; and any lands which may in the future come within the jurisdiction of the Tribe by any lawful means.

(ff) "Qualifying Patient" means a person who has been diagnosed by a medical provider as having a debilitating medical condition pursuant to this Title.

(gg) "Registry Identification Card" means a document issued by the Pueblo of Picuris that identifies a person as a registered qualifying medical cannabis cardholder. Cardholders and Nonresident Medical Cannabis cardholders may purchase and consume medical cannabis on certain designated premises and places on tribal land.

(hh) "Solvent-based cannabis concentrate" means a Cannabis Concentrate that was produced by extracting cannabinoids from cannabis through the use of glycerin, isopropyl alcohol, ethanol, or propylene glycol as a solvent.

(ii) "State" means the State of New Mexico.

(jj) "Tribe" means , and "Tribal" refers to the Pueblo of Picuris, a federally recognized Indian tribe.

(kk) "Tribal Court" means the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Courts as established pursuant to the Tribe's Law and Order Title.

(ll) "Water-based cannabis concentrate" means a Cannabis Concentrate that was produced by extracting cannabinoids from cannabis through the use of only water or ice.

(mm) "Written certification" means a document dated and signed by a Medical provider, stating that in the medical provider's professional opinion the patient is likely to receive therapeutic or palliative benefit from the medical use of cannabis to treat or alleviate the patient's debilitating medical conditions associated therewith.

CHAPTER 2 â PATIENT REGISTRY

Section 12-2-1. Establishment of a Confidential Patient Registry.

(a) The Medical Cannabis Program shall create and maintain a confidential patient registry of patients who have applied for and are entitled to receive a registry identification card.

(b) All personal medical records and personal identifying information held by the patient registry shall be confidential information.

(c) No person shall be permitted to gain access to any information about patients in this registry, except for authorized employees of the Medical Cannabis Program, or employees of licensed cannabis businesses, in the course of their official duties.

(d) Authorized employees of local law enforcement agencies may be granted access to the information contained within the patient registry only for the purpose of verifying that an individual who has presented a registry identification card is lawfully in possession of such card.

Section 12-2-2. Qualifying Debilitating Medical Conditions.

(a) Qualifying debilitating medical conditions are any medical conditions for which a licensed medical provider certifies in writing that medical cannabis can benefit the patient's health, including, but not limited to the following:

(1) Alzheimer's

(2) Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's Disease)

(3) Anorexia/Cachexia

(4) Arthritis

(5) Autism

(6) Cancer

(7) Chronic Pain

(8) Cirrhosis

(9) Crohn's Disease

(10) Depression

(11) Diabetes

(12) Epilepsy/Seizure Disorder

(13) Fibromyalgia

(14) Gastroesophageal Reflux

(15) Glaucoma

(16) Hepatitis C

(17) HIV/AIDS

(18) Hospice Patients

(19) Huntington's

(20) Inflammatory autoimmune medicated arthritis

(21) Insomnia

(22) Intractable Nausea/Vomiting

(23) Lupus

(24) Migraines

(25) Multiple Sclerosis (MS)

(26) Painful Peripheral Neuropathy

(27) Parkinson's

(28) Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

(29) Spasmodic Torticollis (Cervical Dystonia)

(30) Spinal cord damage

(31) Substance Abuse/Alcoholism

(32) Ulcerative Colitis

(b) The Executive Committee may add, remove or modify a qualifying condition, after review by the Medical Advisory Board of the proposed addition, removal or modification to this Title Section.

Section 12-2-3. Application Requirements for a Registry Identification Card.

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Program Manager may issue Registry Identification Cards to qualifying patients who submit the following documents in accordance with this Title:

(1) A written certification issued by a medical provider within 90 days immediately preceding the date of an application including:

(a) The diagnosis of a qualifying debilitating medical conditions;

(b) A certification that medical cannabis provides adequate relief for the qualifying condition;

(c) The potential risks and benefits of the use of medical cannabis for the qualifying condition have been discussed with the patient;

(d) The name, address and telephone number of the medical provider;

(e) The medical provider's clinical licensure;

(f) The patient's applicant's name, address and date of birth;

(g) The applicant's qualifying debilitating medical condition;

(h) Clinical notes of the medical provider of the debilitating medical condition, which shall include, but not be limited to, a statement that in the medical provider's professional opinion the patient can benefit from the use of medical cannabis;

(i) An attestation that the medical provider's primary place of practice is located within the Pueblo of Picuris or the State of New Mexico;

(j) The medical provider's signature and date;

(k) A copy of the applicant's driver's license, passport, or valid identification issued by a tribal or state government;

(l) A copy of the applicant's nonresident medical cannabis patient card, if applicable;

(m) A release of information and HIPPA forms;

(n) The applicant's social security number, date of birth, signature and date;

(o) The Twenty-Five Dollar ($25.00) application fee; and

(p) Other documentation as the Pueblo of Picuris deems necessary.

(b) A medical provider may be prohibited from certifying patient application under this Title for failure to comply with any provision of this Title; falsification of any material or information submitted; and determination by the medical provider's licensing body that medical provider has engaged in unprofessional or dishonorable conduct.

(c) The Program Manager, or a designee, shall approve or deny an application within twenty (20) calendar days of receipt of the completed application. A request for additional information shall stop the time period until such requested information is received.

Section 12-2-4. Minors with Debilitating Medical Conditions.

(a) Minors who have a valid medical provider's written certification for a qualifying condition may consume medical cannabis under the supervision of their parent or guardian. The Medical Cannabis Program Manager may issue a registry identification care to a minor if:

(1) All application material are submitted and the minor's custodial parent or legal guardian provides proof of legal guardianship; and

(2) The custodial parent or legal guardian signs and submits a written statement that the minor's medical provider has explained to the minor, and to the minor's custodial parent or legal guardian, the potential risks and benefits of the use of medical cannabis; and

(3) The minor's custodial parent or legal guardian consents to the use of medical cannabis by the minor; and

(4) The custodial parent or legal guardian agrees to control the dosage and frequency of the use of medical cannabis by the minor; and

(5) The custodial parent or legal guardian agrees not to divert any medical cannabis in their possession pursuant to this Title.

Section 12-2-5. Registry Identification Card Issuance; Administrative Order.

(a) The Pueblo of Picuris shall establish and maintain a Medical Cannabis Program for the issuance of Registry Identification Cards to qualified persons who meet the requirements.

(b) The Program Manager, or a designee, shall issue a Registry Identification Card to a person who is a resident of the Pueblo of Picuris, a resident of any Pueblo or Tribe in New Mexico, or a resident of the State of New Mexico, or a person with a verified Nonresident Medical Cannabis Card who submits an application on a form prescribed by the Program Manager accompanied by all documents required by this Title.

(c) The Registry Identification Card is an Administrative Order of the Medical Cannabis Program and shall be upheld by the Tribal Court and acknowledged and enforced as such.

(d) Upon receipt of the Application for a Medical Cannabis Registry Identification Card, the Program Manager shall:

(1) Record on the Application the date it is received;

(2) Retain the original Application and make two copies for the file;

(3) Review the contents of the Application and verify information accordingly;

(4) Identify any incomplete or missing items in the Application and notify the applicant of said review and decision;

(5) Recommend the approval or denial of the Application; and

(6) Issue or deny the Registry Identification Card, with written notice provided.

Section 12-2-6. Three-Year Term; Renewal of Registry Identification Card.

(a) A Registry Identification Card is valid for a period of three (3) years and may be renewed by submitting a Renewal Application, a fee of Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) and all of the required documents.

Section 12-2-7. Revocation of Registry Identification Card.

(a) If at any time, the Program Manager, or a designee, determines that a person provided false information on his or her Application, or Renewal Application, or is violating the rules of the Medical Cannabis Program, the registry identification card issued to that person shall immediately be revoked, and written notice provided in accordance with this Title.

(b) A person whose registry identification card has been revoked pursuant to this Title may not reapply for a registry identification card for at least twelve (12) months after the date of revocation.

Section 12-2-8. Denial of Registry Identification Card.

(a) The Program Manager shall give written notice to the applicant of the reason for denying a Registry Identification Card. Denial of an application or renewal is considered a final decision. The application or renewal may be denied if the applicant;

(1) Does not provide the required information, fee, or required materials after three (3) written requests;

(2) Previously had a registry identification card revoked; or

(3) Provided false information.

Section 12-2-9. Contents of Registry Identification Card.

(a) Medical Cannabis Registry Identification Cards must contain all of the following:

(1) The name and photograph of the cardholder;

(2) The date of issuance and expiration date of the registry identification card and;

(3) A random 10-digit alphanumeric identification number, containing at least four numbers and at least four letters, that is unique to the cardholder.

(b) The expiration date shall be (3) three years after the date of issuance. If the medical provider certifies that the qualifying patient would benefit from medical cannabis until an earlier specified date, then the registry identification card shall expire on that date.

Section 12-2-10. Cardholder Required Notifications.

(a) A registered cardholder shall notify the Program Manager of any change in his or her name or address within thirty (3) days of the change.

(b) A registered cardholder shall notify the Program Manager if they lose their registry identification card within thirty (30) days of becoming aware the card has been lost.

(c) There is a Twenty-Five Dollar ($25.00) replacement fee.

(d) After receiving the replacement fee, if the cardholder remains eligible under this Title, the Program Manager shall issue the cardholder a new medical cannabis registry identification card with a new random 10-digit alphanumeric identification number within ten (10) business days of receiving the notification.

(e) If a medical provider notifies the Program Manager in writing that either the registered cardholder has ceased to suffer from a debilitating medical condition, or that the medical provider no longer believes the cardholder would receive therapeutic or palliative benefit from the medical use of cannabis, the card shall become null and void.

Section 12-2-11. Protection for the Use of Medical Cannabis.

(a) A medical cannabis cardholder who possesses a valid Pueblo of Picuris medical cannabis registry identification card is not subject to arrest, prosecution, or penalty in any manner, or denial of any right or privilege, including any civil penalty or disciplinary action by a court, or occupational or professional licensing board or bureau for the medical use of medical cannabis pursuant to his Title, provided the cardholder does not possess more than the allowable amount of medical cannabis, and that any medical cannabis being carried shall be enclosed in a sealed container, if it is being possessed or transported for personal medical use.

(b) There is a presumption that a qualifying cardholder is engaged in the medical use of cannabis pursuant to this Title if the cardholder is in possession of a Pueblo of Picuris registry identification card and an amount of cannabis that does not exceed the allowable amount of cannabis.

(c) A medical provider shall not be subject to arrest, prosecution, or penalty in any manner, or denied any right or privilege, including, but limited to, civil penalty or disciplinary action by any other occupational or professional licensing board or bureau, solely for providing written certifications or for otherwise stating that, in the medical provider's professional opinion, a person is likely to receive therapeutic or palliative benefit from the medical use of cannabis to treat or alleviate the patient's debilitating medical condition, or symptoms associated with the debilitating medical condition, or symptoms associated with the debilitating medical condition.

(d) For the purposes of the laws of the Pueblo of Picuris, activities related to medical cannabis shall be considered lawful as long as they are in compliance with this Title.

(e) No law enforcement officer employed by an agency which receives state, local, or federal government funds shall expend any resources, including the officer's time, to effect any arrest or seizure of medical cannabis, or conduct any investigations, on the sole basis of activity the officer believes to constitute a violation of the federal law if the officer has reason to believe that such activity is in compliance with this civil law Title.

(f) It is the public policy of the Pueblo of Picuris that lawful activities related to medical cannabis that are entered into by cardholders, medical cannabis businesses or licensed facilities, or medical cannabis business or licensed facility agents, are exempt from criminal penalties by this Title.

Section 12-2-12. Limitation on the Use of Medical Cannabis.

(a) The use and possession of medical cannabis is limited by operation of law and certain conduct is prohibited. This Title prohibits:

(1) Operating, navigating or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle or ATV while impaired by the influence of medical cannabis; and

(2) Undertaking any task under the influence of medical cannabis, when doing so would constitute negligence or pose a reasonably foreseeable harm to oneself or others.

Section 12-2-13. Lawful Possession and Use of Medical Cannabis.

(a) A medical cannabis patient shall ensure that all cannabis, cannabis-derived products, and paraphernalia are kept secure and out of the reach of children under the age of 21.

(b) All medical cannabis shall remain in a sealed package or container when not in use.

(c) Patients are strictly prohibited from using medical cannabis in any undesignated public place and on federal property.

(d) Special events for medical cannabis patients 21 and over are permitted under this Title in designated areas at limited times and places only for the purposes permitted and approved by the Executive Committee.

Section 12-2-14. Medical Cannabis Cardholder Discrimination Prohibited.

(a) No school or landlord may refuse to enroll, lease to, or otherwise penalize a person solely for the person's status as a medical cannabis cardholder.

(b) A person shall not be denied custody, visitation rights, or parenting time with a minor child solely for the person's status as a cardholder, and there shall be no presumption of neglect or child endangerment for conduct allowed under this Title, unless the person's behavior is such that it creates an unreasonable danger to the safety of the minor as established by clear and convincing evidence.

(c) A cardholder who uses medical cannabis shall be afforded all the same rights and responsibilities as the individual would be afforded if he or she were solely prescribed pharmaceutical medications, as it pertains to any interaction with a person's employer.

(d) The Pueblo of Picuris and all cannabis businesses and licensed facilities shall remain a Drug Free Workplace.

Section 12-2-15. Indemnification.

(a) The Tribe, including its officers, employees, agents, representatives, successors, and assigns, shall not be held responsible for any injurious outcomes form the use of medical cannabis by any person.

Section 12-2-16. Medical Advisory Board.

(a) The Executive Committee shall appoint a Medical Advisory Board comprised of no less than three (3) medical providers with experience in medical cannabis research and treatment modalities; individuals with experience in policy development or implementation in the field of medical cannabis; and medical support staff.

(b) The Medical Advisory Board shall meet at least twice per year for the purpose of evaluating and making recommendations to the Executive Committee regarding;

(1) The ability of qualifying cardholders to obtain timely access to high-quality medical cannabis;

(2) The effectiveness of the cultivation facilities in serving the needs of qualifying cardholders, including the provision of educational and support services, the reasonableness of their prices, whether they are generating any complaints or security problems, and the sufficiency of the number operating to produce adequate supply for registered qualifying cardholders;

(3) The effectiveness of the medical cannabis testing facilities and services;

(4) The sufficiency of the regulatory and security safeguards contained in this Title to ensure that access to and use of medical cannabis cultivated is provided only to cardholders;

(5) Any recommended additions or revisions to the Medical Cannabis Program or list of qualifying conditions, and

(6) Any research studies regarding health effects of medical cannabis.

Section 12-2-17. Recognition of Nonresident Medical Cannabis Cards.

(a) As used in this section, "nonresident card" means a medical cannabis card issued by a State, Tribe, or jurisdiction other than Pueblo of Picuris; and is the functional equivalent of a registry identification card, as determined by the Program Manager, or a designee.

(b) The Pueblo of Picuris Medical Cannabis Program may verify and recognize a nonresident card under the following circumstances;

(1) The nonresident card has an expiration date and has not yet expired; and

(2) The cardholder of the nonresident card agrees to abide by, and shall abide by, the legal limitations on the possession and use of medical cannabis in this Title.

(c) The Program Manager may assess a Twenty-Five Dollar ($25.00) administrative fee for nonresident cardholder to receive a Pueblo of Picuris Registry Identification Card.

CHAPTER 3 â LICENSING

Section 12-3-1. Cannabis Businesses; Licensure.

(a) The Executive Committee shall determine the appropriate number of licensed cannabis businesses, including cultivation facilities, processing facilities, distribution facilities, deliver companies, testing laboratories, or any combination thereof, based on the number of medical cannabis patients in the Medical Cannabis Program registry, and other relevant business considerations.

(b) Each licensed cannabis business under the jurisdiction of the Tribe shall be required to meet all licensing requirements under this Title.

(c) The Executive Committee may assess a licensing fee per annum to each licensed cannabis business.

(d) All medical cannabis businesses must be licensed by the Executive Committee to lawfully operate within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris.

(e) All cultivation, processing, packaging and storing of cannabis must take place in a secure facility that may only be accessed by licensed persons and authorized visitors.

(f) All licensed facilities shall be constructed, maintained, and operated in a manner that adequately protects the environment and the health and safety of the public.

(g) The Executive Committee may limit the size, location, capacity, and hours of operation of all licensed facilities.

(h) No licensed facility may be located within 300 feet of a school, church, or daycare center.

(i) All licensed facilities shall adopt security and safety procedures and protocols, including lighting, signage, video surveillance, alarms, employee badges/wands, panic buttons, emergency response policies and operational policies that ensure the security of the crop and prevents diversion for non-medical purposes.

(j) Firearms are prohibited at all times at a licensed facility.

Section 12-3-2. Employee Requirements.

(a) Every employee of a cannabis business shall be required to obtain from the Program Manager, or its designee, a Cannabis Business Employee License as a prerequisite to such employment on tribal lands.

(b) The application for a Cannabis Employee License shall include the following information:

(1) The name, address, telephone number, email address, social security number and date of birth of the applicant;

(2) Proof that the applicant is at least twenty one (21) years of age;

(3) A current photograph of the applicant;

(4) Nationwide criminal background search results for the past five (5) years to establish that the applicant has not been convicted of any felony offense involving a crime of violence, fraud, theft, or involvement with organized crime, within the past five (5) years. For each conviction, the name and address of the court involved and the date and disposition. A conviction within the meaning of this subsection means a plea or verdict of guilty or a conviction following a plea of nolo contendere;

(5) Currently and for the previous five (5) years; business and employment positions held, ownership interests in those businesses, business and residence addresses, and driver's license numbers;

(6) The names, telephone numbers, email address and current physical address of at least two (2) references, including at least one (1) professional reference;

(7) Written permission of the applicant authorizing the Program Manager or its designee to seek verification of the information contained within the application;

(8) A statement in writing that the applicant pledges to not dispense or otherwise divert cannabis to any person or entity that is not allowed to lawfully possess cannabis.

(9) A statement in writing that the applicant certifies under penalty of perjury that all the information contained in the application is true and correct; and

(10) Any other information the Program Manager deems relevant.

(c) Unless otherwise suspended or revoked, a Cannabis Employee License shall expire three (3) years following its issuance. A person may re-apply for a Cannabis Employee License for subsequent periods of three (3) years.

Section 12-3-3. Eligibility Determination.

(a) The Program Manager or its designee shall review an applicant's prior activities, criminal record, and reputation, to make a finding concerning the eligibility for employment in a cultivation facility, distribution facility or processing facility.

Section 12-3-4. Grounds for Denial of Cannabis Employee License.

(a) The grounds for denial of a Cannabis Employee License may be one or more of the following:

(1) The applicant has violated this Title;

(2) The applicant has knowingly made a false statement of material fact or has knowingly omitted to state a material fact in the application for a Cannabis Employee License;

(3) The applicant has been convicted of a felony offense involving a crime of violence, fraud, theft, or involvement with organized crime, within the past five (5) years. A conviction within the meaning of this subsection means a plea or verdict of guilty or a conviction following a plea of nolo contendere;

(4) A determination by the Program Manager or the Executive Committee that employment of the applicant poses a threat to the public interest or to the effective regulation of cannabis; or

(5) The applicant is under twenty one (21) years of age.

Section 12-3-5. Reconsideration of Denial.

(a) A person aggrieved by the decision of the Program Manager or its designee to deny a Cannabis Employee License may seek reconsideration of such decision to the Executive Committee by filing a written petition for reconsideration with the Tribal Court within thirty (30) calendar days of service of the written notice of decision. If a petition for reconsideration is not filed within such time, the decision shall be final.

(b) Following review of the petition for reconsideration, the Program Manager may issue the Cannabis Employee License subject to such conditions as it deems reasonable under the circumstances to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the Pueblo of Picuris and its tribal members or it may deny the issuance of the Cannabis Employee License for any of the grounds specified in this Title. The decision of the Executive Committee shall be final and not subject to judicial review by tribal, federal or state court.

CHAPTER 4 â CULTIVATING CANNABIS

Section 12-4-1. Cultivation Facility; Licensure.

(a) Prior to licensure, each cultivation facility shall establish written operating procedures for the cultivation of medical cannabis. The operating procedures must include the following information:

(1) An acknowledgement that no pesticides and other agricultural chemicals are to be applied during its cultivation process;

(2) The equipment and methods employed in the cultivation of the cannabis;

(3) How the cultivated cannabis will be transported to a processing facility or distribution facility;

(4) The measures taken to minimize or offset energy use from the cultivation of cannabis;

(5) The manner in which waste will be stored at the premises;

(6) The production plan;

(7) The sales and distribution plan;

(8) The manufacturing plan for cannabis derived products;

(9) The quality assurance plan;

(10) The security plan;

(11) Testing and Labeling Requirements;

(12) Employee Training Plan; and

(13) Any other information required by the Executive Committee.

(b) A copy of all operating procedures must be maintained at every cultivation facility.

Section 12-4-2. On-site Consumption Prohibited.

The use of consumption of cannabis shall be prohibited at each cultivation facility, except in a designated area for employees who are valid Registry Identification Cardholders.

Section 12-4-3. Quality Assurance; Testing Requirements.
